headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations. P
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Gene Coleman, Executive Vice President, Offshore
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Gene Coleman, Executive Vice President, Offshore; and Mike McFadyen, Executive Vice President, Onshore. Please refer to the informational slides that we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with your webcast today. 
Today's prepared comments will be a little bit longer than usual so that we can give you more color on our recently announced joint venture. John will begin by providing a review of the fourth quarter financial results and key year-end balance sheet position. Roger will then follow with an operational update as well as more details regarding the Montney Midstream monetization and Duvernay Montney joint venture opportunity we just announced. We will end the call with a question-and-answer period. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on the Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy makes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Consolidated results in the fourth quarter of 2015 were a loss of $587 million, that's $3.41 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $375 million or $2.11 per diluted share a year ago. Excludin
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Consolidated results in the fourth quarter of 2015 were a loss of $587 million, that's $3.41 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $375 million or $2.11 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations, continuing operations had a loss of $583 million in the fourth quarter of '15, $3.39 per diluted share, and that compares to the fourth quarter '14 of $442 million profit, $2.48, per diluted share a year ago. The fourth quarter results for 2015 from continuing operations included noncash property impairments of $192.2 million, which after taxes amounted to $123.5 million charge. These impairments were attributable to a decline in future periods oil prices and primarily were related to an oil and gas property in the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico. The just completed quarter also included an after-tax expense of $183.3 million to reflect the cost to exit 2 Deepwater drilling rig contracts in the Gulf of Mexico. We chose to stack these rigs as low oil prices led to significant reductions in our capital expenditure program in the Gulf of Mexico, and the company was no longer able to obtain partner support for U.S. Deepwater drilling as these partners are experiencing significant capital constraints. 
Murphy also recorded a U.S. income tax charge of $188.5 million in the fourth quarter due to U.S. taxable income generated foreign dividend declared in December. The company had previously recorded U.S. income tax benefits earlier in 2015 associated with an anticipated U.S. operating loss carryforward prior to our decision to make this foreign distribution to the parent. The foreign distribution was made through a combination of $800 million in cash and the remainder in the form of a 10-year note. This distribution effectively was cash tax neutral in 2015 due to operating losses and availability of foreign tax credits. This U.S. tax charge was recorded in the company's corporate reporting area, which led to a higher corporate net cost overall in the 2015 quarter compared to the prior year. 
Let me speak about adjusted earnings. These adjusted earnings adjust our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of earnings between periods. And this adjusted earnings was a loss of $130.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2015, down from a profit of $69 million a year ago. This decline in adjusted earnings was primarily attributable to lower oil and natural gas sales prices in the current period. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
The company's average realized price for its crude oil production fell more than $28 per barrel in the fourth quarter compared to the prior year which amounted to a 40% drop between periods. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the fourth quarter compared to the prior-year quarter. 
Realized oil index natural gas process offshore Sarawak fell 31% to an average of $3.81 per Mcf following the decline in global crude oil prices. Sales prices continue to be soft in January and, therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as quarter 1 2016 prices remain significantly below prices a year ago. As a reminder, however, the company has oil price hedges for 20,000 barrels per day at a WTI price of $52.01 for the remainder of 2016.
At December 31, 2015, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to slightly more than $3 billion, which represented 36.4% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to 32.8%. As of year end, we had $600 million borrowed under our $2 billion revolver. Plus we had a total of cash and invested cash for about $450 million worldwide. Murphy sold debt covenant is a total debt to total capital ratio of 60%, which obviously were well below. I believe we have adequate liquidity to weather the lower for longer oil price environment currently being experienced. 
That concludes my comments, and I'll pass it now to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Our company remains focused on balance sheet metrics as the entire industry experiences further commodity price drops. But this focus comes in extensive drop in capita
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Our company remains focused on balance sheet metrics as the entire industry experiences further commodity price drops. But this focus comes in extensive drop in capital spending; however, Murphy intends to be in the business for the long haul and is evidenced with news of our 2 purchase and sales agreements we released yesterday when closed will allow Murphy to sell the natural gas midstream business and use a portion of the proceeds to purchase a long-term asset that deliver value to shareholders say, especially in a price recovery. 
Looking back at operations over the course of the year, the following highlights stand out. We spent $2.2 billion in capital, which is 42% down from the prior year, while still growing production with the prior year when factoring in the 30% fell down in Malaysia. 
On the coal side, we made significant improvements in reducing both operating and G&A expenses. We lowered our operating costs excluding Syncrude by $1.82 per BOE to $9.21 per BOE or 17% over the course of 2015 and lowered our G&A expenses by over $57 million or 16% compared to 2014 levels. 
In our onshore business, the Eagle Ford Shale continues to outperform expectations, where we averaged just over 57,000 barrel equivalents per day for the year, delivering a frontloaded schedule of 136 new wells, of which 27 were in the fourth quarter. We drilled our first thousand well in Orange County, achieving a very successful IP 30 flow rate of 1,500 barrels equivalent per day. We're planning on doing our second [indiscernible] well in the first quarter of 2016. 
In Canada, our recently completed wells in the Montney continue to produce above plan where we averaged 194 million cubic feet per day for the year. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, the Dalmatian South 2 well which was drilled in the third quarter achieved first production ahead of plan late in 2015, the world's currently facility. 
Development work continues at the nonoperated Kodiak project where the first 2 wells will flow in the coming days. 
In Malaysia, fourth quarter Sarawak natural gas production is over 134 million per day net and oil production was over 14,000 barrels a day. Full year production for Malaysia was over 65,200-barrel equivalents per day. 
We are seeing continued drilling success at our South axis drill in Sarawak where we announced the Sergeant volumes double. In addition, we drilled the Keratau well offshore Brunei, finding commercial natural gas that were in line with pre drill estimates adding to our resources in the field. 
On the fourth quarter, production was just over 200,700 barrel equivalents per day and a full-year for the year, we produced close to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day.
We are pleased with the ongoing efforts we're making on cost reductions. Our LOE for quarter 4 2015, excluding Syncrude, is 8 25 per BOE, showing a reduction of 19% from the fourth quarter of '14. This is in line with the 17% reduction for full-year 2014 on LOE. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, our fourth quarter operating expenses just under 8 50 per BOE, and we expect this to be a reasonable runway going forward. 
In 2015, we produced over 207 barrel of oil equivalent per day, our strong production variance over the course of the year is attributable to Sarawak oil and natural gas fields is performing better. The Eagle Ford Shale, new well volumes exceeding plan due to EUR increases and completion performance and how our natural gas production from the Montney. 
More importantly, we spent $2.19 billion as compared to our original CapEx plan of $2.3 billion. Even with the significant reduction in capital for 2015, we grew annual production by 3%. 
In 2015, based on preliminary data, we expect to add reserves at a replacement rate of 123% for the funding and development costs of $18.70 per BOE. Year end 2015 reserve volumes represented Reserve Life Index of 10.2 years, an increase from 9.2 years from a year ago. This is consistent with our five-year average reserve replacement rate greater than 180% and is our 10th consecutive year over 100%. During the same time frame, we have more than doubled our production, including the sell down of our Malaysia assets. 
The capital program for 2016 is currently $825 million, which is approximately 62% lower than $2.19 billion we invested in 2015. We expect production for full-year to be 180,000 to 185,000 barrel equivalents per day, which is lower than 2015 due to significant CapEx cuts. As common in our industry, the capital program still remains in review for further reductions as commodity prices persist.
Moving on to the subsequent year events, as you've heard in our news release last night, we signed 2 purchase and sale agreements announcing the monetization of our midstream Montney and the joint venture of the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids rich Montney on the area. We signed a definitive agreement with Enbridge to divest our natural gas processing sales pipeline assets that support our Montney natural gas field in topper and upper West. The cash consideration is expected to be CAD 538 million and expected to be closed early in the second quarter. 
In a separate but related transaction, we signed a definitive agreement for a joint venture with Athabasca Oil Corporation to acquire 70% operated working interest in Athabasca's acreage infrastructure and facilities in the Kaybob Duvernay lands and a 30% nonoperated working interest in the liquids rich Montney. The total consideration is CAD 475 million, of which CAD 250 million is in cash at closing and the remaining CAD 225 million is a carry for a period up to 5 years. 
In the Kaybob Duvernay, there were 230,000 gross acres, 200,000 currently perspective that are currently producing 6,900-barrel equivalent gross per day of production, of which 58% is liquids. This area also includes 247,000 gross acres with over rights in the conventional Montney. 
In the liquids rich Montney area, there are 60,000 gross acres, 21,000 currently perspective that are currently producing 900-barrel equivalent a day gross at 44% liquids. 
Very excited to enter to the Kaybob Duvernay and liquid rich Montney that complements our current onshore North America and resources, fits well with our in-house expertise and will be our third significant North American unconventional position. The CAD 225 million carry in Long Beach term associated with the Kaybob Duvernay is flexible over 5 years, which is key in this period of low commodity prices where we are able to control the pace of spend. We're allocating partial proceeds from our Montney midstream monetization into this project sufficient use of capital that has a positive impact to cash on hand for our balance sheet this year as well as use of Canadian funds in Canada in a tax efficient manner and enter a project that's expected to be self funding within Canada over the life of the period. 
The primary markable product hearing is realized will be produced condensate, which is used for oil Sands vitamin production and transport. The Western Canadian oil Sands project along been demonstrated record of production resiliency that will continue to generate demand well in the excess of regional supply results in the relative price stability for the foreseeable future. Our joint venture has oil battery capacity of 30,000 barrels today of oil and gas pipeline with over 100 million [indiscernible] per day of capacity.
The Kaybob Duvernay is an emerging play and has 3 same segments seen in the Eagle Ford Shale, natural gas, gas condensate and light oil. The gas condensate area is including several prolific wells of late in the light oil area that we now have a significant position in is in the early stages of development. We are seeing all signs of the shale place success with increasing EURs, improving completion techniques as well as lowering the drilling and completion costs. We feel that with 3 to 4 wells per section, we will have over 500 gross locations in the play and this number will greatly increase should downspacing opportunities exist here as seen in other successful North American plays. 
We are seeing many successful wells across the play now approaching 30 test centers [indiscernible] over 2,000-barrel equivalent per day with yields ranging from 200 to 950 barrel per million and a clear indicator of the oil-rich nature of this basin. 
The Duvernay areas have been heavily drilled for other types of plays through the years in the basin which leads to thousands of penetrations and knowledge of the shale characteristics. Additionally, we have a black hole area in the play, again matching success seen in the Eagle Ford Shale area.
Our new joint venture partner, Athabasca, has been successful in the play with the results the condensate region and most importantly, in the light oil area of the play. Athabasca's recently released information about our key oil and the gas condensate light oil area that's flowed 1,300-barrel equivalents per day with 62% liquids. This appears to be a very good well by any measure. 
As in any shale play, the optimization of the fracture treatments are key to the learning curve in the light higher prop and concentrations have used in the region. This slide highlights the increase in EUR seen that data up to 2 years in duration illustrating recent higher treatments consistent EUR levels. Some wells are announcing above the 1,000 -- 1 million, rather, barrel type curve. This will shown here in the condensate window are now partnered in the 33,000 acres with a 70% working interest. We've seen the same well performance with higher stimulation treatments in the Duvernay light oil area as well as where we are working a 7% working interest with our partner in 67,000 acres. We believe there's significant upside in the black hole area where our partnership has 110,000 gross acres. Current data showing high prop content at the 607 -- 670,000-barrel equivalent EUR level. 
Our joint venture also includes our liquids rich Montney, which is among the top active plays in Canada. We participate here in the nonop 30% working interest. The region has a minimum of 30% of the flow stream containing liquids, similar to the condensate in light oil areas. The results in the liquid rich area are also shown increasingly EURs completion enhancements and the lowering of cost with 750,000-barrel equivalent EURs seen in the data set. This area has significant running room in the range of 100 to 200 locations with downspacing. We see a tightening leased up area around our newer acreage with many no North American shale players. Rates here are also prolific in the range of 800 barrel equivalents with high liquid yields.
Like all major shale plays in North America, the key economic drivers is lowering the drilling and completion cost while simultaneously improving the completion techniques for each area. We are seeing the early stages of a major improvement in cost per region and our expertise in 2 other plays where we are top quartile drilling and completion company will enhance our ability to quickly move up the learning curve here. Our partner Athabasca is active in the cost reduction business, and we will be able to quickly adapt to the area where they have recently seen incredible improvements as we see great upside in lowering cost from the current CAD 9.4 million per well don to CAD 6.5 million per well. Athabasca has recently seen wells being drilled for as low as CAD 3.25 million, which is an outstanding performance. 
As I close our call today, if you a few takeaways we are focusing on our balance sheet at Murphy. The purchase and sale agreements to monetize our natural gas midstream and use a portion of proceeds whether new onshore oil conventionally shale play that allows for balance sheet neutrality with a 5-year carrying liquidity this year for our cash positions. We see this venture as an investment to the long term with total spend flexibility over a five-year period as we anticipate a price recovery. Cost reductions will continue to be our focus. Our Eagle Ford Shale continues to perform very well for us. The budget reductions will lead to a very limited exploration spend this year. We continue to illustrate the execution advantages we have in the offshore. We had an excellent year operationally in our company with the reserve additions, significant capital reductions and lowering costs leading the way. 
I would now like to open the phone lines up for your questions, and thank you.

componenttextpreview: Can we talk about the acquisition. I mean, I know the sell down in Malaysia, a little over a year ago, I think that's right, yes, or at least the announcement. Then the talk of a transformative acquisition. Is this one of those transformative acquisitions
componenttext: Can we talk about the acquisition. I mean, I know the sell down in Malaysia, a little over a year ago, I think that's right, yes, or at least the announcement. Then the talk of a transformative acquisition. Is this one of those transformative acquisitions? Or should we still consider something in the lower 48 is still more likely and still desirable opportunity?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think of it as transformative for us. I mean, it's got all of the things we're looking for today. It's very rare to get into M&A in North America and have flexibility in the first year of capital spend and have no continuous drilling causes, be able
componenttext: No. I think of it as transformative for us. I mean, it's got all of the things we're looking for today. It's very rare to get into M&A in North America and have flexibility in the first year of capital spend and have no continuous drilling causes, be able to drag out the carryover a very long period of time and a very low oil price. I've said for a long time that I would like a 10% cost of capital type return at a strip price. And with the drilling costs we are seeing here, we are able to do that here, even on strip that we used on January 19, which is probably $4 behind where we are today. So I see this as transformative as far as Roger, honestly, because it has a 200 million, 300 million barrel ability for us. It's pretty low cost entry. It's different from buying a company that's flipping acres because we have a partner that's working there and has drilled there, has infrastructure there, and we're able to work with them and take over as the operator. They're able to operate a piece where they've been very successful. It's in Canada. We'll have Canadian proceeds. There's a low 4x right now for this transaction. Where the U.S. the equivalent of that would not get you at least to get you here in the United States. And all of those factors led to this decision.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we look at many opportunities. I do the same thing, whether its offshore or in the Permian or in the Eagle Ford or whatever. We look at the rate of return we get at strip prices and with cost and how will it flex our balance sheet and how we h
componenttext: No, I mean, we look at many opportunities. I do the same thing, whether its offshore or in the Permian or in the Eagle Ford or whatever. We look at the rate of return we get at strip prices and with cost and how will it flex our balance sheet and how we have to drill so much capital and hurt our balance sheet further, and that's come up as a venue factor in the M&A analysis that we had from a year ago. And that's just as important now. The balance sheet of how one of these projects would impact you is anything for me now. So we saw the return to a very similar to a project where we working in the lower 48 but we ended up with a project in the lower 48, totally downspaced, every zone working, at the same rate of return as one in Canada where we have no downspacing at all, built-in partner, 5-year lease program, five-year carry period and just every advantage to me in $30 oil that don't have down here right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And last question I'll ask on the acquisition front. You've always talked about you wanted to use cash or debt. Obviously, now debt is a little more questionable as an opportunity for a whole host of reasons. Would you, at all, consider issui
componenttext: Okay. Great. And last question I'll ask on the acquisition front. You've always talked about you wanted to use cash or debt. Obviously, now debt is a little more questionable as an opportunity for a whole host of reasons. Would you, at all, consider issuing equity? I know that's not something the company's historically done, but as you think about that cost of capital, does that factor in or not so much?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Roger we are working pretty hard on these 2 transactions and I don't have another one in the pocket today, I'm pretty tart. And taking us a lot of work to do these 2 and we didn't have to use debt and we didn't have to use equity and I'm very please
componenttext: Well, Roger we are working pretty hard on these 2 transactions and I don't have another one in the pocket today, I'm pretty tart. And taking us a lot of work to do these 2 and we didn't have to use debt and we didn't have to use equity and I'm very pleased and not looking for a deal today to issue equity at this price in my company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a very nice transaction. We're very pleased with it. We're not disclosing the tariff arrangement there. You would have to look at cost of capital as top players, residual value and you can work through that. I think the way to think about this bus
componenttext: We have a very nice transaction. We're very pleased with it. We're not disclosing the tariff arrangement there. You would have to look at cost of capital as top players, residual value and you can work through that. I think the way to think about this business is if you have $1.90 to $2 echo [ph] that business every year, we're able to drill that dwells and have cash flow neutrality and not hurt our balance sheet in any way, a lot of optionality around how many wells we drill, we're doing very well there in the EUR per well basis. We're able to get the money from these guys at the favorable rate to us as to how this works and we're able to use these proceeds of selling steel and getting into 200, 300 million barrel reserves type P2 number. And I like the sound of it, like the transaction, and we are not concerned about the level of drilling that we'll need to do or allocate capital here because of the incredible reduction in our operating expenses, our improved fracturing techniques, our lower drilling cost and all the positive attributes shale we have in the Montney 2. And we have very good partner there, one is dominating the plays in North American space and very, very happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Great. Just maybe kind of circling back to the Duvernay, realize the ink still haven't been dried yet on this deal, but how are you guys kind of just high-level thinking about development over the next couple of years? Is kind of the light oil window going to be the near-term area of focus? Actually we think about derisking that new position there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we have -- just got the ink dry on those deals are complex. And today in the price collapse and doing the deal like this with our partner, very happy about all the areas. And I would say that we concentrate in a mixture of both the condensat
componenttext: Well, I mean, we have -- just got the ink dry on those deals are complex. And today in the price collapse and doing the deal like this with our partner, very happy about all the areas. And I would say that we concentrate in a mixture of both the condensate, which is very, very successful by winning successful share players. Pretty big light oil window that were creeping north toward if you look to the slides today. And we'll have a limited capital in 2016 because of severe drop in price. Most of that capital will be allocated to our completing wells that are owned by the partner today when we close the transaction. And got about a 6 or 9 month period to plan out where we want to execute on that. But very pleased with all the areas and be happy to drill wells in any of it, to be honest with you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a dividend policy here for a very long time. And the oil prices just collapsed for a short time. But like any company today, if these price levels persist, then the dividend discussion will be on the table here in our company. And we will
componenttext: Well, we've had a dividend policy here for a very long time. And the oil prices just collapsed for a short time. But like any company today, if these price levels persist, then the dividend discussion will be on the table here in our company. And we will have that and review that as necessary. And I would say we'll be on the table in these prices more than before. And that's really all I have to say in that matter.

So any return framework for how you think these assets for capital in the current environment or rising oil price environment? I think would help us better understand this?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in a very big collapse in price here recently of course and when we say strip, where we're using a January 19 strip, and it's around 32 76 2016 $37 for '17 and up to $44 in 2020 of course today, these numbers are about $4 better than that. And
componenttext: Well, we're in a very big collapse in price here recently of course and when we say strip, where we're using a January 19 strip, and it's around 32 76 2016 $37 for '17 and up to $44 in 2020 of course today, these numbers are about $4 better than that. And when we run through this entire thing, as we've always said and always desired and requirement here, is we'd be above 10%. When we look at current drilling and completion costs, which are very critical, and that's down spacing at all. And then we have another price deck here, we call our low planning price from January, it's a very low price for '16, around $29, $41 in '17 and going up to $60 in 2020. And this project looks very good, as good as any M&A we've seen and above 15 range. And when you get a big cost, big price recovery deck here, we'll get to the 20% range. So we're very happy about it. It stacks up well with all the opportunities we reviewed across the spectrum and we look at that a lot. And very, very happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then can you talk a little bit more about the flexibility that you have, the minimum level of activity you all have to progress there with the JV in terms of holding acreage or the minimum commitments that you have when it c
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then can you talk a little bit more about the flexibility that you have, the minimum level of activity you all have to progress there with the JV in terms of holding acreage or the minimum commitments that you have when it comes to allocating capital, because it sounds as if that was an attractive element to this deal. So if you could just talk about that a little bit more?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very attractive element because full-time we look at it, we've had another level of price collapse. And looking in the USD 130 million, USD 140 million capital through the first 3 years on our low basis and going into the 200s in 2020 to get this car
componenttext: Yes, very attractive element because full-time we look at it, we've had another level of price collapse. And looking in the USD 130 million, USD 140 million capital through the first 3 years on our low basis and going into the 200s in 2020 to get this carried behind us and kind of a smooth 200 million a year doesn't lead to incredible growth for us, we're talking about a 30,000-barrel a day type number in 2023 or so. Of course, that can be greatly enhanced. We feel we have conservative EURs in this analysis. And start drilling some wells improving, trying not to build up the big overspend here. And the key thing for us is if you look at our cash position, they have $240 million, $250 million, whatever it is, take this money in for midstream, have a big Western Canada business, Syncrude, East Coast Canada and our Montney business and our new midstream business and we are able to run through this business here, and it's EBITDA accretive to us, it's the income slight income accretion to us with very, very low prices and we're able to run through that and keep all of our cash balances intact. And it's some 300 something million dollars the whole time. And that's very attractive for us because we have to get on the balance sheet here, have to get back to free cash flow, have to get this debt worked down over time and that's about the only project we had that had a returns I wanted and had the ability to do that for us right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then final one for me. On the capital budget for 2016, you made a comment that the budget would be under review for further reduction. So just trying to understand that comment. Is that if the current strip persists? Is that if we see ano
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then final one for me. On the capital budget for 2016, you made a comment that the budget would be under review for further reduction. So just trying to understand that comment. Is that if the current strip persists? Is that if we see another leg down in price? Help us understand that comment? And then it seems that you hit the CapEx budget pretty hard, obviously. Where do you have incremental flexibility to flex lower if you choose to do that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a lot of flexibility in the Eagle Ford and we can go down $100 million there if we want to. That's the beauty of these plays as you can slow it down more difficult than offshore and that would be worth that would come from. And while prices on a r
componenttext: We have a lot of flexibility in the Eagle Ford and we can go down $100 million there if we want to. That's the beauty of these plays as you can slow it down more difficult than offshore and that would be worth that would come from. And while prices on a rampage the last 4 days, still not too exciting to me, I can tell you that. So we have got to kick this balance sheet intact. We cannot be lulled into believing this is back here headed into the 40s and just not headed that way. I'm not scared to cut the CapEx and I will. Never going to get on balance sheet instead of production because I've grown production as much as anybody through the years. And so we're going to stay in the business for a long time. We're going to keep our balance sheet in the right ZIP Code here.

componenttextpreview: Maybe a following up on capital allocation level, can you talk a little bit about relative competition to the capital between the Eagle Ford and the Athabasca JV going forward? I mean, what are the relative rates of return? What are the relative rate of r
componenttext: Maybe a following up on capital allocation level, can you talk a little bit about relative competition to the capital between the Eagle Ford and the Athabasca JV going forward? I mean, what are the relative rates of return? What are the relative rate of return right now between the 2 plays? And if we were to see incremental upward pressure on the commodity, where would we see capital go first?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that our Eagle Ford, because of its oily nature and not the U.S. income, it will always be slightly ahead of wells up there. But then you have this balance sheet issue of U.S. cost and repatriation and tax efficiency and working in the area. But i
componenttext: I think that our Eagle Ford, because of its oily nature and not the U.S. income, it will always be slightly ahead of wells up there. But then you have this balance sheet issue of U.S. cost and repatriation and tax efficiency and working in the area. But if we remove it around pretty good, they compete very well. The condensate well, oil window well up in Canada competes very well with Lower Eagle Ford Shale and Karnes. That's what's so interesting around, about this deal and about the shale plays is that 4 years ago, the Catarina area, where we have an enormous acreage position in Western Eager ford shale was one our lowest rate of return areas in the company in -- in the Eagle Ford, I mean. So over this time, the EURs have doubled, the drilling costs and went from the bottom the best. So it's the best individual well, economics around 25% on that January 19 strip date where we normalize all our costs. And this project up there is competing there. But the point is, these things change. Some areas become better than others. Prices not so good last time, it's better this time. The cost in this northern light oil area are very, very good, getting much better and we put those cost and year. This project is going to compete with the Eagle Ford very well for us. And it will be a matter of what we do about repatriation and how we want to work in our cash balance. But on the overall allocation capital, it will work well and it would be some hard decisions there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's primarily drilling and completions. We're going to drill 45 wells. And we're going to complete between 55 and 60 wells. So we have some well inventory that we'll complete with that capital as well. So it's a fairly significant amount. There's a littl
componenttext: It's primarily drilling and completions. We're going to drill 45 wells. And we're going to complete between 55 and 60 wells. So we have some well inventory that we'll complete with that capital as well. So it's a fairly significant amount. There's a little bit electrification work that will help lower our operating cost, probably about $30 million, $40 million of that. But as Roger mentioned, that capital could be considered to be cut as well, and we could consider going down to less than 1 rig in the Eagle Ford and putting back $100 million to the Corporation.

componenttext: That's correct, Paul. We don't have of explaining this. The $825 million is Murphy as is. We go into this transaction we of course have to pay the downpayment. And I'm speaking to you now and it's another confusing thing, Paul, we have to keep in mind as I'm speaking now in USD. So this CapEx will go up by $223 million, but most of it is a purchase of down payment. And then we will have very limited capital at $30 million to $40 million this year is the current plan. We have to get with our partner, get with what's going on with their production reserves, et cetera, and allocate capital there efficiently. But we have planned the. Keep in mind that this deal is structured between November 30 and January 20, and it was an exciting time for oil prices, Paul, and so we have very limited capital there planned in '16, kind of getting our feet on the ground, getting in there with a partner that has been working and has been working well and able to pick up and move forward and get it on into '17. But very little this year, Paul, but that is correct. The guidance here for production and the capital in these remarks today do not include the transaction we did with our joint venture partner, Athabasca.

componenttext: No, I don't see that. There's loads of wells here. There's incredible amount of information being released by nearby shale players like in Canada, very successful here. And it is a very good job in that regard. And I see us getting into pads and drilling 4 well pads much earlier than we did in the Eagle Ford. And I think that, that's critical to understand that Murphy had 0 shale presence in our company 4 years ago, 900 wells today and know what we're doing and we're going to get in there and get going and hopefully in pad drilling hit pretty quick, Paul.

componenttext:
Yes, that's true, Paul. Mike McFadyen is going to look at the production for you to know speak about the reserves. 
 We have very good reserves in this company and we've done a good job on it for a long time and we had a superb locations in the Eagle Ford. We've had some very small negative revisions in our performance as a company. We've got some type curve enhancements in Eagle Ford Shale. We had some operating expense help into the long cycle. Actually, Paul, with our company in Malaysia you're able to get some added new barrels with price and as our entitlement goes up, so it's an advantage then of not just being in one spot. It's not significant, but it helps us there. And of course, we sold down 20 million barrels in Malaysia and produced 76 million. So to replace budget, and we're a company that's very proud of our EURs and our costs and I'm very happy about the lack of a write-down in our calculations, Paul. And now Mike is going to talk to you about the reduction in Eagle Ford which has a lot less CapEx this year.

componenttext: Sure. On the a production side, so we finished the quarter 4 of 2015 at about 57,000 barrels oil equivalent. Forecast forward for the first quarter is about 54,000. Second quarter is 48,000. Third quarter is 47,000. And then the fourth is about 44,000. For 2016 average of 48,400.

componenttext: In the light oil or window which represents the lion's share of the acreage, we [indiscernible] 67,000 acres of that is can be drilled without intermediate casing. And Athabasca just drilled 2 pacesetter wells there in 2015, one at 13 days and one at 16 days. So it's that kind of drilling performance in the CAD 3 million to CAD 3.5 million is what they spent, including lease construction costs is what's going to get us there. It's similar to the northern part of our Eagle Ford where we've started in the basin and with drill times at 25, 25 plus days and are now down to 7 days in the Catarina area. It's also similar to our Montney operated area where we are continuing to improve drill times and costs there where we've driven -- we're down now in the 6 million, sub 6 million drilling complete cost in our Tupper West area where we are targeting anywhere from 12 to 14 days of well this year.

componenttext: Okay. And then on the recoverable resource of 200 to 350, I'm just looking at the bubble map you got on Slide 12. headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't count any of above the black oil line on Page 12 right now. And we used only the light oil and the condensate and then the liquids Montney that shows up in some other slides. And this acreage is quite derisked and the gas condensate area is succ
componenttext: We didn't count any of above the black oil line on Page 12 right now. And we used only the light oil and the condensate and then the liquids Montney that shows up in some other slides. And this acreage is quite derisked and the gas condensate area is successful well is all around it and we'll use no down spacing there and use no down spacing anywhere to arrive that number, Ed. And we then took an over in the Western part of this thing called light oil on Page 12, some very successful wells. And we took a higher EUR curve there. You can see some of the EUR results in the back here as to the concentration of proppant, Ed. And moving to the east, we took a more conservative one. These wells have a rate of return in the 14%, 15% range, $30 oil type strip. I think in the black oil area, it's a matter of there would be some experimentation there to figure out how to make that work. That's the issue now with capital allocation. But the advantage here is that a lot of long life leases like leasing in the Gulf of Mexico if you will, it's our a Crowley's and no continuous drilling causes, a lot of flexibility, a lot of information to come to us, there's constantly was being released for information in this region. And going to be monitoring that and real excited about just a portion of it working is incredibly valuable to us, Ed.

componenttext: No, not at all. I mean, today, they have 30,000 of oil batteries and ability on oil over 100 million of gas. There's a lot of MLP type activity and people reactivating gas plants. There's 2 exits for gas coming out of here, which are very helpful. And we now have a part of that infrastructure as lower working interest with our partner there and glad to have it. It's valuable as well. It's up and going. They're adding to it. Use that adding to it. Know how to add to it. Please do not have to start over in infrastructure business at $34 oil.

I seem to remember that you were saying that you could go down as low as $800 million, but it would be very painful to go any lower than that. And this being kind of $100 million number turnaround for less activity in the Eagle Ford, are those numbers about right? Can I just clarify, I wasn't sure exactly what you're saying or implying, but are you saying that the dividend would or would not be part of a potential change in spending? I couldn't understand whether you're kind of saying...

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to take -- I would first in that matter what I said if these prices persists and I'm not greatly enthused by the run-up today, I still believe we're going to be in the low 30s world, I'm very happy a little for us. As we have that persist, we
componenttext: We're going to take -- I would first in that matter what I said if these prices persists and I'm not greatly enthused by the run-up today, I still believe we're going to be in the low 30s world, I'm very happy a little for us. As we have that persist, we will have to take a closer look at our dividend then we have before. And it will be done as we go through the year. And on your product questions, I mean, yes, I said the $800 million will be very painful and it is because our production levels are down. But we got to get control of our free cash flow goal, and then we'll get this rig issue behind us this year, which would require us a lot more capital had we kept it. We will work toward not running up our debt at all and look to lowering debt best we can. So that's since I so you, we probably lost $10 a barrel of crude, Paul. So it is a lot more. So if I said it was painful, it is. So  and we have to realize it, get on it, focus on cost. We've done a great job on cost, and we are seeing very competitive prices from service companies as to fracking services in North America. And these continue to compete well with each other and help us pass through this collapse. And we're going to continue to stay on it, and that's what we're going to do.

componenttext: Just 2 kind of housekeeping items. On the Canadian, dual Canadian deals, is there a tax efficiency to keeping your proceeds from the midstream deal in Canada rather than repatriating?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, if you -- if we were to consider repatriating and declaring some type of dividend bubble, we'd have to pay a toll for doing that because there's withholding tax of 5%. And there is quite frankly, always has been a differential in
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, if you -- if we were to consider repatriating and declaring some type of dividend bubble, we'd have to pay a toll for doing that because there's withholding tax of 5%. And there is quite frankly, always has been a differential in the tax rate in Canada being 25, 26, 27 range as opposed to a 35% tax rate in the U.S. So we've always been declared indefinitely and reinvested in Canada. You'd keep it that way up until you couldn't do it anymore because you don't really want to pay that toll if you don't have to. But there is cash up there, so it's an evaluation of how you have to look at it on an overall basis what's best for the Corporation in total. So yes, keeping it up there saves cash taxes is the short answer.

componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Gene Coleman, Executive Vice President, Offshore
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Gene Coleman, Executive Vice President, Offshore; and Mike McFadyen, Executive Vice President, Onshore. Please refer to the informational slides that we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with your webcast today. 
Today's prepared comments will be a little bit longer than usual, so that we can give you more color on our recently announced joint venture. John will begin by providing a review of the fourth quarter financial results and key year-end balance sheet position. Roger will then follow with an operational update as well as more details regarding the Montney Midstream monetization and Duvernay-Montney joint venture opportunity we just announced. We will end the call with a question-and-answer period. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on the Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy makes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Consolidated results in the fourth quarter of 2015 were a loss of $587 million, that's $3.41 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $375 million or $2.11 per diluted share a year ago. Excludin
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Consolidated results in the fourth quarter of 2015 were a loss of $587 million, that's $3.41 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $375 million or $2.11 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations, continuing operations had a loss of $583 million in the fourth quarter of '15, $3.39 per diluted share, and that compares to the fourth quarter '14 of $442 million profit, $2.48 per diluted share a year ago. 
The fourth quarter results for 2015 from continuing operations included noncash property impairments of $192.2 million, which after taxes amounted to $123.5 million charge. These impairments were attributable to a decline in future periods oil prices and primarily were related to an oil and gas property in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico. The just completed quarter also included an after-tax expense of $183.3 million to reflect the cost to exit 2 deepwater drilling rig contracts in the Gulf of Mexico. We chose to stack these rigs as low oil prices led to significant reductions in our capital expenditure program in the Gulf of Mexico, and the company was no longer able to obtain partner support for U.S. deepwater drilling as these partners are experiencing significant capital constraints. 
Murphy also recorded a U.S. income tax charge of $188.5 million in the fourth quarter due to U.S. taxable income generated foreign dividend declared in December. The company had previously recorded U.S. income tax benefits earlier in 2015 associated with an anticipated U.S. operating loss carryforward prior to our decision to make this foreign distribution to the parent. The foreign distribution was made through a combination of $800 million in cash and the remainder in the form of a 10-year note. This distribution effectively was cash tax neutral in 2015 due to operating losses and availability of foreign tax credits. This U.S. tax charge was recorded in the company's corporate reporting area, which led to a higher corporate net cost overall in the 2015 quarter compared to the prior year. 
Let me speak about adjusted earnings. These adjusted earnings adjust our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of earnings between periods. And this adjusted earnings was a loss of $130.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2015, down from a profit of $69 million a year ago. This decline in adjusted earnings was primarily attributable to lower oil and natural gas sales prices in the current period. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
The company's average realized price for its crude oil production fell more than $28 per barrel in the fourth quarter compared to the prior year which amounted to a 40% drop between periods. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the fourth quarter compared to the prior year quarter. 
Realized oil index natural gas process offshore Sarawak fell 31% to an average of $3.81 per Mcf, following the decline in global crude oil prices. Sales prices continue to be soft in January and, therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as quarter 1 2016 prices remain significantly below prices a year ago. As a reminder, however, the company has oil price hedges for 20,000 barrels per day at a WTI price of $52.01 for the remainder of 2016.
At December 31, 2015, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to slightly more than $3 billion, which represented 36.4% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to 32.8%. As of year end, we had $600 million borrowed under our $2 billion revolver. Plus we had a total of cash and invested cash for about $450 million worldwide. Murphy sold debt covenant is a total debt to total capital ratio of 60%, which obviously were well below. I believe we have adequate liquidity to weather the lower for longer oil price environment currently being experienced. 
That concludes my comments, and I'll pass it now to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Our company remains focused on balance sheet metrics as the entire industry experiences further commodity price drops. But this focus comes in extensive drop in capita
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Our company remains focused on balance sheet metrics as the entire industry experiences further commodity price drops. But this focus comes in extensive drop in capital spending; however, Murphy intends to be in the business for the long haul and is evidenced with news of our 2 purchase and sales agreements we released yesterday when closed will allow Murphy to sell a natural gas midstream business and use a portion of the proceeds to purchase a long-term asset that deliver value to shareholders, especially in a price recovery. 
Looking back at operations over the course of the year, the following highlights stand out. We spent $2.2 billion in capital, which is 42% down from the prior year, while still growing production with the prior year when factoring in the 30% sell-down in Malaysia. 
On the coal side, we made significant improvements in reducing both operating and G&A expenses. We lowered our operating costs, excluding Syncrude, by $1.82 per BOE to $9.21 per BOE or 17% over the course of 2015 and lowered our G&A expenses by over $57 million or 16% compared to 2014 levels. 
In our onshore business, the Eagle Ford Shale continues to outperform expectations, where we averaged just over 57,000 barrel equivalents per day for the year, delivering a front-loaded schedule of 136 new wells, of which 27 were in the fourth quarter. We drilled our first Austin Chalk well in  Karnes County, achieving a very successful IP 30 flow rate of 1,500 barrels equivalent per day. We're planning on drilling our second Austin Chalk well in the first quarter of 2016. 
In Canada, we recently completed -- our recently completed wells in the Montney continue to produce above plan where we averaged 194 million cubic feet per day for the year. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, the Dalmatian South 2 well which was drilled in the third quarter achieved first production ahead of plan late in 2015. The well is currently flowing back to Petronius facility. Development work continues at the non-operated Kodiak project where the first 2 wells will flow in the coming days. 
In Malaysia, fourth quarter Sarawak natural gas production is over 134 million per day net and oil production was over 14,000 barrels a day. Full year production for Malaysia was over 65,200-barrel equivalents per day. 
We are seeing continued drilling success at our South Acis field in Sarawak, where we announced the sanctioned volumes doubling. In addition, we drilled the Keratau well offshore Brunei, finding commercial natural gas that were in line with pre-drill estimates adding to our resources in the Kelidang field. 
On the fourth quarter, production was just over 200,700 barrel equivalents per day and our full year for the year, we produced close to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day.
We are pleased with the ongoing efforts we're making on cost reductions. Our LOE for quarter 4 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $8.25 per BOE, showing a reduction of 19% from the fourth quarter of '14. This is in line with the 17% reduction for full year 2014 on LOE. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, our fourth quarter operating expenses are just under $8.50 per BOE, and we expect this to be a reasonable run rate going forward. 
In 2015, we produced over 207 barrel oil equivalent per day, our strong production variance over the course of the year is attributable to Sarawak oil and natural gas fields is performing better. The Eagle Ford Shale, new well volumes exceeding plan due to EUR increases and completion performance and how our natural gas production from the Montney. 
More importantly, we spent $2.19 billion as compared to our original CapEx plan of $2.3 billion. Even with the significant reduction in capital for 2015, we grew annual production by 3%. 
In 2015, based on preliminary data, we expect to add reserves at a replacement rate of 123% for the finding and development costs of $18.70 per BOE. Year end 2015 reserve volumes represented Reserve Life Index of 10.2 years, an increase from 9.2 years from a year ago. This is consistent with our 5-year average reserve replacement rate greater than 180% and is our 10th consecutive year over 100%. During the same time frame, we have more than doubled our production, including a sell-down of our Malaysia assets. 
The capital program for 2016 is currently $825 million, which is approximately 62% lower than $2.19 billion we invested in 2015. We expect production for full year to be 180,000 to 185,000 barrel equivalents per day, which is lower than 2015 due to significant CapEx cuts. As common in our industry, the capital program still remains under review for further reductions, should the commodity prices persist.
Moving on to the subsequent year-end events, as you have read in our news release from last night, we signed 2 purchase and sale agreements announcing the monetization of our midstream Montney and the joint venture in the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids-rich Montney area. We signed a definitive agreement with Enbridge to divest our natural gas processing sales pipeline assets that support our Montney natural gas field in Tupper and Tupper West. The cash consideration is expected to be CAD 538 million and expected to be closed early in the second quarter. 
In a separate but related transaction, we signed a definitive agreement for a joint venture with Athabasca Oil Corp. to acquire 70% operated working interest in Athabasca's acreage infrastructure and facilities in the Kaybob Duvernay lands and a 30% non-operated working interest in the liquids-rich Montney. The total consideration is CAD 475 million, of which CAD 250 million is in cash at closing and the remaining CAD 225 million is a carry for a period up to 5 years. 
In the Kaybob Duvernay, there were 230,000 gross acres, 200,000 currently perspective that are currently producing 6,900-barrel equivalent gross per day of production, of which 58% is liquids. This area also includes 247,000 gross acres with overlying rights in the conventional Montney. 
In the liquids-rich Montney area, there are 60,000 gross acres, 21,000 currently viewed as perspective that are currently producing 900-barrel equivalent a day gross at 44% liquids. 
We're very excited to enter to the Kaybob Duvernay and liquid-rich Montney as it complements our current onshore North American resources, fits well with our in-house expertise and will be our third significant North American unconventional position. The CAD 225 million carry in long lease term associated with the Kaybob Duvernay is flexible over 5 years, which is key in this period of low commodity prices where we're able to control the pace of spend. We're allocating partial proceeds from our Montney midstream monetization into this project. And I see as efficient use of capital that has a positive impact to cash on hand for our balance sheet this year as well as use of Canadian funds in Canada in a tax efficient manner and enter a project that's expected to be self funding within Canada over the life of the period. 
The primary marketable product here as realized will be produced condensate, which is used as diluent for oil sands bitumen production and transport. The Western Canadian oil sands project have long demonstrated a record of production resiliency that will continue to generate demand well in the excess of regional supply, resulting in relative price stability for foreseeable future. Our joint venture has oil battery capacity of 30,000 barrels per day of oil and gas pipeline with over 100 million scf per day of capacity.
The Kaybob Duvernay is an emerging play and has 3 same segments seen in the Eagle Ford Shale, natural gas, gas condensate and light oil. The gas condensate area has included several prolific wells of late in the light oil area that we now have a significant position in is in the early stages of development. We are seeing all signs of a shale play success with increasing EURs, improving completion techniques, as well as lowering of drilling and completion costs. We feel that with 3 to 4 wells per section, we will have over 500 gross locations in the play and this number can greatly increase should downspacing opportunities exist here as seen in other successful North American plays. 
We are seeing many successful wells across the play now approaching 30 test intervals of over 2,000-barrel equivalent per day with yields ranging from 200 to 950 barrel per million and a clear indicator of the oil-rich nature of this basin. 
The Duvernay areas have been heavily drilled for other types of plays through the years in the basin which leads to thousands of penetrations and knowledge of the shale characteristics. Additionally, we have a black hole area in the play, again matching success seen in the Eagle Ford Shale area.
Our new joint venture partner, Athabasca, has been successful in the play with the results the condensate region and most importantly, in the light oil area of the play. Athabasca's recently released information about a key well in the gas condensate light oil area that's flowed 1,300-barrel equivalents per day with 62% liquids. This appears to be a very good well by any measure. 
As in any shale play, the optimization of the fracture treatments are key to the learning curve. Of late, higher proppant concentrations have been used in the region. This slide highlights the increase in EUR seen with data up to 2 years in duration, illustrating recent higher treatments lead to consistent EUR levels. Some wells announcing above the 1,000 -- 1 million, rather, barrel type curve. This well shown here in the condensate window are now partnered in the 33,000 acres with a 70% working interest. We're seeing the same -- we see the same well performance with higher stimulation treatments in the Duvernay light oil area as well as where we are working a 70% working interest with our partner in 67,000 acres. We believe there's significant upside in the black hole area where our partnership has 110,000 gross acres. Current data showing high proppant content at the 607 -- 670,000-barrel equivalent EUR level. 
Our joint venture also includes our liquids-rich Montney, which is among the top active plays in Canada. We participate here in the non-op 30% working interest. The region has a minimum of 30% of the flow stream containing liquids, similar to the condensate in light oil areas. The results in the liquid-rich area are also showing increasing EURs due to completion enhancements and the lowering of cost with 750,000-barrel equivalent EURs seen in the data set. This area has significant running room in the range of 100 to 200 locations with downspacing. We see a tightly leased up area around our new acreage with many non-North American shale players. Rates here are also prolific in the range of 800 barrel equivalents with high-liquid yields.
Like all major shale plays in North America, the key economic drivers is lowering the drilling and completion cost while simultaneously improving the completion techniques for each area. We are seeing the early stages of a major improvement in cost for the region and our expertise in 2 other plays where we are top quartile drilling and completion company will enhance our ability to quickly move up the learning curve here. Our partner Athabasca is active in the cost reduction business, and we will be able to quickly adapt to the area where they have recently seen incredible improvements as we see great upside in lowering cost from the current CAD 9.4 million per well down to CAD 6.5 million per well. Athabasca has recently seen wells being drilled for as low as CAD 3.25 million, which is an outstanding performance. 
As I close our call today, here are a few takeaways: We're focusing on our balance sheet at Murphy. The purchase and sale agreements to monetize our natural gas midstream and use a portion of proceeds to enter in the onshore conventional shale play that allows for balance sheet neutrality with a 5-year carry and further liquidity this year for our cash positions. We see this venture as an investment for the long term with total spend flexibility over a 5-year period as we anticipate a price recovery. Cost reductions will continue to be our focus. Our Eagle Ford Shale continues to perform very well for us. The budget reductions will lead to a very limited exploration spend this year. We continue to illustrate the execution advantages we have in the offshore. We had an excellent year operationally in our company with the reserve additions, significant capital reductions and lowering costs leading the way. 
I would now like to open the phone lines up for your questions, and thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about the acquisition. I mean, I know the sell-down in Malaysia, a little over a year ago, I think that's right, yes, or at least the announcement. Then the talk of a transformative acquisition. Is this one of those transformative acquisitions
componenttext: Can we talk about the acquisition. I mean, I know the sell-down in Malaysia, a little over a year ago, I think that's right, yes, or at least the announcement. Then the talk of a transformative acquisition. Is this one of those transformative acquisitions? Or should we still consider something in the lower 48 is still more likely and still desirable opportunity?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think of it as transformative for us. I mean, it's got all of the things we're looking for today. It's very rare to get into M&A in North America and have flexibility on the first year of capital spend and have no continuous drilling clauses, be abl
componenttext: No. I think of it as transformative for us. I mean, it's got all of the things we're looking for today. It's very rare to get into M&A in North America and have flexibility on the first year of capital spend and have no continuous drilling clauses, be able to drag out the carryover a very long period of time and a very low oil price. I've said for a long time that I would like a 10% cost of capital-type return at a strip price. And with the drilling costs we're seeing here, we're able to do that here, even on strip that we used on January 19, which was probably $4 behind where we are today. So I see this as transformative as far as Roger, honestly, because it has a 200 million, 300 million barrel ability for us. It's pretty low-cost entry. It's different from buying a -- from a company that's flipping acres because we have a partner that's working there and has drilled there and has infrastructure there, and we're able to work with them and take over as the operator. They're able to operate a piece where they've been very successful. It's in Canada. We'll have Canadian proceeds. There's a low 4x right now for this transaction. Where the USD equivalent of that would not get you what used to get you here in the United States. And all of those factors led to this decision.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then as you think about lower 48, are there still opportunities? Are we still too far apart on a bid-ask spread? Just curious, any update you would have on what you're seeing there.
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then as you think about lower 48, are there still opportunities? Are we still too far apart on a bid-ask spread? Just curious, any update you would have on what you're seeing there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we look at many opportunities. I do the same thing, whether its offshore or in the Permian or in the Eagle Ford or wherever. We look at the rate of return we get at strip prices and with cost and how will it flex our balance sheet and how we h
componenttext: No, I mean, we look at many opportunities. I do the same thing, whether its offshore or in the Permian or in the Eagle Ford or wherever. We look at the rate of return we get at strip prices and with cost and how will it flex our balance sheet and how we have to drill so much capital and hurt our balance sheet further, and that's come up as a new factor in the M&A analysis that we had from a year ago. And that's just as important now. The balance sheet of how one of these projects would impact you is anything for me now. So we saw the return to a very similar to a project where we working in the lower 48, but we ended up with a project in the lower 48, totally downspaced, every zone working, they have the same rate of return as one in Canada where we have no downspacing at all, built-in partner, 5-year lease program, 5-year carry period, and just offered every advantage to me in $30 oil that I don't have down here right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And last question I'll ask on the acquisition front. You've always talked about you wanted to use cash or debt. Obviously, now debt is a little more questionable as an opportunity for a whole host of reasons. Would you, at all, consider issui
componenttext: Okay, great. And last question I'll ask on the acquisition front. You've always talked about you wanted to use cash or debt. Obviously, now debt is a little more questionable as an opportunity for a whole host of reasons. Would you, at all, consider issuing equity? I know that's not something the company's historically done, but as you think about that cost of capital, does that factor in or not so much?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Roger, we've been working pretty hard on these 2 transactions and I don't have another one in my pocket today, I'm pretty tired. And it's taken us a lot of work to do these 2, and we didn't have to use debt and we didn't have to use equity. And I'm
componenttext: Well, Roger, we've been working pretty hard on these 2 transactions and I don't have another one in my pocket today, I'm pretty tired. And it's taken us a lot of work to do these 2, and we didn't have to use debt and we didn't have to use equity. And I'm very pleased, and not looking for a deal today to issue equity at this price in my company.
