headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a very nice transaction there. We're very pleased with it. We're not disclosing the tariff arrangement there. You would have to look at cost of capital, those top players, residual value and you can work through that. I think the way to think abou
componenttext: We have a very nice transaction there. We're very pleased with it. We're not disclosing the tariff arrangement there. You would have to look at cost of capital, those top players, residual value and you can work through that. I think the way to think about this business is if you have $1.90 to $2 echo [ph] run through that business every year, we're able to drill our wells and have cash flow neutrality and not hurt our balance sheet in any way, a lot of optionality around how many wells we drill, we're doing very, very well there in the EUR per well basis. We're able to get the money from these guys at a favorable rate to us as to how this works, and we're able to use these proceeds of selling steel and getting into 200 million to 300 million barrel reserves type P2 number. And I like the sound of it, I like the transaction, and we're not concerned about the level of drilling that we'll need to do or allocate capital here because of the incredible reduction in our operating expenses, our improved fracturing techniques, our lower drilling cost and all the positives attributed to shale we have in the Montney 2. And we have very good partner there, one of the dominating players in North America in the space and very, very happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then maybe just kind of circling back to Duvernay, realize the ink still haven't been dried yet on this deal, but how are you guys kind of just high-level thinking about development over the next couple of years? Is kind of the light oil
componenttext: Okay, great. And then maybe just kind of circling back to Duvernay, realize the ink still haven't been dried yet on this deal, but how are you guys kind of just high-level thinking about development over the next couple of years? Is kind of the light oil window going to be the near-term area of focus? Or how should we be thinking about in terms of derisking that new position there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we have -- just got the ink dried on the thing, these deals are complex and today in the price collapse and doing the deal like this with our partner, very happy about all the areas. And I would say that we concentrate in a mixture of both t
componenttext: Well, I mean, we have -- just got the ink dried on the thing, these deals are complex and today in the price collapse and doing the deal like this with our partner, very happy about all the areas. And I would say that we concentrate in a mixture of both the condensate, which is very, very successful by many successful shale players. Pretty big light oil window that were creeping north toward, if you look to the slides today. And we'll have a limited capital in 2016 because of severe drop in price. Most of that capital will be allocated to our completing wells that are owned by the partner today when we close the transaction. And got about a 6- or 9-month period to plan out where we want to execute on that. But very pleased with all the areas and be happy to drill wells in any of it, to be honest with you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And one last one for me, Roger. Just what's your kind of current comfort level with the dividend?
componenttext: That's helpful. And one last one for me, Roger. Just what's your kind of current comfort level with the dividend?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a dividend policy here for a very long time. And the oil prices just collapsed for a short time. But like any company today, if these price levels persist, then the dividend discussion will be on the table here in our company. And that we
componenttext: Well, we've had a dividend policy here for a very long time. And the oil prices just collapsed for a short time. But like any company today, if these price levels persist, then the dividend discussion will be on the table here in our company. And that we will have that and review that as necessary. And I would say we'll be on the table in these prices more than before. And that's really all I have to say on that matter.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Guy Baber from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Guy Baber from Simmons & Company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the JV transaction, I wanted to follow up on a comment that you made earlier, Roger, about the return. So can you just help frame for us and maybe discuss the economics that are underlying the deal? On the last call, you talked about running 4 price de
componenttext: On the JV transaction, I wanted to follow up on a comment that you made earlier, Roger, about the return. So can you just help frame for us and maybe discuss the economics that are underlying the deal? On the last call, you talked about running 4 price decks, I think a screen deal and wanting to get a return at the strip. And we aren't as familiar with these assets. So any return framework or how you think these assets compete for capital in the current environment or rising oil price environment, I think, would help us better understand this.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in a very big collapse in price here recently, of course, and when we say strip, where we're using a January 19 strip. And it was around $32.76 2016, $37 for '17 and up to $44 in 2020 of course today, these numbers are about $4 better than tha
componenttext: Well, we're in a very big collapse in price here recently, of course, and when we say strip, where we're using a January 19 strip. And it was around $32.76 2016, $37 for '17 and up to $44 in 2020 of course today, these numbers are about $4 better than that. And when we run through this entire thing, as we've always said and always desired and requirement here, is we'd be above 10%. When we look at current drilling and completion costs, which are very critical, and that's without any downspacing at all. And then when we have another price deck here, we call our low planning price from January, it's a very low price for '16, around $29, $41 in '17 and going up to $60 in 2020. And this project looks very good, as good as any M&A we've seen and above '15 range. And when you get a big cost, a big price recovery deck here, we'll get into the 20% range. So we're very happy about it. It stacks up well with all the opportunities we reviewed across the spectrum and we look that a lot. And very, very happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then can you talk a little bit more about the flexibility that you have, the minimum level of activity you all have to progress there with the JV in terms of holding acreage or the minimum commitments that you have when it c
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then can you talk a little bit more about the flexibility that you have, the minimum level of activity you all have to progress there with the JV in terms of holding acreage or the minimum commitments that you have when it comes to allocating capital, because it sounds as if that was an attractive element to this deal. So if you could just talk about that a little bit more?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very attractive element, because as the whole time we looked at it, we've had another level of price collapse. And looking in the USD 130 million, USD 140 million capital through the first 3 years on our low basis and going into the 200s in 2020 to g
componenttext: Yes, very attractive element, because as the whole time we looked at it, we've had another level of price collapse. And looking in the USD 130 million, USD 140 million capital through the first 3 years on our low basis and going into the 200s in 2020 to get this carried behind us and kind of a smooth 200 million a year doesn't lead to incredible growth for us, we're talking about a 30,000-barrel a day type number in 2023 or so. Of course, that can be greatly enhanced. We feel we have conservative EURs in this analysis. And start drilling some wells and proving, and trying not to build up the big overspend here. And the key thing for us is if you look at our MOCAL [ph] cash position, they have $240 million, $250 million, whatever it is, take this money in for midstream, have a big Western Canada business, Syncrude, East Coast Canada and our Montney business and our new midstream business and we're able to run through this business here, and it's EBITDA accretive to us, it's income -- slight income accretion to us with very, very low prices, and we're able to run through that and keep all of our MOCAL [ph] cash balances intact. And it's some $300-something million the whole time. And that's very attractive for us because we have to get on the balance sheet here, have to get back to free cash flow, have to get this debt worked down over time and that's about the only project we had that had a returns I wanted and had the ability to do that for me right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then final one for me. On the capital budget for 2016, you made a comment that the budget would be under review for further reduction. So just trying to understand that comment. Is that if the current strip persists? Is that if we see ano
componenttext: Okay, great. And then final one for me. On the capital budget for 2016, you made a comment that the budget would be under review for further reduction. So just trying to understand that comment. Is that if the current strip persists? Is that if we see another leg down in price? Help us understand that comment? And then, it seems that you've hit the CapEx budget pretty hard, obviously. Where do you have incremental flexibility to flex lower if you choose to do that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a lot of flexibility in the Eagle Ford and we can go down $100 million there if we want to. And that's the beauty of these plays as you can slow it down more difficult than offshore, and that would be where that would come from. And while prices o
componenttext: We have a lot of flexibility in the Eagle Ford and we can go down $100 million there if we want to. And that's the beauty of these plays as you can slow it down more difficult than offshore, and that would be where that would come from. And while prices on a rampage the last 4 days, it's still not too exciting to me, I can tell you that. So we have got to kick this balance sheet intact. We cannot be lulled into believing this is back here headed into the 40s and just not headed that way. I'm not scared to cut the CapEx, and I will. And we're going to get on balance sheet instead of production because I've grown production as much as anybody through the years. And so we're going to stay in business for a long time. We're going to keep our balance sheet in the right ZIP Code here.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Ryan Todd, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Ryan Todd, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe following up on capital allocation level, can you talk a little bit about relative competition to the capital between the Eagle Ford and the Athabasca JV going forward? I mean, what are the relative rates of return? What is the relative rate of retu
componenttext: Maybe following up on capital allocation level, can you talk a little bit about relative competition to the capital between the Eagle Ford and the Athabasca JV going forward? I mean, what are the relative rates of return? What is the relative rate of return right now between the 2 plays? And if we were to see incremental upward pressure on the commodity, where would we see capital go first?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that our Eagle Ford, because of its oily nature and not the U.S. acre nature. It will always be slightly ahead of wells up there. But then you have this balance sheet issue of U.S. cost and repatriation and tax efficiency and working in the MOCAL
componenttext: I think that our Eagle Ford, because of its oily nature and not the U.S. acre nature. It will always be slightly ahead of wells up there. But then you have this balance sheet issue of U.S. cost and repatriation and tax efficiency and working in the MOCAL [ph] area. But if we remove it around pretty good, they compete very well. A condensate well and an oil window well up in Canada competes very well with lower Eagle Ford Shale and Karnes. That's what's so interesting, Ryan, about this deal and about the shale plays is that 4 years ago, the Catarina area, where we have an enormous acreage position in Western Eagle Ford Shale was one of our lowest rate of return areas in the company in -- in the Eagle Ford, I mean. So over this time, the EURs have doubled, the drilling costs have halved and it went from the bottom to the best. So it's a best individual well, economics around 25% on that January 19 strip date where we normalized all our costs. And this project up there is competing there. But the point is, these things change. Some areas become better than others. Price is not so good last time or better this time. The cost in this northern light oil area are very, very good, getting much better and we put those costs in here. This project is going to compete with the Eagle Ford very well for us. And then, it will be a matter of our capital -- what we do about repatriation and how we want to work in our MOCAL [ph] cash balance. But on the overall allocation capital, it will work well and it would be some hard decisions there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe one -- maybe another one on CapEx. In the Eagle Ford, the level of spending in the Eagle Ford seems fairly high for running 1.25 rigs. I mean, is there a timing issue related there? How much of that is infrastructure related? Or is t
componenttext: Great. And then maybe one -- maybe another one on CapEx. In the Eagle Ford, the level of spending in the Eagle Ford seems fairly high for running 1.25 rigs. I mean, is there a timing issue related there? How much of that is infrastructure related? Or is there as we look forward over the next year or 2, is there some of that CapEx that we should expect to see roll off going forward?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Mike answer that for you.
componenttext: I'll let Mike answer that for you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: It's Mike McFadyen here. I guess, the -- could you repeat the question again please?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The question is, it looks like you're spending about $340 million in the Eagle Ford, running 1.25 rigs roughly for the year, which -- I mean, the absolute level of spend seems a little high. Is that -- can you -- how much of that additional capital in the
componenttext: The question is, it looks like you're spending about $340 million in the Eagle Ford, running 1.25 rigs roughly for the year, which -- I mean, the absolute level of spend seems a little high. Is that -- can you -- how much of that additional capital in the Eagle Ford is infrastructure related? Or and should we expect to see any of that roll off over the -- or is it a timing issue over the next period of months or years?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's primarily drilling and completions. We're going to drill 45 wells. And we're going to complete between 55 and 60 wells. So we have some well inventory that we'll complete with that capital as well. So it's a fairly significant amount. There's a littl
componenttext: It's primarily drilling and completions. We're going to drill 45 wells. And we're going to complete between 55 and 60 wells. So we have some well inventory that we'll complete with that capital as well. So it's a fairly significant amount. There's a little bit electrification work that will help lower our operating cost, probably about $30 million, $40 million of that. But as Roger mentioned, that capital could be considered to be cut as well, and we could consider going down to less than 1 rig in the Eagle Ford and putting back $100 million to the Corporation.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Paul Cheng, Barclays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like it's a very good transaction. I was just curious, the $825 million CapEx that you put out, I'm assuming that's not including the JV spending, right?
componenttext: It looks like it's a very good transaction. I was just curious, the $825 million CapEx that you put out, I'm assuming that's not including the JV spending, right?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct, Paul. We're going to have a year of explaining this. The $825 million is Murphy as is. We go into this transaction we, of course, have to pay the down payment. And I'm speaking to you now and it's another confusing thing, Paul, we have to
componenttext: That's correct, Paul. We're going to have a year of explaining this. The $825 million is Murphy as is. We go into this transaction we, of course, have to pay the down payment. And I'm speaking to you now and it's another confusing thing, Paul, we have to keep in mind as I'm speaking now in USD. So this CapEx will go up by $223 million, but most of it is the purchase down payment. And then, we will have a very limited capital at $30 million to $40 million this year is the current plan. We have to get with our partner, get with what's going on with their production reserves, et cetera, and allocate capital there efficiently, but we have plan. Keep in mind that this deal is structured between November 30 and January 20, and it was an exciting time for oil prices, Paul, and so we have very limited capital there planned in '16, kind of getting our feet on the ground, getting there with a partner that has been working and has been working well and able to pick up and move forward and get it on into '17. But very little this year, Paul, but that is correct. The guidance here for production and the capital in these remarks today do not include the transaction we did with our joint venture partner, Athabasca.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, on the first couple of years when you start spending money in this joint venture, are those some of the science project or that is going to be really already in the manufacturing side?
componenttext: Roger, on the first couple of years when you start spending money in this joint venture, are those some of the science project or that is going to be really already in the manufacturing side?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't see that. There's loads of wells here. There's incredible amount of information being released by nearby shale players like in Canada, very successful here. And Canada is a little different than Texas. It's incredible accurate data released pu
componenttext: No, I don't see that. There's loads of wells here. There's incredible amount of information being released by nearby shale players like in Canada, very successful here. And Canada is a little different than Texas. It's incredible accurate data released publicly. A lot of what all the proppants are, what are the link to the wells are, the orientation of the well. Canada is a very good job in that regard. And I see us getting into pads and drilling 4 well pads much earlier than we did in the Eagle Ford. And I think that it's critical to understand that Murphy had 0 shale presence in our company 4 years ago, 900 wells today and know what we're doing and we're going to get in there and get going and hopefully, in pad drilling hit pretty quick, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, we've been doing very well in production here. Eagle Ford has been a resilient. We have it declining in here this year, and we've gone through 2 or 3 budgets here, have a board meeting next week in that regard and really not getting off into '17. We
componenttext: Paul, we've been doing very well in production here. Eagle Ford has been a resilient. We have it declining in here this year, and we've gone through 2 or 3 budgets here, have a board meeting next week in that regard and really not getting off into '17. We had a pretty big collapse in price. We're trying to focus on our about balance sheet above all and not leading the way on the '17 guidance parade there, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Two final questions. One, can you give us some idea that how's the Eagle Ford production trend by quarter look like or that I mean we start out from what and end the year at roughly what run rate? And then finally, look like you guys didn't have any
componenttext: Okay. Two final questions. One, can you give us some idea that how's the Eagle Ford production trend by quarter look like or that I mean we start out from what and end the year at roughly what run rate? And then finally, look like you guys didn't have any research write-down or markdown on the full-time reserve unlike some of your peers. I just want to make sure that's the case?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's true, Paul. Mike McFadyen is going to look up the cap -- the production for you. I'll now speak about the reserves. We have very good reserves in this company and we've done a good job on it for a long time and we had a superb locations in the
componenttext: Yes, that's true, Paul. Mike McFadyen is going to look up the cap -- the production for you. I'll now speak about the reserves. We have very good reserves in this company and we've done a good job on it for a long time and we had a superb locations in the Eagle Ford. We've had some very small negative revisions in our performance as a company. We've had some type curve enhancements in Eagle Ford Shale. We had some operating expense help into the long cycle. Actually, Paul, with our company in Malaysia you're able to get some added new barrels with price and as our entitlement goes up, so it's an advantage then of not just being in one spot. It's not significant, but it helps us there. And of course, we sold down 20 million barrels in Malaysia and produced 76 million. So to replace with highest budget, and we're a company that's very proud of our EURs and our costs, and I'm very happy about the lack of a write-down in our calculations, Paul. And now Mike is going to talk to you about the production Eagle Ford which has -- have a lot less CapEx this year.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the a production side, so we finished the quarter 4 of 2015 at about 57,000 barrels oil equivalent. Forecast forward for the first quarter is about 54,000. Second quarter is 48,000. Third quarter is 47,000. And then the fourth is about 44,000. Fo
componenttext: Sure. On the a production side, so we finished the quarter 4 of 2015 at about 57,000 barrels oil equivalent. Forecast forward for the first quarter is about 54,000. Second quarter is 48,000. Third quarter is 47,000. And then the fourth is about 44,000. For 2016 average of 48,400.

componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to get a little extra detail, if I may. I mean, obviously, 9 million getting down to 6.4 million in terms of the well costs, 11,000 feet of total vertical depth. I mean maybe just can you walk us through what the biggest things are that w
componenttext: So I just wanted to get a little extra detail, if I may. I mean, obviously, 9 million getting down to 6.4 million in terms of the well costs, 11,000 feet of total vertical depth. I mean maybe just can you walk us through what the biggest things are that will get you to get that cost down. And then I'll follow up on the EURs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike McFadyen, our head of our onshore business is going to comment on that for me, Ed.
componenttext: Mike McFadyen, our head of our onshore business is going to comment on that for me, Ed.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll speak to that. So the light oil window which represents the lion's share of the acreage, we value 67,000 acres of that, is can be drilled without intermediate casing. And Athabasca just drilled 2 pacesetter wells there in 2015, one at 13 days an
componenttext: Yes, I'll speak to that. So the light oil window which represents the lion's share of the acreage, we value 67,000 acres of that, is can be drilled without intermediate casing. And Athabasca just drilled 2 pacesetter wells there in 2015, one at 13 days and one at 16 days. So it's that kind of drilling performance in the CAD 3 million to CAD 3.5 million is what they spent, including lease construction costs is what's going to get us there. It's similar to the northern part of our Eagle Ford where we've started in the basin and with drill times at 25, 25-plus days and are now down to 7 days in the Catarina area. It's also similar to our Montney operated area where we're continuing to improve drill times and costs there where we've driven -- we're down now in the 6 million, sub-6 million drilling complete cost in our Tupper, Tupper West area where we're targeting anywhere from 12 to 14 days of well this year.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the recoverable resource of 200 to 350, I'm just looking at the bubble map you got on Slide 12. I mean, as with some of these other combo plays, you have the better results in the gas condensate light oil. I don't know how many wells hav
componenttext: Okay. And then on the recoverable resource of 200 to 350, I'm just looking at the bubble map you got on Slide 12. I mean, as with some of these other combo plays, you have the better results in the gas condensate light oil. I don't know how many wells have actually been drilled in the black oil area. Maybe talk a little bit about the decent chunk of acreage of that, maybe talk a little bit about what was included in that resource number? And then what economics would be needed to get the black oil window to work?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't count any of above the black oil line on Page 12 right now. And that we used only the light oil and the condensate and then the liquids Montney that shows up in some other slides. And this acreage is quite derisked and the gas condensate area is
componenttext: We didn't count any of above the black oil line on Page 12 right now. And that we used only the light oil and the condensate and then the liquids Montney that shows up in some other slides. And this acreage is quite derisked and the gas condensate area is a successful wells all around it, and we'll use a no downspacing there and use no downspacing anywhere to arrive that number, Ed. And we then took a -- over in the Western part of this thing called light oil on Page 12, some very successful wells. And we took a higher EUR curve there, you can see some of the EUR results in the back here as to the concentration of proppant, Ed. And moving to the east, we took a more conservative one. These wells have a rate of return in the 14%, 15% range, $30 oil type strip. I think in the black oil area, it's a matter of there would be some experimentation there to figure out how to make that work. That's the issue now with capital allocation. But the advantage here is that a lot of long life leases like leasing in the Gulf of Mexico, if you will, it's a government ground lease and no continuous drilling clauses, a lot of flexibility, a lot of information to come to us, there's constantly wells being released for information in this region. And we're going to be monitoring that and real excited about just a portion of it working is incredibly valuable to us, Ed.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The final question from me is on the Alberta royalty review. I mean, obviously, a part of the reason why Canada does better than the U.S. is because you have more attractive fiscal terms. So maybe any color in terms of what you think is going to happen th
componenttext: The final question from me is on the Alberta royalty review. I mean, obviously, a part of the reason why Canada does better than the U.S. is because you have more attractive fiscal terms. So maybe any color in terms of what you think is going to happen there and how that might impact the economics?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have about 5% starting off royalty there, probably going into '15 over the life. There are some discussions about the royalty that have been, albeit, Alberta government and in general being helpful in some of these things as the price collapse is
componenttext: Well, we have about 5% starting off royalty there, probably going into '15 over the life. There are some discussions about the royalty that have been, albeit, Alberta government and in general being helpful in some of these things as the price collapse is going down, probably unlike our administration here. And we -- we're happy -- we think that could impact like less than a digit type of rate of return and not significant from the Alberta group that's coming up. And we're happy with the comment that you made and agree and happy about the royalty situation up here.

componenttext: No, not at all. I mean, today, they have 30,000 of old batteries and ability on oil over 100 million of gas. There's a lot of MLP-type activity and people reactivating gas plants. This has been a historic producing basin. Similarly, the Eagle Ford Shale in many ways, a lot of gas pipes headed to Edmonton, a lot of transport of condensate. There's 2 exits for gas coming out of here, which are very helpful. And we now have a part of that infrastructure as to our working interest with our partner there, and glad to have it. It's valuable as well. It's up and going. They're adding to it, used to adding to it, know how to add to it, pleased to not have to start over in the infrastructure business at a $34 oil.

componenttext: Well, we have a very good partner that operates a lot of midstream in North America, and lot midstream in Canada, this is a competitive process, very glad with the winner there, if you will. And if they lower operating expenses at the plant level, we were able to share in some of that with them. They should be able to do that as they do that for a living there. We operate just those 2 plants. I think we're very good operator, but I think they could help and we could share in that. We got our operating expenses probably down in the $0.30 range per Mcf, it's incredible job by Mike and his team. And so that's where it stands, and I'm really pleased to move that midstream into an upstream and not impact my balance sheet, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to take -- I would -- first, in that matter what I said is that if these prices persists and I'm not greatly enthused by the run-up today, I still believe we're going to be in the low 30s world, I'm very happy. It's up to a little bit I suppos
componenttext: We're going to take -- I would -- first, in that matter what I said is that if these prices persists and I'm not greatly enthused by the run-up today, I still believe we're going to be in the low 30s world, I'm very happy. It's up to a little bit I suppose. As we have that persist, we will have to take a closer look at our dividend than we have them before. And it will be done as we go through the year. And on your prior questions, I mean, yes, I said the $800 million will be very painful and it is because our production levels are down. But we got to get control of our free cash flow goal, and then we'll get this rig issue behind us this year, which require a lot more capital had we kept it. We will work toward not running up our debt at all and look to lowering debt best we can. So that's thing of change -- since I saw you, we probably lost $10 a barrel of crude, Paul. So it is a lot more. So if I said it was painful, it is. So -- and we have to realize it, get on it, focus on cost. We've done a great job on cost, and we are seeing very competitive prices from service companies as to fracking services in North America. And these continue to compete well with each other and help us as to this collapse. And we're going to continue to stay on it, and that's what we're going to do.

componenttext: Just 2 kind of housekeeping items. On the Canadian, dual Canadian deals, is there a tax efficiency to keeping your proceeds from the midstream deal in Canada rather than repatriating?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, if you -- if we were to consider repatriating and declaring some type of dividend bubble, we'd have to pay a toll for doing that because there's withholding tax of 5%. And there is quite frankly, a different -- always has been a d
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, if you -- if we were to consider repatriating and declaring some type of dividend bubble, we'd have to pay a toll for doing that because there's withholding tax of 5%. And there is quite frankly, a different -- always has been a differential in the tax rate in Canada being 25%, 26%, 27% range as opposed to a 35% tax rate in the U.S. So we've always been declared indefinitely reinvested in Canada. You'd keep it that way up until you couldn't do it anymore and because you don't really want to pay that toll if you don't have to. But there is cash up there, so it's an evaluation of how you have to look at it on an overall basis and what's best for the corporation in total. So yes, keeping it up there saves cash taxes is a short answer.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
