componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Gene Coleman, Executive Vice President, Offshore
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Gene Coleman, Executive Vice President, Offshore; and Mike McFadyen, Executive Vice President, Onshore. Please refer to the informational slides that we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with your webcast today. 
Today's prepared comments will be a little bit longer than usual, so that we can give you more color on our recently announced joint venture. John will begin by providing a review of the fourth quarter financial results and key year-end balance sheet position. Roger will then follow with an operational update as well as more details regarding the Montney Midstream monetization and Duvernay-Montney joint venture opportunity we just announced. We will end the call with a question-and-answer period. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on the Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy makes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Consolidated results in the fourth quarter of 2015 were a loss of $587 million, that's $3.41 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $375 million or $2.11 per diluted share a year ago. Excludin
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Consolidated results in the fourth quarter of 2015 were a loss of $587 million, that's $3.41 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $375 million or $2.11 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations, continuing operations had a loss of $583 million in the fourth quarter of '15, $3.39 per diluted share, and that compares to the fourth quarter '14 of $442 million profit, $2.48 per diluted share a year ago. 
The fourth quarter results for 2015 from continuing operations included noncash property impairments of $192.2 million, which after taxes amounted to $123.5 million charge. These impairments were attributable to a decline in future periods oil prices and primarily were related to an oil and gas property in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico. The just completed quarter also included an after-tax expense of $183.3 million to reflect the cost to exit 2 deepwater drilling rig contracts in the Gulf of Mexico. We chose to stack these rigs as low oil prices led to significant reductions in our capital expenditure program in the Gulf of Mexico, and the company was no longer able to obtain partner support for U.S. deepwater drilling as these partners are experiencing significant capital constraints. 
Murphy also recorded a U.S. income tax charge of $188.5 million in the fourth quarter due to U.S. taxable income generated by a foreign dividend declared in December. The company had previously recorded U.S. income tax benefits earlier in 2015 associated with an anticipated U.S. operating loss carryforward prior to our decision to make this foreign distribution to the parent. The foreign distribution was made through a combination of $800 million in cash and the remainder in the form of a 10-year note. This distribution effectively was cash tax neutral in 2015 due to operating losses and availability of foreign tax credits. This U.S. tax charge was recorded in the company's corporate reporting area, which led to a higher corporate net cost overall in the 2015 quarter compared to the prior year. 
Let me speak about adjusted earnings. These adjusted earnings adjust our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of earnings between periods. And this adjusted earnings was a loss of $130.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2015, down from a profit of $69 million a year ago. This decline in adjusted earnings was primarily attributable to lower oil and natural gas sales prices in the current period. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
The company's average realized price for its crude oil production fell more than $28 per barrel in the fourth quarter compared to the prior year which amounted to a 40% drop between periods. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the fourth quarter compared to the prior year quarter. 
Realized oil index natural gas prices offshore Sarawak fell 31% to an average of $3.81 per Mcf, following the decline in global crude oil prices. Sales prices continue to be soft in January and, therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as quarter 1 2016 prices remain significantly below prices a year ago. As a reminder, however, the company has oil price hedges for 20,000 barrels per day at a WTI price of $52.01 for the remainder of 2016.
At December 31, 2015, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to slightly more than $3 billion, which represented 36.4% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to 32.8%. As of year end, we had $600 million borrowed under our $2 billion revolver. Plus we had a total of cash and invested cash of about $450 million worldwide. Murphy's sole debt covenant is a total debt to total capital ratio of 60%, which obviously we're well below. I believe we have adequate liquidity to weather the lower for longer oil price environment currently being experienced. 
That concludes my comments, and I'll pass it now to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Our company remains focused on balance sheet metrics as the entire industry experiences further commodity price drops. With this focus comes an extensive drop in capit
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Our company remains focused on balance sheet metrics as the entire industry experiences further commodity price drops. With this focus comes an extensive drop in capital spending; however, Murphy intends to be in the business for the long haul and as evidenced with news of our 2 purchase and sales agreements we released yesterday when closed will allow Murphy to sell a natural gas midstream business and use a portion of the proceeds to purchase a long-term asset that will deliver value to shareholders, especially in a price recovery. 
Looking back at operations over the course of the year, the following highlights stand out. We spent $2.2 billion in capital, which is 42% down from the prior year, while still growing production with the prior year when factoring in the 30% sell-down in Malaysia. 
On the coal side, we made significant improvements in reducing both operating and G&A expenses. We lowered our operating costs, excluding Syncrude, by $1.82 per BOE to $9.21 per BOE or 17% over the course of 2015 and lowered our G&A expenses by over $57 million or 16% compared to 2014 levels. 
In our onshore business, the Eagle Ford Shale continues to outperform expectations, where we averaged just over 57,000 barrel equivalents per day for the year, delivering a front-loaded schedule of 136 new wells, of which 27 were in the fourth quarter. We drilled our first Austin Chalk well in  Karnes County, achieving a very successful IP 30 flow rate of 1,500 barrels equivalent per day. We're planning on drilling our second Austin Chalk well in the first quarter of 2016. 
In Canada, we recently completed -- our recently completed wells in the Montney continue to produce above plan where we averaged 194 million cubic feet per day for the year. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, the Dalmatian South 2 well which was drilled in the third quarter achieved first production ahead of plan late in 2015. The well is currently flowing back to the Petronius facility. Development work continues at the non-operated Kodiak project where the first 2 wells will flow in the coming days. 
In Malaysia, fourth quarter Sarawak natural gas production was over 134 million per day net and oil production was over 14,000 barrels a day. Full year production for Malaysia was over 65,200-barrel equivalents per day. 
We are seeing continued drilling success at our South Acis field in Sarawak, where we announced the sanctioned volumes doubling. In addition, we drilled the Keratau well offshore Brunei, finding commercial natural gas that were in line with pre-drill estimates adding to our resources in the Kelidang field. 
On the fourth quarter, production was just over 200,700 barrel equivalents per day and our full year for the year, we produced close to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day.
We are pleased with the ongoing efforts we're making on cost reductions. Our LOE for quarter 4 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $8.25 per BOE, showing a reduction of 19% from the fourth quarter of '14. This is in line with the 17% reduction for full year 2014 on LOE. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, had fourth quarter operating expenses of just under $8.50 per BOE, and we expect this to be a reasonable run rate going forward. 
In 2015, we produced over 207 barrel oil equivalent per day, our strong production variance over the course of the year is attributable to Sarawak oil and natural gas fields performing better. The Eagle Ford Shale, new well volumes exceeding plan due to EUR increases and completion performance and higher natural gas production from the Montney. 
More importantly, we spent $2.19 billion as compared to our original CapEx plan of $2.3 billion. Even with the significant reduction in capital for 2015, we grew annual production by 3%. 
In 2015, based on preliminary data, we expect to add reserves at a replacement rate of 123% with finding and development costs of $18.70 per BOE. Year end 2015 reserve volumes represented Reserve Life Index of 10.2 years, an increase from 9.2 years from a year ago. This is consistent with our 5-year average reserve replacement rate greater than 180% and is our 10th consecutive year over 100%. During the same time frame, we have more than doubled our production, including a sell-down of our Malaysia assets. 
The capital program for 2016 is currently $825 million, which is approximately 62% lower than $2.19 billion we invested in 2015. We expect production for full year to be 180,000 to 185,000 barrel equivalents per day, which is lower than 2015 due to significant CapEx cuts. As common in our industry, the capital program still remains under review for further reductions, should the commodity prices persist.
Moving on to the subsequent year-end events, as you have read in our news release from last night, we signed 2 purchase and sale agreements announcing the monetization of our midstream Montney and the joint venture in the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids-rich Montney area. We signed a definitive agreement with Enbridge to divest our natural gas processing sales pipeline assets that support our Montney natural gas fields in Tupper and Tupper West. The cash consideration is expected to be CAD 538 million and expected to be closed early in the second quarter. 
In a separate but related transaction, we signed a definitive agreement for a joint venture with Athabasca Oil Corp. to acquire 70% operated working interest in Athabasca's acreage, infrastructure and facilities in the Kaybob Duvernay lands and a 30% non-operated working interest in the liquids-rich Montney. The total consideration is CAD 475 million, of which CAD 250 million is in cash at closing and the remaining CAD 225 million is a carry for a period up to 5 years. 
In the Kaybob Duvernay, there were 230,000 gross acres, 200,000 currently prospective that are currently producing 6,900-barrel equivalent gross per day of production, of which 58% is liquids. This area also includes 247,000 gross acres with overlying rights in the conventional Montney. 
In the liquids-rich Montney area, there are 60,000 gross acres, 21,000 currently viewed as prospective that are currently producing 900-barrel equivalent a day gross at 44% liquids. 
We're very excited to enter to the Kaybob Duvernay and liquid-rich Montney as it complements our current onshore North American resources, fits well with our in-house expertise and will be our third significant North American unconventional position. The CAD 225 million carry in long lease term associated with the Kaybob Duvernay is flexible over 5 years, which is key in this period of low commodity prices where we're able to control the pace of spend. We're allocating partial proceeds from our Montney midstream monetization into this project. And I see it as efficient use of capital that has a positive impact to cash on hand for our balance sheet this year as well as use of Canadian funds in Canada in a tax efficient manner and enter a project that's expected to be self funding within Canada over the life of the period. 
The primary marketable product here as realized will be produced condensate, which is used as diluent for oil sands bitumen production and transport. The Western Canadian oil sands projects have long demonstrated a record of production resiliency that will continue to generate demand well in the excess of regional supply, resulting in relative price stability for foreseeable future. Our joint venture has oil battery capacity of 30,000 barrels per day of oil, and gas pipeline with over 100 million scf per day of capacity.
The Kaybob Duvernay is an emerging play and has 3 same segments seen in the Eagle Ford Shale, natural gas, gas condensate and light oil. The gas condensate area has included several prolific wells of late, and the light oil area that we now have a significant position in is in the early stages of development. We are seeing all signs of a shale play success with increasing EURs, improving completion techniques, as well as lowering of drilling and completion costs. We feel that with 3 to 4 wells per section, we will have over 500 gross locations in the play and this number can greatly increase should downspacing opportunities exist here as seen in other successful North American plays. 
We are seeing many successful wells across the play now approaching 30 test intervals of over 2,000-barrel equivalent per day with yields ranging from 200 to 950 barrel per million and a clear indicator of the oil-rich nature of this basin. 
The Duvernay areas have been heavily drilled through other types of plays through the years in the basin which leads to thousands of penetrations and knowledge of the shale characteristics. Additionally, we have a black oil area in the play, again matching success seen in the Eagle Ford Shale area.
Our new joint venture partner, Athabasca, has been successful in the play with results the condensate region and most importantly, in the light oil area of the play. Athabasca's recently released information about a key well in the gas condensate light oil area that's flowed 1,300-barrel equivalents per day with 62% liquids. This appears to be a very good well by any measure. 
As in any shale play, the optimization of the fracture treatments are key to the learning curve. Of late, higher proppant concentrations have been used in the region. This slide highlights the increase in EUR seen with data up to 2 years in duration, illustrating recent higher treatments lead to consistent EUR levels. Some wells are now seeing above the 1,000 -- 1 million, rather, barrel type curve. These wells shown here in the condensate window are now partnered in the 33,000 acres with a 70% working interest. We're seeing the same -- we see the same well performance with higher stimulation treatments in the Duvernay light oil area as well as where we are working a 70% working interest with our partner in 67,000 acres. We believe there's significant upside in the black oil area where our partnership has 110,000 gross acres. Current data is showing high proppant content at the 607 -- 670,000-barrel equivalent EUR level. 
Our joint venture also includes our liquids-rich Montney, which is among the top active plays in Canada. We participate here in the non-op 30% working interest. The region has a minimum of 30% of the flow stream containing liquids, similar to the condensate in light oil areas. The results in the liquid-rich area are also showing increasing EURs due to completion enhancements and the lowering of costs with 750,000-barrel equivalent EURs seen in the data set. This area has significant running room in the range of 100 to 200 locations with downspacing. We see a tightly leased up area around our new acreage with many non-North American shale players. Rates here are also prolific in the range of 800 barrel equivalents with high-liquid yields.
Like all major shale plays in North America, the key economic driver is the lowering of drilling and completion costs while simultaneously improving the completion techniques for each area. We are seeing the early stages of a major improvement in costs for the region and our expertise in 2 other plays where we are a top quartile drilling and completion company will enhance our ability to quickly move up the learning curve here. Our partner Athabasca is active in the cost reduction business, and we will be able to quickly adapt to the area where they have recently seen incredible improvements as we see great upside in lowering costs from the current CAD 9.4 million per well down to CAD 6.5 million per well. Athabasca has recently seen wells being drilled for as low as CAD 3.25 million, which is an outstanding performance. 
As I close our call today, here are a few takeaways: We're focusing on our balance sheet at Murphy. The purchase and sale agreement to monetize our natural gas midstream and use a portion of proceeds to enter into an onshore conventional shale play that allows for balance sheet neutrality with a 5-year carry and further liquidity this year for our cash positions. We see this venture as an investment for the long term with total spend flexibility over a 5-year period as we anticipate a price recovery. Cost reductions will continue to be our focus. Our Eagle Ford Shale continues to perform very well for us. The budget reductions will lead to a very limited exploration spend this year. We continue to illustrate the execution advantages we have in the offshore. We had an excellent year operationally in our company with the reserve additions, significant capital reductions and lowering costs leading the way. 
I would now like to open the phone lines up for your questions, and thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Roger Read, Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Roger Read, Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about the acquisition. I mean, I know the sell-down in Malaysia, a little over a year ago, I think that's right, yes, or at least the announcement. Then the talk of a transformative acquisition. Is this one of those transformative acquisitions
componenttext: Can we talk about the acquisition. I mean, I know the sell-down in Malaysia, a little over a year ago, I think that's right, yes, or at least the announcement. Then the talk of a transformative acquisition. Is this one of those transformative acquisitions? Or should we still consider something in the lower 48 is still more likely and still desirable opportunity?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think of it as transformative for us. I mean, it's got all of the things we're looking for today. It's very rare to get into M&A in North America and have flexibility on the first year of capital spend and have no continuous drilling clauses, be abl
componenttext: No. I think of it as transformative for us. I mean, it's got all of the things we're looking for today. It's very rare to get into M&A in North America and have flexibility on the first year of capital spend and have no continuous drilling clauses, be able to drag out the carry over a very long period of time at a very low oil price. I've said for a long time that I would like a 10% cost of capital-type return at a strip price. And with the drilling costs we're seeing here, we're able to do that here, even on strip that we used on January 19, which was probably $4 behind where we are today. So I see this as transformative for us, Roger, honestly, because it has a 200 million, 300 million barrel ability for us. It's pretty low-cost entry. It's different from buying a -- from a company that's flipping acres because we have a partner that's working there and has drilled there and has infrastructure there, and we're able to work with them and take over as the operator. They're able to operate a piece where they've been very successful. It's in Canada. We'll have Canadian proceeds. There's a low ForEx right now for this transaction. Where the USD equivalent of that would not get you what it used to get you here in the United States. And all of those factors led to this decision.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then as you think about lower 48, are there still opportunities? Are we still too far apart on a bid-ask spread? Just curious, any update you would have on what you're seeing there.
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then as you think about lower 48, are there still opportunities? Are we still too far apart on a bid-ask spread? Just curious, any update you would have on what you're seeing there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we look at many opportunities. I do the same thing, whether its offshore or in the Permian or in the Eagle Ford or wherever. We look at the rate of return we get at strip prices and with cost and how will it flex our balance sheet and how we h
componenttext: No, I mean, we look at many opportunities. I do the same thing, whether its offshore or in the Permian or in the Eagle Ford or wherever. We look at the rate of return we get at strip prices and with cost and how will it flex our balance sheet and how we have to drill so much capital and hurt our balance sheet further, and that's come up as a new factor in the M&A analysis that we had from a year ago. And that's just as important now, the balance sheet of how one of these projects would impact you, if anything for me now. So we sought the return or see a very similar to a project we working in the lower 48, but we ended up with a project in the lower 48, totally downspaced, every zone working, to have the same rate of return as one in Canada where we have no downspacing at all, built-in partner, 5-year lease program, 5-year carry period, and just offered every advantage to me in $30 oil that I don't have down here right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And last question I'll ask on the acquisition front. You've always talked about wanting to use cash or debt. Obviously, now debt is a little more questionable as an opportunity for a whole host of reasons. Would you, at all, consider issuing
componenttext: Okay, great. And last question I'll ask on the acquisition front. You've always talked about wanting to use cash or debt. Obviously, now debt is a little more questionable as an opportunity for a whole host of reasons. Would you, at all, consider issuing equity? I know that's not something the company's historically done, but as you think about that cost of capital, does that factor in or not so much?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Roger, we've been working pretty hard on these 2 transactions and I don't have another one in my pocket today, I'm pretty tired. And it's taken us a lot of work to do these 2, and we didn't have to use debt and we didn't have to use equity. And I'm
componenttext: Well, Roger, we've been working pretty hard on these 2 transactions and I don't have another one in my pocket today, I'm pretty tired. And it's taken us a lot of work to do these 2, and we didn't have to use debt and we didn't have to use equity. And I'm very pleased, and not looking for a deal today to issue equity at this price in my company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Kyle Rhodes, RBC.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Kyle Rhodes, RBC.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any more light you can shed on the new midterm agreements with Enbridge just maybe in terms of minimum volume commitments? And what that means for future drilling obligation there and maybe run rate gathering and processing expense we should be m
componenttext: Is there any more light you can shed on the new midterm agreements with Enbridge just maybe in terms of minimum volume commitments? And what that means for future drilling obligation there and maybe run rate gathering and processing expense we should be modeling in going forward?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a very nice transaction there. We're very pleased with it. We're not disclosing the tariff arrangement there. You would have to look at cost of capital, those top players, residual value and you can work through that. I think the way to think abou
componenttext: We have a very nice transaction there. We're very pleased with it. We're not disclosing the tariff arrangement there. You would have to look at cost of capital, those top players, residual value and you can work through that. I think the way to think about this business is if you have $1.90 to $2 AECO run through that business every year, we're able to drill our wells and have cash flow neutrality and not hurt our balance sheet in any way, a lot of optionality around how many wells we drill, we're doing very, very well there in the EUR per well basis. We're able to get the money from these guys at a favorable rate to us as to how this works, and we're able to use these proceeds of selling steel and getting into 200 million to 300 million barrel reserves type P2 number. And I like the sound of it, I like the transaction, and we're not concerned about the level of drilling that we'll need to do or allocate capital here because of the incredible reduction in our operating expenses, our improved fracturing techniques, our lower drilling cost and all the positives attributes to shale we have in the Montney 2. And we have a very good partner there, one of the dominating players in North America in the space and very, very happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then maybe just kind of circling back to Duvernay, realize the ink still not even dry yet on this deal, but how are you guys kind of just high-level thinking about development over the next couple of years? Is kind of the light oil window
componenttext: Okay, great. And then maybe just kind of circling back to Duvernay, realize the ink still not even dry yet on this deal, but how are you guys kind of just high-level thinking about development over the next couple of years? Is kind of the light oil window going to be the near-term area of focus? Or how should we be thinking about in terms of derisking that new position there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we have -- just got the ink dried on the thing, these deals are complex and today in the price collapse and doing the deal like this with our partner, very happy about all the areas. And I would say that we concentrate in a mixture of both t
componenttext: Well, I mean, we have -- just got the ink dried on the thing, these deals are complex and today in the price collapse and doing the deal like this with our partner, very happy about all the areas. And I would say that we concentrate in a mixture of both the condensate, which is very, very successful by many successful shale players. Pretty big light oil window that were creeping north toward, if you look to the slides today. And we'll have a limited capital in 2016 because of severe drop in price. Most of that capital will be allocated to our completing wells that are owned by the partner today when we close the transaction. And got about a 6- or 9-month period to plan out where we want to execute on that. But very pleased with all the areas and be happy to drill wells in any of it, to be honest with you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And one last one for me, Roger. Just what's your kind of current comfort level with the dividend?
componenttext: That's helpful. And one last one for me, Roger. Just what's your kind of current comfort level with the dividend?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a dividend policy here for a very long time. And the oil prices just collapsed for a short time. But like any company today, if these price levels persist, then the dividend discussion will be on the table here in our company. And that we
componenttext: Well, we've had a dividend policy here for a very long time. And the oil prices just collapsed for a short time. But like any company today, if these price levels persist, then the dividend discussion will be on the table here in our company. And that we will have that and review that as necessary. And I would say we'll be on the table in these prices more than before. And that's really all I have to say on that matter.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Guy Baber from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Guy Baber from Simmons & Company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the JV transaction, I wanted to follow up on a comment that you made earlier, Roger, about the return. But can you just help frame for us and maybe discuss the economics that are underlying the deal? On the last call, you talked about running 4 price d
componenttext: On the JV transaction, I wanted to follow up on a comment that you made earlier, Roger, about the return. But can you just help frame for us and maybe discuss the economics that are underlying the deal? On the last call, you talked about running 4 price decks, I think to screen deals and wanting to get a return at the strip. And we aren't as familiar with these assets. So any return framework or how you think these assets compete for capital in the current environment or rising oil price environment, I think, would help us better understand this.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in a very big collapse in price here recently, of course, and when we say strip, where we're using a January 19 strip. And it was around $32.76 2016, $37 for '17 and up to $44 in 2020. Of course today, these numbers are about $4 better than th
componenttext: Well, we're in a very big collapse in price here recently, of course, and when we say strip, where we're using a January 19 strip. And it was around $32.76 2016, $37 for '17 and up to $44 in 2020. Of course today, these numbers are about $4 better than that. And when we run through this entire thing, as we've always said and always desired and a requirement here, is we'd be above 10%. When we look at current drilling and completion costs, which are very critical, and that's without any downspacing at all. And then when we have another price deck here, we call our low planning price from January, it's a very low price for '16, around $29, $41 in '17 and going up to $60 in 2020. And this project looks very good, as good as any M&A we've seen and above '15 range. And when you get a big cost, a big price recovery deck here, we'll get into the 20% range. So we're very happy about it. It stacks up well with all the opportunities we reviewed across the spectrum and we looked that a lot. And very, very happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then can you talk a little bit more about the flexibility that you have, the minimum level of activity you all have to progress there with the JV in terms of holding acreage or the minimum commitments that you have when it c
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then can you talk a little bit more about the flexibility that you have, the minimum level of activity you all have to progress there with the JV in terms of holding acreage or the minimum commitments that you have when it comes to allocating capital, because it sounds as if that was an attractive element to this deal. So if you could just talk about that a little bit more?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a very attractive element, because as the whole time we looked at it, we've had another level of price collapse. And looking in the USD 130 million, USD 140 million capital through the first 3 years on our low basis and going into the 200s in 20
componenttext: Yes, it's a very attractive element, because as the whole time we looked at it, we've had another level of price collapse. And looking in the USD 130 million, USD 140 million capital through the first 3 years on our low basis and going into the 200s in 2020 to get this carry behind us and kind of a smooth 200 million a year doesn't lead to incredible growth for us, we're talking about a 30,000-barrel a day type number in 2023 or so. Of course, that can be greatly enhanced with the -- we feel we have conservative EURs in this analysis. And start drilling some wells and proving, and trying not to build up the big overspend here. And the key thing for us is if you look at our Mocal cash position, they have $240 million, $250 million, whatever it is, take this money in for midstream, have a big Western Canada business, Syncrude, East Coast Canada and our Montney business and our new midstream business and we're able to run through this business here, and it's EBITDA accretive to us, it's income -- slight income accretion to us with very, very low prices, and we're able to run through that and keep all of our Mocal cash balances intact. And it's some $300-something million the whole time. And that's very attractive for us because we have to get on the balance sheet here, have to get back to free cash flow, have to get this debt worked down over time and that's about the only project we had that had the returns I wanted and had the ability to do that for me right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then final one for me. On the capital budget for 2016, you made a comment that the budget would be under review for further reduction. So just trying to understand that comment. Is that if the current strip persists? Is that if we see ano
componenttext: Okay, great. And then final one for me. On the capital budget for 2016, you made a comment that the budget would be under review for further reduction. So just trying to understand that comment. Is that if the current strip persists? Is that if we see another leg down in price? Help us understand that comment? And then, it seems that you've hit the CapEx budget pretty hard, obviously. Where do you have incremental flexibility to flex lower if you choose to do that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a lot of flexibility in the Eagle Ford and we can go down $100 million there if we want to. And that's the beauty of these plays as you can slow it down more difficult than offshore, and that would be where that would come from. And while prices o
componenttext: We have a lot of flexibility in the Eagle Ford and we can go down $100 million there if we want to. And that's the beauty of these plays as you can slow it down more difficult than offshore, and that would be where that would come from. And while prices on a rampage the last 4 days, it's still not too exciting to me, I can tell you that. So we have got to keep this balance sheet intact. We cannot be lulled into believing this is back here headed into the 40s and just not headed that way. I'm not scared to cut the CapEx, and I will. And we're going to get on balance sheet instead of production because I've grown production as much as anybody through the years. And so we're going to stay in business for a long time. We're going to keep our balance sheet in the right zip code here.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Ryan Todd, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Ryan Todd, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe following up on capital allocation level, can you talk a little bit about relative competition to the capital between the Eagle Ford and the Athabasca JV going forward? I mean, what are the relative rates of return? What is the relative rate of retu
componenttext: Maybe following up on capital allocation level, can you talk a little bit about relative competition to the capital between the Eagle Ford and the Athabasca JV going forward? I mean, what are the relative rates of return? What is the relative rate of return right now between the 2 plays? And if we were to see incremental upward pressure on the commodity, where would we see capital go first?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that our Eagle Ford, because of its oily nature and not the U.S. AECO nature. It will always be slightly ahead of wells up there. But then you have this balance sheet issue of U.S. cost and repatriation and tax efficiency and working in the Mocal
componenttext: I think that our Eagle Ford, because of its oily nature and not the U.S. AECO nature. It will always be slightly ahead of wells up there. But then you have this balance sheet issue of U.S. cost and repatriation and tax efficiency and working in the Mocal area. But if we remove it around pretty good, they compete very well. A condensate well and an oil window well up in Canada competes very well with lower Eagle Ford Shale and Karnes. That's what's so interesting, Ryan, about this deal and about these shale plays is that 4 years ago, the Catarina area, where we have an enormous acreage position in Western Eagle Ford Shale was one of our lowest rate of return areas in the company in -- in the Eagle Ford, I mean. So over this time, the EURs have doubled, the drilling costs have halved and it went from the bottom to the best. So it's a best individual well, economics around 25% on that January 19 strip date where we normalized all our costs. And this project up there is competing with there. But the point is, is things change. Some areas become better than others. Places not so good last time are better this time. The cost in this northern light oil area are very, very good, getting much better and we put those costs in here. This project is going to compete with the Eagle Ford very well for us. And then, it will be a matter of our capital -- what we do about repatriation and how we want to work in our Mocal cash balance. But on the overall allocation capital, it will work well and it will be some hard decisions there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe one -- maybe another one on CapEx. In the Eagle Ford, the level of spend in the Eagle Ford seems fairly high for running 1.25 rigs. I mean, is there a timing issue related to there? How much of that is infrastructure related? Or is t
componenttext: Great. And then maybe one -- maybe another one on CapEx. In the Eagle Ford, the level of spend in the Eagle Ford seems fairly high for running 1.25 rigs. I mean, is there a timing issue related to there? How much of that is infrastructure related? Or is there as we look forward over the next year or 2, is there some of that CapEx that we should expect to see roll off going forward?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Mike answer that for you.
componenttext: I'll let Mike answer that for you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mike McFadyen here. I guess, the -- could you repeat the question again please?
componenttext: It's Mike McFadyen here. I guess, the -- could you repeat the question again please?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The question is, it looks like you're spending about $340 million in the Eagle Ford, running 1.25 rigs roughly for the year, which -- I mean, the absolute level of spend seems a little high. Is that -- can you -- how much of that additional capital in the
componenttext: The question is, it looks like you're spending about $340 million in the Eagle Ford, running 1.25 rigs roughly for the year, which -- I mean, the absolute level of spend seems a little high. Is that -- can you -- how much of that additional capital in the Eagle Ford is infrastructure related? Or and should we expect to see any of that roll off over the -- or is it a timing issue over the next period of months or years?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's primarily drilling and completions. We're going to drill 45 wells. And we're going to complete between 55 and 60 wells. So we have some well inventory that we'll complete with that capital as well. So it's a fairly significant amount. There's a littl
componenttext: It's primarily drilling and completions. We're going to drill 45 wells. And we're going to complete between 55 and 60 wells. So we have some well inventory that we'll complete with that capital as well. So it's a fairly significant amount. There's a little bit electrification work that will help lower our operating cost, probably about $30 million, $40 million of that. But as Roger mentioned, that capital could be considered to be cut as well, and we could consider going down to less than 1 rig in the Eagle Ford and putting back $100 million to the Corporation.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Paul Cheng, Barclays.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take our next question from Paul Cheng, Barclays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like it's a very good transaction. I was just curious, the $825 million CapEx that you put out, I'm assuming that's not including the JV spending, right?
componenttext: It looks like it's a very good transaction. I was just curious, the $825 million CapEx that you put out, I'm assuming that's not including the JV spending, right?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct, Paul. We're going to have a year of explaining this. The $825 million is Murphy as is. We go into this transaction we, of course, have to pay the down payment. And I'm speaking to you now and it's another confusing thing, Paul, we have to
componenttext: That's correct, Paul. We're going to have a year of explaining this. The $825 million is Murphy as is. We go into this transaction we, of course, have to pay the down payment. And I'm speaking to you now and it's another confusing thing, Paul, we have to keep in mind as I'm speaking now in USD. So this CapEx will go up by $223 million, but most of it is the purchase down payment. And then, we will have a very limited capital at $30 million to $40 million this year is the current plan. We have to get with our partner, get with what's going on with their production reserves, et cetera, and allocate capital there efficiently, but we have plan. Keep in mind that this deal is structured between November 30 and January 20, and it was an exciting time for oil prices, Paul, and so we have very limited capital there planned in '16, kind of get our feet on the ground, get in there with a partner that has been working and has been working well and able to pick up and move forward and get it on into '17. But very little this year, Paul, but that is correct. The guidance here for production and the capital in these remarks today do not include the transaction we did with our joint venture partner, Athabasca.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, on the first couple of years when you start spending money in this joint venture, are those some of the science project or that is going to be really already in the manufacturing side?
componenttext: Roger, on the first couple of years when you start spending money in this joint venture, are those some of the science project or that is going to be really already in the manufacturing side?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't see that. There's loads of wells here. There's incredible amount of information being released by nearby shale players like Encana, very successful here. And Canada is a little different than Texas. It's incredible accurate data released publi
componenttext: No, I don't see that. There's loads of wells here. There's incredible amount of information being released by nearby shale players like Encana, very successful here. And Canada is a little different than Texas. It's incredible accurate data released publicly. A lot of what all the proppants are, what are the link to the wells are, the orientation of the well. Canada does a very good job in that regard. And I see us getting into pads and drilling 4 well pads much earlier than we did in the Eagle Ford. And I think that it's critical to understand that Murphy had 0 shale presence in our company 4 years ago, 900 wells today and know what we're doing and we're going to get in there and get going and hopefully, in pad drilling hit pretty quick, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Can you give us some idea that in 2017, what kind of range of oil price and what kind of the JV spending are going to look like?

componenttext: I only have the low case in front of me, Paul. When we get back to 60, we'll be glad to speak with you about that. I'm seeing capital in the USD 130 million range for '17 and '18 right now in front of me, as I look at this, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And Roger, if you're going to stay at $825 million on your base operation and yet you stay here for 2017, what's going to be 2017 recovery look like? Is it going to be [indiscernible]...

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, we've been doing very well in production here. Eagle Ford has been a resilient. We have it declining in here this year, and we've gone through 2 or 3 budgets here, have a board meeting next week in that regard and really not getting off into '17. We
componenttext: Paul, we've been doing very well in production here. Eagle Ford has been a resilient. We have it declining in here this year, and we've gone through 2 or 3 budgets here, have a board meeting next week in that regard and really not getting off into '17. We had a pretty big collapse in price. We're trying to focus on our about balance sheet above all and not leading the way on the '17 guidance parade there, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Two final questions. One, can you give us some idea that how's the Eagle Ford production trend by quarter look like or that I mean we start out from what and end the year at roughly what run rate? And then finally, look like you guys didn't have any
componenttext: Okay. Two final questions. One, can you give us some idea that how's the Eagle Ford production trend by quarter look like or that I mean we start out from what and end the year at roughly what run rate? And then finally, look like you guys didn't have any research write-down or markdown on the full-time reserve unlike some of your peers. I just want to make sure that's the case?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's true, Paul. Mike McFadyen is going to look up the cap -- the production for you. I'll now speak about the reserves. We had a very good year in reserves in this company and we've done a good job on it for a long time and we added some PUD locat
componenttext: Yes, that's true, Paul. Mike McFadyen is going to look up the cap -- the production for you. I'll now speak about the reserves. We had a very good year in reserves in this company and we've done a good job on it for a long time and we added some PUD locations in the Eagle Ford. We've had some very small negative revisions in our performance as a company. We've had some type curve enhancements in Eagle Ford Shale. We had some operating expense help into the long cycle. Actually, Paul, with our company in Malaysia you're able to get some added new barrels with price and as our entitlement goes up, so it's an advantage then of not just being in one spot. It's not significant, but it helps us there. And of course, we sold down 20 million barrels in Malaysia and produced 76 million. So to replace with highest the [ph] budget, and we're a company that's very proud of our EURs and our costs, and I'm very happy about the lack of a write-down in our calculations, Paul. And now Mike is going to talk to you about the production Eagle Ford which has -- have a lot less CapEx this year.

componenttext: Yes, I'll speak to that. So the light oil window which represents the lion's share of the acreage, we value 67,000 acres of that, is can be drilled without intermediate casing. And Athabasca just drilled 2 pacesetter wells there in 2015, one at 13 days and one at 16 days. So it's that kind of drilling performance in the CAD 3 million to CAD 3.5 million is what they spent, including lease construction costs is what's going to get us there. It's similar to the northern part of our Eagle Ford where we've started in the basin and with drill times at 25, 25-plus days and are now down to 7 days in the Catarina area. It's also similar to our Montney operated area where we're continuing to improve drill times and costs there where we've driven -- we're down now in the 6 million, sub-6 million drilling complete cost in our Tupper, Tupper West area where we're targeting anywhere from 12 to 14 days of well this year.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then on the recoverable resource of 200 to 350, I'm just looking at the bubble map you got on Slide 12. I mean, as with some of these other combo plays, you have the better results in the gas condensate light oil. I don't know how many wells have actually been drilled in the black oil area. Maybe talk a little bit about -- the decent chunk of acreage up there, maybe talk a little bit about what was included in that resource number? And then what economics would be needed to get the black oil window to work?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't count any of above the black oil line on Page 12 right now. And that we used only the light oil and the condensate and then the liquids Montney that shows up in some other slides. And this acreage is quite derisked and the gas condensate area, t
componenttext: We didn't count any of above the black oil line on Page 12 right now. And that we used only the light oil and the condensate and then the liquids Montney that shows up in some other slides. And this acreage is quite derisked and the gas condensate area, there's successful wells all around it, and we used a no downspacing there and use no downspacing anywhere to arrive that number, Ed. And we then took a -- over in the Western part of this thing called light oil on Page 12, some very successful wells. And we took a higher EUR curve there, you can see some of the EUR results in the back here as to the concentration of proppant, Ed. And moving to the east, we took a more conservative one. These wells have a rate of return in the 14%, 15% range, $30 oil type strip. I think in the black oil area, it's a matter of there would be some experimentation there to figure out how to make that work. That's the issue now with capital allocation. But the advantage here is that a lot of long life leases like leasing in the Gulf of Mexico, if you will, it's a government crown lease and no continuous drilling clauses, a lot of flexibility, a lot of information to come to us, there's constantly wells being released for information in this region. And we're going to be monitoring that and real excited about just a portion of it working is incredibly valuable to us, Ed.

componenttext: No, not at all. I mean, today, they have 30,000 of oil batteries and ability on oil, over 100 million of gas. There's a lot of MLP-type activity and people reactivating gas plants. This has been a historic producing basin. Similar to the Eagle Ford Shale in many ways, a lot of gas pipes headed to Edmonton, a lot of transport of condensate. There's 2 exits for gas coming out of here, which are very helpful. And we now have a part of that infrastructure as to our working interest with our partner there, and glad to have it. It's valuable as well. It's up and going. They're adding to it, used to adding to it, know how to add to it, pleased to not have to start over in the infrastructure business at a $34 oil.

componenttext: Well, we have a very good partner that operates a lot of midstream in North America, and a lot midstream in Canada, this is a competitive process, very glad with the winner there, if you will. And if they lower operating expenses at the plant level, we were able to share in some of that with them. They should be able to do that as they do that for a living there. We operate just those 2 plants. I think we're very good operator, but I think they could help and we could share in that. We got our operating expenses probably down in the $0.30 range per Mcf, it's incredible job by Mike and his team. And so that's where it stands, and I'm really pleased to move that midstream into an upstream and not impact my balance sheet, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to take -- I would -- first, in that matter what I said is that if these prices persist and I'm not greatly enthused by the run-up today, I still believe we're going to be in a low 30s world, but I'm very happy it's up to a little bit I suppos
componenttext: We're going to take -- I would -- first, in that matter what I said is that if these prices persist and I'm not greatly enthused by the run-up today, I still believe we're going to be in a low 30s world, but I'm very happy it's up to a little bit I suppose. As we have that persist, we will have to take a closer look at our dividend than we have before. And it will be done as we go through the year. And on your prior questions, I mean, yes, I said the $800 million will be very painful and it is because our production levels are down. But we got to get control of our free cash flow goal, and then we'll get this rig issue behind us this year, which would require a lot more capital had we kept it. We will work toward not running up our debt at all and look to lowering debt best we can. So that's -- things have changed -- since I saw you, we probably lost $10 a barrel of crude, Paul. So it is a lot more. So if I said it was painful, it is. So -- and we have to realize it, get on it, focus on cost. We've done a great job on cost, and we are seeing very competitive prices from service companies as to fracking services in North America. And these continue to compete well with each other and help us pass through this collapse. And we're going to continue to stay on it, and that's what we're going to do.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 kind of housekeeping items. On the Canadian, dual Canadian deals, is there a tax efficiency to keeping your proceeds from the midstream deal in Canada rather than repatriating?
componenttext: Just 2 kind of housekeeping items. On the Canadian, dual Canadian deals, is there a tax efficiency to keeping your proceeds from the midstream deal in Canada rather than repatriating?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, if you -- if we were to consider repatriating and declaring some type of dividend bubble, we'd have to pay a toll for doing that because there's withholding tax of 5%. And there is quite frankly, a different -- always has been a d
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, if you -- if we were to consider repatriating and declaring some type of dividend bubble, we'd have to pay a toll for doing that because there's withholding tax of 5%. And there is quite frankly, a different -- always has been a differential in the tax rate in Canada being 25%, 26%, 27% range as opposed to a 35% tax rate in the U.S. So we've always been declared indefinitely reinvested in Canada. You'd keep it that way up until you couldn't do it any more and because you don't really want to pay that toll if you don't have to. But there is cash up there, so it's an evaluation of how you have to look at it on an overall basis and what's best for the corporation in total. So yes, keeping it up there saves cash taxes is a short answer.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Plea
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the inf
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you can follow along with the webcast today. John will begin by providing a review of first quarter financial results, highlighting our strong balance sheet and liquidity position following our most recently announced divestitures. Roger will then follow with an operational update and outlook, after which questions will be taken. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exists that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2015 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the first quarter of 2016 were loss of $198.8 million, which is $1.16 per diluted share, and that compares to a loss of $14.4 million or $0.08 per diluted share a y
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the first quarter of 2016 were loss of $198.8 million, which is $1.16 per diluted share, and that compares to a loss of $14.4 million or $0.08 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding our discontinued operations, our continuing operations had a loss of $199.5 million, again $1.16, versus a profit in the first quarter of 2015 of $3.5 million, which was $0.02 per diluted share. 
The first quarter results from continuing operations for 2016 included noncash property impairments of $95.1 million, which after tax has amounted to $68.9 million charge. These impairments were primarily attributable to the declines in future periods oil prices as of quarter end March and the impairments related to both Terra Nova and Seal properties in Canada. 
The just completed quarter also included an after-tax expense of $6.2 million to reflect restructuring costs by the company. The 2015 first quarter a year ago benefited from $199.5 million after-tax gain on the sale of 10% of our Malaysian assets, which closed in January 2015. 
Adjusted earnings, which adjusts our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of results between periods was a loss of $112.8 million in the first quarter 2016, an improvement from the adjusted net loss of $198.5 million a year ago. This improvement in adjusted results in 2016 was primarily attributable to lower exploration expenses, partially offset by significantly lower oil and natural gas sales prices compared to a year ago. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included in this part of our earnings release and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
The company's average realized price for its crude oil production was $34.19 per barrel sold, which was almost $13 per barrel lower, 27% in the first quarter 2016 compared to the prior year. 
Natural gas prices also were weaker in the first quarter compared to the prior year's quarter average North American gas price realizations of $1.57 per 1,000 cubic feet dropped $0.89 per Mcf or a decline of 36%. Realized oil index natural gas prices offshore Sarawak fell 18% to an average of $3.67 per Mcf following the decline in global crude oil prices. 
The company's cash flow from continuing operations for the first 3 months of 2016 was burdened by deepwater rig contract exit payments of $253.2 million. The income statement charge associated with these deepwater rig exits was recorded in the fourth quarter of 2015. 
For the second quarter 2016, the company has WTI-based oil price hedges for 20,000 barrels per day at a WTI average price of $52.01. For the last 6 months of 2016, the company has entered into an additional 5,000 barrels per day hedge at $45.30 per barrel or a blended average WTI price of $50.67 covering 25,000 barrels per day for the last 6 months of 2016. 
Additionally, the company has forward sales contracts for Canadian natural gas in the amount of 59 million cubic feet a day at an average AECO price of CAD 3.19 per thousand cubic feet on the remaining 9 months of 2016. 
At quarter end March 31, 2016, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to $3.4 billion, 39.6% percent of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to 35.5%. 
As of quarter end, we had $971 million of combined borrowings under our $2 billion revolver and uncommitted credit facilities. We also had a total of cash and invested cash of about $569 million worldwide. The closing of the Montney midstream asset sale for CAD 538 million on April 1 added to our cash position early in the second quarter. And the future completion of the recently announced Syncrude sale will also add to our cash position. 
Murphy's sole debt covenant at the present time is a total debt to capital ratio of 60%. 
Thank you, and that concludes my comments. And I'll pass it over to Roger at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for listening on our call today. Looking back at the first quarter, the following highlights stand out. We produced 196,600 barrel equivalents. We were able to exceed our quarterly guidance with hig
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for listening on our call today. Looking back at the first quarter, the following highlights stand out. We produced 196,600 barrel equivalents. We were able to exceed our quarterly guidance with high level of execution, which [indiscernible] close to 0 planned downtime or maintenance across our diversified production base and higher field performance in many of our key fields. 
From a safety standpoint, we had 0 recordable incidents across our entire company during the quarter, which are a remarkable feat for our operating team. 
We remain laser focused on reducing cost across our business. During the quarter, we reduced our 2016 annual capital to $580 million from the previously announced $825 million plan and, most importantly, after a 73% reduction from our 2015 capital spend of $2.2 billion. 
We also reduced lease operating expenses, excluding Syncrude, by 22% quarter-over-quarter. 
Also we continue to reposition our portfolio, including closing the previously announced noncore asset sale of our Montney midstream assets as well as recently signing a purchase sale agreement to divest 5% nonoperated working interest at Syncrude. We are working diligently to close our previously announced joint venture focused on expanding our footprint the North American onshore and conventional business in the Kaybob Duvernay and liquid-rich Montney areas in Canada. We continue review our portfolio and we'll act when opportunities present themselves.
I'm pleased with the ongoing efforts our team is making on cost reductions. Our lease operating expenses in quarter 1, excluding Syncrude, of $7.50 per BOE shown a reduction some 22% from the first quarter of '15 and a reduction of 9% from the fourth quarter last year. As a result, our decreased activities following ore commodity process and implemented a companywide workforce reduction, [indiscernible] stacking levels by about 20% in 2016. 
We've been able to lower our G&A cost excluding restructuring charges approximately 26% quarter-over-quarter. 
The capital program for 2016 being maintained as the press release said at $580 million while maintaining our production guidance range of 180,000 to 185,000-barrel equivalents per day. Our first quarter spending is roughly 25% of our annual CapEx, which is on our plan. Our annual and quarter capital and production plans have not yet been adjusted for pending asset divestment and assets should be acquired. Updating for production in capital spending would be released on the closing of these transactions. Production for the second quarter 2016 is estimated to be in the range of 177,000 to 180,000-barrel equivalents per day.
Looking at production. As I said, we produced 196,600 equivalents per day, exceeding guidance. The stronger-than-forecasted first quarter volumes were primarily due to higher production from Eagle Ford Shale, higher natural gas prod from the Montney, higher oil production from both offshore Sabah, Malaysia and offshore Canada. And these increases were partially offset by delays in bringing on our Kodiak subsea well in the Gulf of Mexico as well as increased downtime in Sarawak and Kikeh involved in our natural gas production in that area. It's important to note that our second quarter production guidance of 177,000 to 180,000 compared to first quarter's negatively impacted a planned downtime and maintenance across many of our assets, including 10 days at Sarawak natural gas, [indiscernible] subsea well 2 subsea wells shut in for 21 days in offshore Malaysia and Terra Nova they're at working on 28 day turnaround, and we are part of the long term 45-day turnaround at Syncrude, which is ongoing. The current guidance is based on Syncrude producing at reduced rates until the planned turnaround is complete over the next 2 weeks. However, we've not updated forecast with the recent news of wildfires in this area [indiscernible] misplaced residents in the Fort McMurray area. 
Plus Eagle Ford Shale will have natural production decline this quarter as we have no new wells planned to be added in that field.
In onshore business, Eagle Ford Shale continues to perform well where we averaged near 56,000-barrel equivalents a day for the quarter, where we delivered 13 new wells online, bringing our total operating well count to over 660. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, that first quarter operating expenses just under $8, a 6% reduction from the fourth quarter 2015. We continue to making strides in increasing drilling and completion costs as we average 4.1 million per well, which is 26% below first quarter 2015. We drilled a well in only 6 days from spud to rig release in our Catarina area. It's important to note that our strategy to work inside a lower-for-longer commodity price regime, with our much lower capital spend in 2016 will lead to bringing on 28 new wells and drilling 25 wells in the Eagle Ford. This is well below the 136 operated wells we brought online in 2015. We still have significant run room ahead of us here, over 2,000 potential Eagle Ford Shale locations and reserves of oil weighted at roughly 90%. Yes, it is very meaningful to Murphy's future reserve production cash flow.
Last year, we drilled our first [indiscernible] in Orange County. We continue to be pleased with the well's performance and just recently spud another [indiscernible] in Catarina area, testing most Western part of our acreage. We have an Austin Chalk well standing in [indiscernible], which will be completed later this year. We estimate we have approximately 265 Austin Chalk well locations of which 115 are in Carnes and 115 Catarina. The Carnes area which is currently by current well being online for some 7 months could add an additional 30 million-barrel equivalent of sources to our Eagle Ford Shale business. 
In Canada, our Montney asset continues to produce above plan. We averaged 207 million a day there for the quarter. LOE was $0.26 per Mcf, a 32% reduction quarter-over-quarter. No new wells brought online in this quarter, but we plan to complete 4 wells in the second quarter, targeting 15 to 18 Bcf EUR in those wells. 
We closed the sale of our Montney natural gas processing plants early in second quarter. After incurring a new tariff associated with sale, we can expect well breakeven process for a 10% rate of return to be approximately USD 1.65 AECO at a ForEx conversion of 0.79. This significant go LOE, along with our greatly reduced drilling and completion costs and higher EUR wells, enable us to easily manage the new tariff and take advantage of the -- and took advantage of the monetization by deploying proceeds to higher return assets. 
In offshore Malaysia business, we produced over 58,000-barrel equivalents per day during the quarter, and we continued with our Sarawak development during the South access and are on track for a July installation of a new producing facility for that field. 
The [indiscernible] first quarter production averaged over 142,000 gross, with peak production 157,000 gross in that field. The field is simply incredible. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the first quarter 2016 is approximately 19,200-barrel equivalents per day, 80% liquids. Kodiak well initially came online at planned rates during the first quarter, it was taken off-line as we experienced surface facilities issues. Those modifications are complete, and the well should be flowing very near term. 
In the month of April, we drilled 2 exploration commitment wells, 1 in Malaysia and 1 in Vietnam and Malaysia. [indiscernible] number 1 offsetting our South access field, and our noncommercial natural gas accumulations plugged and abandoned. Vietnam, cc 1x well in Block 11-2 found oil paint in the well but it's not commercial for planned sidetrack, and we also plugged that well. These are both shallow water low-cost opportunities and, together, will result in a total expense of near $15 million for this second quarter. 
There are exploration wells planned for this year as a result of our reduced capital plan. We continue to progress our farming agreement with PetroVietnam for the 15-1 LDD field in the Cuu Long Basin, where we have got a successful well test last year. 
We continue working to protect our balance sheet. End of the first quarter, we have $1.1 billion of availability in our revolver, with $925 million drawn. We have $569 million of cash in our corporation, which does not include the proceeds from our midstream monetization of some CAD 538 million from earlier in the second quarter. Our long-term debt to total capitalization is just under 40% at the end of first quarter, well below our sole revolver covenant of 60%. 
Takeaways today. We continue to operate at a high level in terms of drilling and completion improvements and cost reductions, as demonstrated in the first quarter results. We continue to focus on our shareholders with no issuance of equity and a price collapse, look to further strengthen our balance sheet. We significantly reduced our 2016 capital plan to $580 million while maintaining our annual guidance of 180,000 to 185,000 equivalents per day. Our key plays continue performing well, especially in North America and unconventional assets as well as our Malaysian assets. Our portfolio is under continuous review as we remain true to our strategy to focusing North American unconventional resources while maintaining our global offshore presence. We are working to reserve our balance sheet, as evidenced by monetizing non-core assets in the Montney midstream, progression of the joint venture closing in the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids-rich Montney area and the recent signing of a purchase sale agreement to monetize our Syncrude position. 
It's all I have and I like to open up the phone lines for questions now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I mean we have a lot of recalibration going on in Murphy right now because we're selling an asset that's a 13,000, 14,000-barrel a day type number, fairly flat. We reposition ourselves into a new unconventional position once closed. We are v
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. I mean we have a lot of recalibration going on in Murphy right now because we're selling an asset that's a 13,000, 14,000-barrel a day type number, fairly flat. We reposition ourselves into a new unconventional position once closed. We are very, very pleased about that. So we have a lot of comings and goings, Paul, so that right now. And if we look out in the fourth quarter, 1 75, 1 74 kind of a fourth quarter number for us. And take away Syncrude and add in the new unconventional project in Duvernay Shale, we get ourselves into the 1 60s range, and I believe we can modestly grow that to with some high 40s next year and kind of get back on the growth plan there. But our focus is trying to get back to cash flow CapEx parity with all certainty, not necessarily looking to grow production but to have the right types of returns and capital allocation among our enhancements in unconventionals that we are looking to do. And really, the way we can have some growth there again going to be a matter of what we want to do to get there. And kind of pleased with that recalibration, but it's going to take some time to get our sales back organized to recover the sale of the Syncrude barrel, if you follow me there.
