componenttext: Total debt or debt to EBITDA or any ratio of debt that you were targeting that at least that we would be able to put into our model. Not necessarily say for tomorrow but that on a longer-term basis that where you want to reach over the next 1 or 2 years?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I mean we were a top quartile EBITDA multiple debt player in October. And when oil prices are higher -- different time, oil price collapsed a lot, since then building back now, and I would like that multiple in the 3 range, low 3s. And we never want
componenttext: Paul, I mean we were a top quartile EBITDA multiple debt player in October. And when oil prices are higher -- different time, oil price collapsed a lot, since then building back now, and I would like that multiple in the 3 range, low 3s. And we never want our debt to cap to be above where it is today, if we can do something about that. And that's a personal type of number for me. Doesn't mean every day you're exactly on that number, but that's kind of goals John and I talk about.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, John, on the U.S., I was a little bit surprised that your unit DD&A in the first quarter didn't drop from the fourth quarter level given you booked additional reserve and you're not bringing on really that many new wells in the shale. Is t
componenttext: Okay. And then, John, on the U.S., I was a little bit surprised that your unit DD&A in the first quarter didn't drop from the fourth quarter level given you booked additional reserve and you're not bringing on really that many new wells in the shale. Is there any particular reason that the unit DD&A may actually be up?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I'm looking at it here.
componenttext: Paul, I'm looking at it here.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll have Kelly follow-up. Paul, we drilled some wells there. We probably have a very small pud debooking in Eagle Ford last year. But our overall reserves there were very positive. And DD&A is at our plan and wasn't planned to be reduced. You got to kee
componenttext: We'll have Kelly follow-up. Paul, we drilled some wells there. We probably have a very small pud debooking in Eagle Ford last year. But our overall reserves there were very positive. And DD&A is at our plan and wasn't planned to be reduced. You got to keep in mind that on impairments, we didn't have any in our onshore business and unconventionals, and it's probably -- primarily been an issue in the offshore where DD&A is significantly lower. But onshore, DD&A for the Eagle Ford Shale is exactly on the plan we've had for a long time as we add costs. You got to keep in mind, we added 138 completed wells there last year. Enormously higher CapEx. And if you're adding costs and reserves at the same pace then the DD&A rate should be the same.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Final question, Roger, with the headcount reduction and all that, based on your current organizational capability, if you're not adding people, how many wells -- how many rigs that you can actually run or handle? Let's say if the economic is available in
componenttext: Final question, Roger, with the headcount reduction and all that, based on your current organizational capability, if you're not adding people, how many wells -- how many rigs that you can actually run or handle? Let's say if the economic is available in U.S. and Canada.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We can easily go to 3, 4 rigs, Paul. I do not see that as an issue. We have capable drilling and completion people and both employed in our offshore and onshore assets between Calgary and Houston. And we've kind of recalibrated the size of our company and
componenttext: We can easily go to 3, 4 rigs, Paul. I do not see that as an issue. We have capable drilling and completion people and both employed in our offshore and onshore assets between Calgary and Houston. And we've kind of recalibrated the size of our company and looked at it very, very closely around our G&A to drive that to a better quartile improvement. And that is not my concern. It's getting back to work if needed from a G&A perspective. I've been through these people say 9x in my career and wouldn't always get back to work and we're organized to be able to do that, and that's not an issue for me.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Roger, when you say 3 to 4 rigs there, is 3 to 4 rigs in U.S., 3 to 4 rigs in Canada, right.
componenttext: So Roger, when you say 3 to 4 rigs there, is 3 to 4 rigs in U.S., 3 to 4 rigs in Canada, right.

componenttext: No, I would say that would be in North America, Paul.

componenttext: North America, 3 to 4 rigs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Between Canada and the Eagle Ford together, 4 rigs to say that won't be a problem. That's not -- I can handle that problem, Paul, whenever we get to that, believe me.
componenttext: Between Canada and the Eagle Ford together, 4 rigs to say that won't be a problem. That's not -- I can handle that problem, Paul, whenever we get to that, believe me.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Guy Baber from Simmons.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Guy Baber from Simmons.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, I had a capital allocation question for you. But as you ramp down your capital spending, the dividend now has obviously become sizable relative to your CapEx. So the question is, how you think about laying the potential for incremental gross spendi
componenttext: Roger, I had a capital allocation question for you. But as you ramp down your capital spending, the dividend now has obviously become sizable relative to your CapEx. So the question is, how you think about laying the potential for incremental gross spending to help arrest declines or allocate capital to attractive places like Montney and Kaybob Duvernay versus continuing to pay out that same dividend at the same level? How do you think about the relative ranking of capital deployment between those 2 options right now?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean the dividend policy at Murphy is a long-term policy and oil price have been a short-term change. Oil price up even $10 since the last time we had a call. That's well over 200 something million in cash flow for Murphy. Our dividend here is und
componenttext: Well, I mean the dividend policy at Murphy is a long-term policy and oil price have been a short-term change. Oil price up even $10 since the last time we had a call. That's well over 200 something million in cash flow for Murphy. Our dividend here is under closer review than it has been before. Will be under meeting in August. And really, you're going to do that quarter-by-quarter. We paid 2 of the dividends at the full price here. And it is important of a capital allocation as it is for other things. And we continue to see well cost come down, we're able to execute more wells with less costs. We're able to do this at both Montney and Eagle Ford. And I think we are still on such a recalibration mode of our cash flows with all of the ins and outs of our business, this will be something really for the fall and we're going to be focusing on this production and cash flow and where we allocate capital and we'll be kicking that can down the road to the fall time, to be honest with you, Guy.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then the capital spending for the quarter, it looked like it was pretty much in line with the annual guidance. But we had actually expected that to be trending lower through the year as you ramp down some of your rig activities. So it loo
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then the capital spending for the quarter, it looked like it was pretty much in line with the annual guidance. But we had actually expected that to be trending lower through the year as you ramp down some of your rig activities. So it looked like the CapEx was lower than what we had anticipated. Are you operating more efficiently and does the CapEx look like it could be coming in lower than what the internal plan has been. Anything you can share on that front?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would imagine today if one of our financial outlook books that we produce here at Murphy we find our capital probably $30 million less than our 5 80 today. And it will be a matter of do we want to add some wells for the savings in a place like in Eagle
componenttext: I would imagine today if one of our financial outlook books that we produce here at Murphy we find our capital probably $30 million less than our 5 80 today. And it will be a matter of do we want to add some wells for the savings in a place like in Eagle Ford. But our capital is really on schedule almost x4 equal. And then we have -- well a few minutes ago we rattled off some wells in the Eagle Ford. We'll have wells in the Montney, too. And then we have opportunities -- our jackup rig in Malaysia is farmed out to another party, and it will be coming back. And we're installing a jacket there. And when CapEx gets at that level, small things can change it. But I'm very pleased with the idea that we are not overspending or front-loading our CapEx, because our CapEx is a very real item that we are focused on here. And we are not front-loading it with the idea that we're going to increase it. We just got our CapEx set at these levels. Happy with how it's going. Happy with the efficiency, the cost reductions and continue on with that regime at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then last one for me, the cost performance this quarter, obviously, very impressive with the lowest per barrel cost in a number of years. To what extent is the performance that you delivered this quarter is that sustainable? Were there any onetime ben
componenttext: And then last one for me, the cost performance this quarter, obviously, very impressive with the lowest per barrel cost in a number of years. To what extent is the performance that you delivered this quarter is that sustainable? Were there any onetime benefits? I know you ran very well during the quarter. But is that sustainable? And then also, in an improving oil price environment, to what extent do you think these are structural cost improvements that you've captured?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say we have some downtime events this quarter, as I went through in my remarks. It doesn't lead to lower OpEx, as you would imagine. We had a very, very good OpEx in 7 50 range. And we are trending to get back to where we were last year arou
componenttext: Well, I would say we have some downtime events this quarter, as I went through in my remarks. It doesn't lead to lower OpEx, as you would imagine. We had a very, very good OpEx in 7 50 range. And we are trending to get back to where we were last year around a $9 range. But in our internal planning, we were $1 under our very aggressive budget. So my folks, the handler upstream business are doing a very good job, our procurement, the cost of services continue to improve and the focus in the proper allocation of those costs, but we didn't not have a special item this quarter that drove that. So I continue to be positively surprised on OpEx by my team. It's a big focus that we have. And while I say that we manned up over at the end of the year with declining production, which we talked about here today, at the same level, I've been greatly surprised and very pleased with how OpEx is going here. As to the service side, you would anticipate that to run out of room there, but it continues to be positive, reinforced procurement and aggressive bidding of services. And each time we have procurement, we continue to have small gains in procurement of bidding to companies that are maintaining their market share of business. So I continue to be positively surprised. I got a great team focused on it, and I think we're doing a great job there and I'm really happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Kyle Rhodes from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Kyle Rhodes from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one for me. Any update you can provide on Block H FLNG program, just maybe in terms of expectations for first gas? I mean, what's your future capital outlays are for that project in 2017 and 2018?
componenttext: Just one for me. Any update you can provide on Block H FLNG program, just maybe in terms of expectations for first gas? I mean, what's your future capital outlays are for that project in 2017 and 2018?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are going to have over $100 million there and probably some more into '18 on the subsurface side of the fields, incredibly successful for us. Many successful wells in a row. Great gas project there. Very similar in rates to our SK Gas. Petronas has sta
componenttext: We are going to have over $100 million there and probably some more into '18 on the subsurface side of the fields, incredibly successful for us. Many successful wells in a row. Great gas project there. Very similar in rates to our SK Gas. Petronas has started this vessel. They're supplying floating LNG vessels in Korea. It is partially built, and they're trying to slow that project down because these are tied to Brent prices but work -- as project works well and Brent's around $50. They have come -- we have a gas agreement with them, they've come to us about pushing the first gas to that into 2020, in which they would have the expense of changing the capital spend with the vessel in the Korean shipyard, if you will. And we are agreeable to that, and it would give us more capital for next year to use in our other high-returning assets like Eagle Ford Shale or in Duvernay shale. And so we pushed out that production to 2020. And that's fine with me at this time. It'll be another long-term LNG asset with one of the great LNG partners in the world, and it is going to work out for us down the road there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So less than $100 million in '17 spend, then any idea kind of just what the full development costs are?
componenttext: Got it. So less than $100 million in '17 spend, then any idea kind of just what the full development costs are?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that right in front of me. I apologize. Kelly can get that for you. But that hasn't changed I would say the costs are lower because I anticipate deep water rigs to be lower. And the well, it may not be by 2019, but I imagine they will. And ou
componenttext: I don't have that right in front of me. I apologize. Kelly can get that for you. But that hasn't changed I would say the costs are lower because I anticipate deep water rigs to be lower. And the well, it may not be by 2019, but I imagine they will. And our services there, we're in a great situation in costs. But our large partner there would like to push it to the right. I'd like to save the $100 million right now. And I'm very pleased with the adjustment when we get organized with Petronas.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- I know you guys have been very successful in reducing CapEx. I'm just trying to understand the full year production guidance following that reduction. I know there's steep declines in 2Q, in your 2Q guidance. What operationally flattens those decl
componenttext: Just -- I know you guys have been very successful in reducing CapEx. I'm just trying to understand the full year production guidance following that reduction. I know there's steep declines in 2Q, in your 2Q guidance. What operationally flattens those declines out in the second half? Is that just a return from maintenance activity that you mentioned?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. I mean, I mean, we are looking at production in Canada in the third quarter, second quarter actually going up as we have some more Montney production there, slightly more. Had enormous pile on of downtime in the second quarter we knew a
componenttext: Yes, that's right. I mean, I mean, we are looking at production in Canada in the third quarter, second quarter actually going up as we have some more Montney production there, slightly more. Had enormous pile on of downtime in the second quarter we knew about. We also have some downtime planned in our business for Kikeh, which is very rarely shut down. And our Block K area has been, I guess, 10 years since that facility stopped. And the Eagle Ford Shale is just a less well count. Decline in the Gulf of Mexico, basically flat. So quarter 2 to quarter 3 would primarily be around just a lack of investment in Eagle Ford Shale. And after that, it would be very flat if it were not for that issue. So I think it's a big downtime in the second quarter. But let's keep in mind that all along our external guidance is the same, and we had a capital spend that was very low. And we came into the year with many wells on the Eagle Ford Shale being completed in December. And now, we are at that same guidance. So nothing has really changed on that regard.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my second question, I guess, following up on the capital allocation question, but what's the -- is regaining your investment-grade rating a key priority in the recovery? And with that would you expect that would drive running your business free
componenttext: Great. And my second question, I guess, following up on the capital allocation question, but what's the -- is regaining your investment-grade rating a key priority in the recovery? And with that would you expect that would drive running your business free cash flow positive into an early portion of a recovery?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The investment-grade thing is a couple of months ago. We moved onto all these assets ins and outs. We've been fairly active in our company changing our portfolio. We want -- I want to get my own targets on debt and continue to defend our position there. A
componenttext: The investment-grade thing is a couple of months ago. We moved onto all these assets ins and outs. We've been fairly active in our company changing our portfolio. We want -- I want to get my own targets on debt and continue to defend our position there. And it's not we get up every day and say, let's get back to investment-grade again. I think the multiples of EBITDA and a limit on debt to cap and working inside cash flow CapEx parity, we continue to illustrate that. Then we'll move back up to investment-grade line again, we're still investment-grade with S&P. So I don't get up every morning focusing on Moody's, but we're going to try to do the right thing, work on these -- being the leader in some of these multiples, and it will work out over time for us.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So free cash flow parity is how we should think about you in terms of the future reinvestment when the commodity price recovers, I guess?
componenttext: So free cash flow parity is how we should think about you in terms of the future reinvestment when the commodity price recovers, I guess?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Sean Sneeden from Oppenheimer. We can take our next question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Sean Sneeden from Oppenheimer. We can take our next question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a couple of questions with regards to decline rates. You mentioned in your comments you've been surprised by a more modest decline coming I think out of the Eagle Ford since you stopped adding new wells. And a wondered if that is just the na
componenttext: Wanted to ask a couple of questions with regards to decline rates. You mentioned in your comments you've been surprised by a more modest decline coming I think out of the Eagle Ford since you stopped adding new wells. And a wondered if that is just the natural decline or whether you're doing anything specifically to try to mitigate that, that has been the source of the better performance?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is a lot of focus on when to put in artificial lift and stay inside our operating expense and cash projections, Brian. There's these rigs we hire to optimize when you put on artificial lift, how you set up the artificial lift. And when things get ve
componenttext: There is a lot of focus on when to put in artificial lift and stay inside our operating expense and cash projections, Brian. There's these rigs we hire to optimize when you put on artificial lift, how you set up the artificial lift. And when things get very difficult and you're cutting your budget, people move from focusing on growth to enhancing the base. And we've been very happy with how our teams have performed as to that total focus on what wells are down, why are they down, and how you improve the artificial lift timing. And that's been the source of their success there, in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could ask a very similar question in Malaysia also, without speaking to the ups and downs of maintenance in various places, can you just talk to what your natural oil decline rates are and then anything that you can do either in terms in a Brownfield
componenttext: If I could ask a very similar question in Malaysia also, without speaking to the ups and downs of maintenance in various places, can you just talk to what your natural oil decline rates are and then anything that you can do either in terms in a Brownfield type legacy type drilling here and there? Or decline mitigations?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think of Malaysia as probably a less than 20% decline, it can be as low as 15%. A lot of these projects are supported by water injection. And we're very constant production of gas. They're on a BOE basis, Brian, you would have been in that business of
componenttext: We think of Malaysia as probably a less than 20% decline, it can be as low as 15%. A lot of these projects are supported by water injection. And we're very constant production of gas. They're on a BOE basis, Brian, you would have been in that business of gas there for a long time. When things are running appropriately, we have at least 250 million gross that we operate into a  Petronas LNG plant. So that's a pretty constant production. It only is up and down with LNG. So that one is fairly constant. Also still cash flow providing field for us at 3 60 type dollar per Mcf. And the rest of the fields, this Kakap-Gumusut where we have 8%, is a very, very successful field, limited decline in its own plateau. And you roll all that together and just not an enormous decline rate coming out of there, primarily at this time related to these uptown -- these downtime events that I described.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one from me. Looking at the possibility that you would resume exploration in 2017 or subsequent to that, other than Vietnam, which you just entered a few months ago, what other geographies might you consider getting back into exploration?
componenttext: Just one from me. Looking at the possibility that you would resume exploration in 2017 or subsequent to that, other than Vietnam, which you just entered a few months ago, what other geographies might you consider getting back into exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, at this time, we have a very nice acreage position in the Vulcan basin North of Australia, and we're trying to focus until the cost structure and the deepwater rigs of the Gulf get more organized. We're not focusing there right now. Vulcan basin Aus
componenttext: Well, at this time, we have a very nice acreage position in the Vulcan basin North of Australia, and we're trying to focus until the cost structure and the deepwater rigs of the Gulf get more organized. We're not focusing there right now. Vulcan basin Australia is a very underexplored place, where we have a very large new seismic data set, and we are onto a new play there with some hundred million barrel type opportunities and very inexpensive to drill. That would be one focus area. We have a partner there, Mitsui, we're 60-40 with them. We also, as you know, in The Great Australian Bight, we have the Ceduna Basin, where we have enormous acreage position with all of our seismic acquired and reprocessed. And we're setting next to BP and Statoil and also Chevron, it will be drilling upwards 6 to 8 wells over the next couple of years. This is a prolific basin, the size of the North Sea and one of the largest left undrilled basins in the world, where we have a position to be able to watch them drill. And those are our focus areas in Vietnam, it's Cuu Long Basin, and we have to think of Vietnam as a place similar to Malaysia, where we started with shallow water blocks. We also have ultra-deepwater blocks. And that entry in that long-term relationship allowed us to enter into the Cuu Long Basin, where we are working with them to add some additional acreage, and we formed into a very successful project there and have to look at Vietnam holistically because the Cuu Long Basin is the prize there. And those are areas today. We're also interested in Mexico bid round because they will not have the higher cost issues placed on the Gulf of Mexico by this administration. I think that's positive. Also of note in the exploration world today, seismic is very inexpensive. Massive seismic availability for inside our budget here. We're not looking to increase our budget in any way, especially in that. But can get lots of data today and build that positions again if needed in this low environment.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: I'll let John speak to it, but it is a blend and extend type thing that we would prefer, an option we prefer. And we believe our Syncrude situation and the cash that we have on our balance sheet, just in general, from an asset perspective, is helping that. And also our lower capital spending hitting our targets and oil price recovery, I think, things are leading to a positive in nature in that, in my view. I sensed a sentiment of improvement in that business over the last 6 weeks.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of more positive action going on in the marketplace, Sean. And we are -- our goal is to extend. We're talking to our bankers about it, probably consider having to adjust our $2 billion somewhat in terms of the maximum size. And we'd like to
componenttext: There's a lot of more positive action going on in the marketplace, Sean. And we are -- our goal is to extend. We're talking to our bankers about it, probably consider having to adjust our $2 billion somewhat in terms of the maximum size. And we'd like to keep it unsecured, obviously. And so we are working toward that as well. So we'll -- it's all in the works, all being discussed and negotiations to proceed over time. And we're confident we can get the thing extended at a reasonable size and a reasonable manner in terms of security and such.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a little bit about the decision to suspend completion activity in the Eagle Ford. Broadly, at a higher level, you guys are shifting towards more of a North America and unconventional focus. A little bit surprised given the quality of y
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a little bit about the decision to suspend completion activity in the Eagle Ford. Broadly, at a higher level, you guys are shifting towards more of a North America and unconventional focus. A little bit surprised given the quality of your Eagle Ford acreage and the core that you would suspend activity or at least the completion activity. I was wondering if you can help us think about that. And what oil price do you think you need, Roger, where you think your U.S. onshore business could deliver value to the drill bit?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it's -- all of our hopefully new to be signed Duvernay shale and our Eagle Ford can deliver 10% rates of return in the low 30s and we're ahead of that now. We, at Murphy, set out earlier in the year and the price collapsed to organize our ca
componenttext: Well, I mean, it's -- all of our hopefully new to be signed Duvernay shale and our Eagle Ford can deliver 10% rates of return in the low 30s and we're ahead of that now. We, at Murphy, set out earlier in the year and the price collapsed to organize our capital around the lowest capital we could have, and then recalibrated our company because in and around that I knew of asset sales and different things we're doing. We're not a company that goes out saying we're selling all these assets and doing that, but we had a lot going on to accomplish all these purchase and sale agreements that you read about in the press. So in and around that, we're trying to get to a minimum capital spend, recalibrate our company. Once we have the closing, and we have a revolver to redo, a recalibration of our company, a focus out of non-core in North America into unconventionals, all of that takes time. And so we went into over the low CapEx. So we're going to Eagle Ford and we have continuous drilling obligations and we moved our rig around for that. And then from that, we are not a company to bill that drill in uncompleted wells and we have a low level CapEx to meet all these other goals of recalibration I spoke of. And that led to that schedule. And that schedule has on been around since around mid-February, and I'm not interested in probably breaking it back up and open it back up to capital parade on May 5, whatever today is. So that's how we are thinking about that. It was derived on purpose from a lowest commitment basis. And we are focusing on cost in that, and we will come out of this and we are confident of an oil price recovery. Unlike any operator, oil gets into the 50s things change a lot. And we'll have to then allocate capital among that and offshore opportunities and move forward. But today; we are looking at it, more conservative view of that at Murphy Oil Corp.

componenttext: That's a really good well. The key thing in the business is subsurface, you have to have subsurface. The well flow, has ability to  flow over 10,000 barrels a day from single well, that's the beauty of offshore, that's why offshore still works. And the well had a choke manufacturing issue on the surface involving some products that were built into the choke that had to be changed with special order type equipment. We had to get involved with the operator and get that turned around and fixed. And it's nothing wrong with the well. It's going to flow at a higher oil price today, so it's fine.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We work on about everything, but I have to tell you, I'm not aware of it. I wouldn't be surprised. But I will say this about unconventionals, this continued improvement by everyone and you look at all these press releases you will see Murphy executing and
componenttext:
We work on about everything, but I have to tell you, I'm not aware of it. I wouldn't be surprised. But I will say this about unconventionals, this continued improvement by everyone and you look at all these press releases you will see Murphy executing and performing at or above everybody else. That's not uncommon. But I know that in my view, with our big service providers looking to merge, and now they're not going to merge, with focus on less capital spending, I believe the technological issues in unconventionals have gone on the sideline for this year. And I believe that we're missing -- we could miss some efficiency as you go to less pad drilling and some efficiency on experimentation of capital that I think was driving a lot of the unconventional improvement, which will lead to lower U.S. oil production and an oil price recovery. But if you have just a few wells and everyone is reducing their CapEx, not just Murphy, there will be less experimentation of capital if you will, in my view.
That's all we have today. That would be the end of our call. I appreciate everyone calling in. And we'll talk to you next time we have a quarterly release. And I appreciate it. Thank you.

componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the inf
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you can follow along with the webcast today. John will begin by providing a review of first quarter financial results, highlighting our strong balance sheet and liquidity position following our most recently announced divestitures. Roger will then follow with an operational update and outlook, after which questions will be taken. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2015 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the first quarter of 2016 were a loss of $198.8 million, which is $1.16 per diluted share, and that compares to a loss of $14.4 million or $0.08 per diluted share a
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the first quarter of 2016 were a loss of $198.8 million, which is $1.16 per diluted share, and that compares to a loss of $14.4 million or $0.08 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding our discontinued operations, our continuing operations had a loss of $199.5 million, again $1.16, versus a profit in the first quarter of 2015 of $3.5 million, which was $0.02 per diluted share. 
The first quarter results from continuing operations for 2016 included noncash property impairments of $95.1 million, which after tax has amounted to $68.9 million charge. These impairments were primarily attributable to declines in future periods oil prices as of quarter end March and the impairments related to both Terra Nova and Seal properties in Canada. 
The just completed quarter also included an after-tax expense of $6.2 million to reflect restructuring costs by the company. The 2015 first quarter a year ago benefited from a $199.5 million after-tax gain on the sale of 10% of our Malaysian assets, which closed in January 2015. 
Adjusted earnings, which adjusts our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of results between periods was a loss of $112.8 million in the first quarter 2016, an improvement from the adjusted net loss of $198.5 million a year ago. This improvement in adjusted results in 2016 was primarily attributable to lower exploration expenses, partially offset by significantly lower oil and natural gas sales prices compared to a year ago. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
The company's average realized price for its crude oil production was $34.19 per barrel sold, which was almost $13 per barrel lower, 27% in the first quarter of 2016 compared to the prior year. 
Natural gas prices also were weaker in the first quarter compared to the prior year's quarter average North American gas price realizations of $1.57 per 1,000 cubic feet dropped $0.89 per Mcf or a decline of 36%. Realized oil index natural gas prices offshore Sarawak fell 18% to an average of $3.67 per Mcf following the decline in global crude oil prices. 
The company's cash flow from continuing operations for the first 3 months of 2016 was burdened by deepwater rig contract exit payments of $253.2 million. The income statement charge associated with these deepwater rig exits was recorded in the fourth quarter of 2015. 
For the second quarter 2016, the company has WTI-based oil price hedges for 20,000 barrels per day at a WTI average price of $52.01. For the last 6 months of 2016, the company has entered into an additional 5,000 barrels per day hedge at $45.30 per barrel or a blended average WTI price of $50.67 covering 25,000 barrels per day for the last 6 months of 2016. 
Additionally, the company has forward sales contracts for Canadian natural gas in the amount of 59 million cubic feet a day at an average AECO price of CAD 3.19 per thousand cubic feet on the remaining 9 months of 2016. 
At quarter end March 31, 2016, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to $3.4 billion, 39.6% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to 35.5%. 
As of quarter end, we had $971 million of combined borrowings under our $2 billion revolver and uncommitted credit facilities. We also had a total of cash and invested cash of about $569 million worldwide. The closing of the Montney midstream asset sale for CAD 538 million on April 1 added to our cash position early in the second quarter. And the future completion of the recently announced Syncrude sale will also add to our cash position. 
Murphy's sole debt covenant at the present time is a total debt to capital ratio of 60%. 
Thank you, and that concludes my comments. And I'll pass it over to Roger at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for listening on our call today. Looking back at the first quarter, the following highlights stand out. We produced 196,600 barrel equivalents. We were able to exceed our quarterly guidance with hig
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for listening on our call today. Looking back at the first quarter, the following highlights stand out. We produced 196,600 barrel equivalents. We were able to exceed our quarterly guidance with high level of execution. We experienced close to 0 planned downtime or maintenance across our diversified production base and higher field performance in many of our key fields. 
From a safety standpoint, we had 0 recordable incidents across our entire company during the quarter, which is a remarkable feat for our operating team. 
We remain laser focused on reducing cost across our business. During the quarter, we reduced our 2016 annual capital of $580 million from the previously announced $825 million plan and, most importantly, after a 73% reduction from our 2015 capital spend of $2.2 billion. 
We also reduced lease operating expenses, excluding Syncrude, by 22% quarter-over-quarter. 
Also we continue to reposition our portfolio, including closing the previously announced noncore asset sale of our Montney midstream assets as well as recently signing a purchase sale agreement to divest 5% nonoperated working interest at Syncrude. We are working diligently to close our previously announced joint venture focused on expanding our footprint in the North American onshore unconventional business in the Kaybob Duvernay and liquid-rich Montney areas in Canada. We'll continue to review our portfolio and we'll act when opportunities present themselves.
I'm pleased with the ongoing efforts our team is making on cost reductions. Our lease operating expenses in quarter 1, excluding Syncrude, of $7.50 per BOE shown a reduction some 22% from the first quarter of '15 and a reduction of 9% from the fourth quarter last year. As a result of our decreased activities following oil commodity prices and implemented a companywide workforce reduction, lowering our staffing levels by about 20% in 2016. 
We've been able to lower our G&A cost excluding restructuring charges approximately 26% quarter-over-quarter. 
The capital program for 2016 being maintained as I previously said at $580 million while maintaining our production guidance range of 180,000 to 185,000-barrel equivalents per day. Our first quarter spending is roughly 25% of our annual CapEx, which is on our plan. Our annual and quarter capital and production plans have not yet been adjusted for pending asset divestment and assets should be acquired. Updating for production in capital spending will be released on the closing of these transactions. Production for the second quarter 2016 is estimated to be in the range of 177,000 to 180,000-barrel equivalents per day.
Looking at production. As I said, we produced 196,600 equivalents per day, exceeding guidance. The stronger-than-forecasted first quarter volumes were primarily due to higher production from Eagle Ford Shale, higher natural gas production from the Montney, higher oil production from both offshore Sabah, Malaysia and offshore Canada. And these increases were partially offset by delays in bringing on our Kodiak subsea well in the Gulf of Mexico as well as increased downtime in Sarawak and Kikeh involved in our natural gas production in that area. It's important to note that our second quarter production guidance of 177,000 to 180,000 compared to first quarter's negatively impacted a planned downtime and maintenance across many of our assets, including 10 days at Sarawak natural gas, the Kakap-Gumusut subsea well, 2 subsea wells shut in for 21 days in offshore Malaysia and Terra Nova they're  working on 28-day turnaround, and we are part of the long term 45-day turnaround at Syncrude, which is ongoing. The current guidance is based on Syncrude producing at reduced rates until the planned turnaround is complete over the next 2 weeks. However, we've not updated forecast with the recent news of wildfires in this area. Our thoughts go to this place's residents in the Fort McMurray area. 
Plus our Eagle Ford Shale will have natural production decline this quarter as we have no new wells planned to be added in that field.
In onshore business, Eagle Ford Shale continues to perform well where we average near 56,000-barrel equivalents a day for the quarter, where we delivered 13 new wells online, bringing our total operated well count to over 660. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, first quarter operating expense is just under $8, a 6% reduction from the fourth quarter 2015. We continue making strides in increasing drilling and completion costs as we average 4.1 million per well, which is 26% below first quarter 2015. We drilled a Pacesetter Well in only 6 days from spud to rig release in our Catarina area. It's important to note that our strategy to work inside a lower-for-longer commodity price regime, with our much lower capital spend in 2016 will lead to bringing on 28 new wells and drilling 25 wells in the Eagle Ford. This is well below the 136 operated wells we brought online in 2015. We still have significant running room ahead of us here, with over 2,000 potential Eagle Ford Shale locations and reserves of oil weighted at roughly 90%. The asset is very meaningful to Murphy's future reserves production cash flow.
Last year, we drilled our first Austin Chalk well, in Karnes County. We continue to be pleased with the well's performance and just recently we spud another Austin Chalk well in Catarina area, testing most Western part of our acreage. We have an Austin Chalk well standing  in Karnes area, which will be completed later this year. We estimate we have approximately 265 Austin Chalk well locations of which 115 are in Karnes and 115 Catarina. The Karnes area, which is currently de-risked by current well being online for some 7 months, could add an additional 30 million-barrel equivalents of resources to our Eagle Ford Shale business. 
In Canada, our Montney asset continues to produce above plan. We average 207 million a day there for the quarter. LOE was $0.26 per Mcf, a 32% reduction quarter-over-quarter, but no new wells brought online in this quarter, but we plan to complete 4 wells in the second quarter, targeting 15 to 18 Bcf EUR in those wells. 
We closed the sale of our Montney natural gas processing plants early in the second quarter after incurring the new tariff associated with sale, we can expect well breakeven process for a 10% rate of return to be approximately USD 1.65 AECO at a ForEx conversion of 0.79. This significantly lower LOE, along with our greatly reduced drilling and completion costs and higher EUR wells, enable us to easily manage the new tariff and take advantage of the -- and we took advantage of the monetization by deploying proceeds into higher returning assets. 
In our offshore Malaysia business, we produced over 58,000-barrel equivalents per day during the quarter, we continued with our Sarawak development drilling in the South access and are on track for a July installation of a new producing facility for that field. 
The Kakap-Gumusut  first quarter production averaged over 142,000 gross, with peak production nearing 157,000 gross in that field. That field is simply incredible. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the first quarter 2016 is approximately 19,200-barrel equivalents per day, 80% liquids. Kodiak well initially came online at planned rates during the first quarter, it was taken off-line as we experienced surface facility issues. Those modifications are complete, and the well should be flowing very near term. 
In the month of April, we drilled 2 exploration commitment wells, 1 in Malaysia and 1 in Vietnam. In Malaysia, [indiscernible] 1 offsetting our South access field, and our noncommercial natural gas accumulations plugged and abandoned. In Vietnam, the CC-1x well in Block 11-2 found oil play in the well but it was not commercial for planned sidetrack, and we also plugged that well. These are both shallow water low-cost opportunities and, together, will result in a total expense of near $15 million for this second quarter. 
There are no exploration wells planned for this year as a result of our reduced capital plan. We continue to progress our farming agreement with PetroVietnam for the 15-1 LDD field in the Cuu Long Basin, where we had a successful well test last year. 
We continue working to protect our balance sheet. End of the first quarter, we have $1.1 billion of availability under our revolver, with $925 million drawn. We have $569 million of cash in our corporation, which does not include the proceeds from our midstream monetization of some CAD 538 million from earlier in the second quarter. Our long-term debt to total capitalization is just under 40% at the end of first quarter, well below our sole revolver covenant of 60%. 
Takeaways today. We continue to operate at a high level in terms of drilling and completion improvements and cost reductions, as demonstrated in the first quarter results. We continue to focus on our shareholders with no issuance of equity and a price collapse, look to further strengthen our balance sheet. We significantly reduced our 2016 capital plan of $580 million while maintaining our annual guidance of 180,000 to 185,000 equivalents per day. Our key plays continue performing well, especially in North America unconventional assets as well as our Malaysian assets. Our portfolio is under continuous review as we remain true to our strategy of focusing on North American unconventional resources while maintaining our global offshore presence. We are working to preserve our balance sheet, as evidenced by monetizing non-core assets in the Montney midstream, progression of the joint venture closing in the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids-rich Montney area and the recent signing of a purchase sale agreement to monetize our Syncrude position. 
It's all I have and I'd like to open up our phone lines for questions now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I mean we have a lot of recalibration going on in Murphy right now because we're selling an asset that's a 13,000, 14,000-barrel a day type number, fairly flat. We reposition ourselves into a new unconventional position once closed. We are v
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. I mean we have a lot of recalibration going on in Murphy right now because we're selling an asset that's a 13,000, 14,000-barrel a day type number, fairly flat. We reposition ourselves into a new unconventional position once closed. We are very, very pleased about that. So we have a lot of comings and goings, Paul, as so that right now. And if we look out in the fourth quarter, 175, 174 kind of a fourth quarter number for us. And take away Syncrude and add in the new unconventional project in Duvernay Shale, we get ourselves into the 160s range, and I believe we can modestly grow that to with some high 40s next year and kind of get back on the growth plan there. But our focus is trying to get back to cash flow CapEx parity with all certainty, not necessarily looking to grow production but to have the right types of returns and capital allocation among our enhancements in unconventionals that we are looking to do. And really believe we can have some growth there again, but it would be a matter of what we want to do to get there. And kind of pleased with that recalibration, but it's going to take some time to get our sales back organized to recover the sale of the Syncrude barrel, if you follow me there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do. I understand that it's under sort of review at the moment or preview, but are we at a kind of a level that you think, is what you're saying that at the high 40s you believe you're now balanced for 2017 with basically flat volumes?

componenttext: That's what I kind of derived from your answer. And where, assuming oil prices recover, would you want Murphy to be in 3 year's time, Roger? Will we ever go back to deepwater exploration? Or do you see it now as very much an unconventional push for you guys?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We make near $100 million of cash flow, cash margin in Malaysia this month and near $100 million in Eagle Ford. Made a lot of money in the offshore business. We are seeing probably more review of discovered reserve opportunities where we bring our com
componenttext: No. We make near $100 million of cash flow, cash margin in Malaysia this month and near $100 million in Eagle Ford. Made a lot of money in the offshore business. We are seeing probably more review of discovered reserve opportunities where we bring our competitive advantage of executing wells, facilities. In the offshore, offshore is a little bit off the beaten path. I would say, today, probably not, if I get my 3 unconventionals organized between Duvernay Shale, Eagle Ford and Montney and probably not looking for a fourth there. And the future would be back to where we've delivered a lot of value, a lot of -- and there's such a cash flow shape of the curve so different between onshore and offshore, as you know, Paul, put a lot of money upfront in offshore and take in a lot of cash as we've done for years. Onshore machines need a lot of cash for a while. So that's the thought basis there. As far as exploration, I mean, there'll be opportunities. And a reduced capital plan, and even super majors have reduced explanations. So we would, too. And we have our thumb in a couple of nice places, and we'll see how that goes and look to do that another day. But this year, laying low and lowering our cost and keeping balance sheet as it is or improved is our focus today.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kicking into kind of looking at that production level in the 160s. Can you talk to us a little bit about decline rates, kind of what you've seen and then what you would expect as you look at I would think mostly your core Eagle Ford position but also acro
componenttext: Kicking into kind of looking at that production level in the 160s. Can you talk to us a little bit about decline rates, kind of what you've seen and then what you would expect as you look at I would think mostly your core Eagle Ford position but also across what you still have in Malaysia?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our offshore business is probably around, offshore Malaysia is probably a 13, 15 kind of number, and our Gulf is around a 20% number. Our Eagle Ford is very complex, Roger. It depends on adding wells and how many wells you're adding and the space between
componenttext: Our offshore business is probably around, offshore Malaysia is probably a 13, 15 kind of number, and our Gulf is around a 20% number. Our Eagle Ford is very complex, Roger. It depends on adding wells and how many wells you're adding and the space between them. It's probably in the 30s for a new well. And after a couple of years, that gets into 20s and then down into the 10s. So it's a complex machine there when you start and stop your completion program in these shale plays. And -- but we have a decline this quarter in Eagle Ford Shale, because we are adding new rigs. We actually haven't added a well since March now. So we're looking over 2 months without adding well. And I'm real pleased with how the production is looking there. And happy about how that's looking and was part of our success in the first quarter and real pleased about that. But the exact decline of a start and stop capital spend in a shale, I think is a pretty hard number to get at there, Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And along those lines, given the CapEx you got laid out, commitments across the board, how should we think about completion process, drilling and completion in the Eagle Ford as we go into the remainder of the year?
componenttext: And along those lines, given the CapEx you got laid out, commitments across the board, how should we think about completion process, drilling and completion in the Eagle Ford as we go into the remainder of the year?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Hang on one second, Roger, I have a schedule here, let me pound through it, they say these  microphones can hear every page you turn, so sorry about that. In the Eagle Ford, we're going to complete 3 wells in July and around 7 wells in August and 3 wells in September. And 4 wells in November. And we're going to drill a few wells between 2 to 4 wells a month between now and the end of the year.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basically taking care of the duck inventory is what that sounds like then?
componenttext: So basically taking care of the duck inventory is what that sounds like then?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it kind of sort of maintaining it, I think. We've never been --  I don't really use that word "duck" too often, it's not one of my favorite terms. We have some wells that have been completed in the low 30s right now. We've never been a big leader in
componenttext: Well, it kind of sort of maintaining it, I think. We've never been --  I don't really use that word "duck" too often, it's not one of my favorite terms. We have some wells that have been completed in the low 30s right now. We've never been a big leader in that parade, and we'll probably maintain it because we are completing about as many as we are drilling. And in that high 30s, we're not one of these hundreds of wells duckman as you like to say.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Ed Westlake from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Ed Westlake from Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I hope everyone is all right up in Canada. On the Duvernay transaction, obviously, appreciate, still very early there, but any updates in any of the wells that been drilled by the partner since you were last able to speak?
componenttext: I hope everyone is all right up in Canada. On the Duvernay transaction, obviously, appreciate, still very early there, but any updates in any of the wells that been drilled by the partner since you were last able to speak?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There hasn't been a lot of wells by our partner. We're working closely with our partner. This is a complex transaction to close because it involves 2 fields. Duvernay shale involves liquid-rich Montney, it involves a built-in infrastructure system tha
componenttext: No. There hasn't been a lot of wells by our partner. We're working closely with our partner. This is a complex transaction to close because it involves 2 fields. Duvernay shale involves liquid-rich Montney, it involves a built-in infrastructure system that they have a hyped interest in, there's ample room for us to enter. A lot of positive news by our peers in the play, especially the condensate area in which we have 33,000 acres there once we close this with our partner. And I would say, in Canada, we'd have more of the recent results there, doing very well in both operating and production. And very excited to get in there with that play and believe that we can jump start the learning curve with all our experience in Eagle Ford and Montney and get with our partner, who has a built-in position and be ready to execute there in short order.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then totally separate, the cash -- I mean obviously, you reckon you'll be raising cash through this year in Canada. Is there some sort of need to kind of, I guess, redistribute that somewhere else internationally as opposed to bring it back in the U.S
componenttext: And then totally separate, the cash -- I mean obviously, you reckon you'll be raising cash through this year in Canada. Is there some sort of need to kind of, I guess, redistribute that somewhere else internationally as opposed to bring it back in the U.S.? Maybe just talk about any drivers other than just the value of the cash on the balance sheet?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to have John answer that for me, if you don't mind.
componenttext: I'm going to have John answer that for me, if you don't mind.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, Ed. We are, as Roger said, nearing closing on the acquisition of Duvernay from another Canadian company. And the transaction, as you probably are aware, requires an acquisition payment of CAD 250 million subject to closing adjustments and also come
componenttext: Hello, Ed. We are, as Roger said, nearing closing on the acquisition of Duvernay from another Canadian company. And the transaction, as you probably are aware, requires an acquisition payment of CAD 250 million subject to closing adjustments and also comes with a commitment to carry our partner on certain future drillings. So we have commitments up in Canada. And the Syncrude, the good news about the Syncrude proceeds, should we get that transaction closed, is it gives us both investment allocation flexibility within our unconventional assets as well as financial flexibility by improving our balance sheet position. We will obviously have lower net debt positions post closing, which is represented by our debt less cash and invested cash. And so we'll have both the capability of capital allocation options and financial options in our favor once the Syncrude transaction closes. So we are in the process, and we will continue to evaluate our options. We'll be discussing this further in future periods when the Syncrude transaction closes. And I think that's really kind of what we want to say at this point in time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just if I could maybe probe a little further. The cash comes in from Syncrude later in the year. Oil prices go up. I mean, there's no imperative to drill under the Canadian leased structure. So it sounds like you get on the front foot in terms of furth
componenttext: So just if I could maybe probe a little further. The cash comes in from Syncrude later in the year. Oil prices go up. I mean, there's no imperative to drill under the Canadian leased structure. So it sounds like you get on the front foot in terms of further delineating and then getting to appraisal in sort of '17, '18?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say, we are well in the midyear now, Ed, and just getting this to hopefully closed soon. And this year, our limited capital spend of completing 4 wells there with our partners and some additional field development expenses. And then get into
componenttext: Yes, I would say, we are well in the midyear now, Ed, and just getting this to hopefully closed soon. And this year, our limited capital spend of completing 4 wells there with our partners and some additional field development expenses. And then get into a plan next year of a decent capital spend and it will have to complete well with our other unconventionals like Eagle Ford but has very, very similar returns and I anticipate that we will be wanting to get in there and work there at some capital level, and we're in the middle of that Field Development Plan as we speak.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, just curious. I mean, you guys own the 5% Syncrude for over 20 years and speaking theoretically, there has been talking about should it be a call, should you not simply sell. In the last say 12 months that seems like final deal after long-suffering
componenttext: Roger, just curious. I mean, you guys own the 5% Syncrude for over 20 years and speaking theoretically, there has been talking about should it be a call, should you not simply sell. In the last say 12 months that seems like final deal after long-suffering that the operation is improving. Unit costs are coming down. And the price you received is not necessarily considered really high. So is there any particular change in your thinking about that asset or your portfolio lead to the decision that you want to sell it here other than saying that you may want to have the cash sitting on the balance sheet because of position yourself for say lower-for-longer oil price. Other than that reason, is there any other fundamental reasons for the decision that you make here?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. I don't believe the price is that bad as to our long range planning and there have been some operational improvements here. They've been very short-term as opposed to the 22 years of turnaround that go over the schedule and various things of
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. I don't believe the price is that bad as to our long range planning and there have been some operational improvements here. They've been very short-term as opposed to the 22 years of turnaround that go over the schedule and various things of that nature. As we look at a price recovery type deck, we see this price to be very fair in our long-range planning and we should know, we've been in an asset for a real long time. So if you're looking at oil being $76 in 2020 or $74 in '19, then I like the position we have in Canadian dollars here, honestly. I think it's a matter of, we probably had 400 million barrels 4, 5 years ago. We have 770 million barrels now. We had real good year of reserve replacement. We've increased our RRP a good bit in our company and it becomes a matter of if not, if when -- if not now, when. So we have a strategic situation where I would like to leave the asset, and we have a strategic situation where Suncor wants to buy the asset at the same time that have built in price on a share base with COS, we were able to turn that into all cash, that opportunity was in stock, thought that was very good for us, and very fair. It's exactly the same money that COS paid for these barrels on a per barrel basis only metric exactly saying. This project returns free cash flow when oil is $100, but not so much when it's below $80. So we wanted to move out of that and feel like our reserves have increased, and we want to focus in unconventional, a nearby acreage there where we can get the OpEx below 10. And out of the OpEx, even if it's improved to slightly below 30, and it was a built-in time to do it, I felt like it was a rare time that we could execute it and went ahead and moved on.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, is the cash proceed from the Syncrude sales, is there much of a tax leakage or that we should assume you received the full cash?
componenttext: John, is the cash proceed from the Syncrude sales, is there much of a tax leakage or that we should assume you received the full cash?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The cash we received and we do have to give some basis, Paul, to Suncor. And so there could be a little bit of cash taxes that we have to pay in Canada. We are still evaluating that and computing it. But so I think there'll be a little bit of cash tax owe
componenttext: The cash we received and we do have to give some basis, Paul, to Suncor. And so there could be a little bit of cash taxes that we have to pay in Canada. We are still evaluating that and computing it. But so I think there'll be a little bit of cash tax owed on a Syncrude transaction. But it won't be a super large amount. And on an overall basis, it's going to be probably P&L slightly positive.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Should we assume that at least you get 90% of whatever is the proceeds in cash?

componenttext: That would -- yes, I think it's that much, Paul, or more. I would say, it's probably a little more.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And John, do you have an update about your negotiation with the bank on the revolver extension?
componenttext: Okay. And John, do you have an update about your negotiation with the bank on the revolver extension?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's ongoing, Paul. And we are -- due to the Syncrude transaction, we are rejiggering all of our numbers for presentation to the banks. Those are being shared with our bankers today, and not at this time, not necessarily today. And we will have discu
componenttext: Yes, it's ongoing, Paul. And we are -- due to the Syncrude transaction, we are rejiggering all of our numbers for presentation to the banks. Those are being shared with our bankers today, and not at this time, not necessarily today. And we will have discussions ongoing for the next few weeks trying to negotiate something there. We had a goal of trying to do something in the next few months, obviously, and so we'd like to get that behind us. But we clearly are -- things are improving. Our situation with our asset transactions, I think, in our favor. So we see it basically being much better and much different than it was 2 to 3 months ago. So we are confident that this will get done in a reasonable time and in a reasonable way.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: With the changing in your asset mix, what is the -- any set of new set of matrix in terms of the financial leverage that you can share with us that you may be targeting?
