componenttext: North America, 3 to 4 rigs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Between Canada and the Eagle Ford together, 4 rigs to say that won't be a problem. That's not -- I can handle that problem, Paul, whenever we get to that, believe me.
componenttext: Between Canada and the Eagle Ford together, 4 rigs to say that won't be a problem. That's not -- I can handle that problem, Paul, whenever we get to that, believe me.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Guy Baber from Simmons.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Guy Baber from Simmons.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, I had a capital allocation question for you. But as you ramp down your capital spending, the dividend now has obviously become sizable relative to your CapEx. So the question is, how you think about laying the potential for incremental gross spendi
componenttext: Roger, I had a capital allocation question for you. But as you ramp down your capital spending, the dividend now has obviously become sizable relative to your CapEx. So the question is, how you think about laying the potential for incremental gross spending to help arrest declines or allocate capital to attractive places like Montney and Kaybob Duvernay versus continuing to pay out that same dividend at the same level? How do you think about the relative ranking of capital deployment between those 2 options right now?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean the dividend policy at Murphy is a long-term policy and oil price have been a short-term change. Oil price up even $10 since the last time we had a call. That's well over 200 something million in cash flow for Murphy. Our dividend here is und
componenttext: Well, I mean the dividend policy at Murphy is a long-term policy and oil price have been a short-term change. Oil price up even $10 since the last time we had a call. That's well over 200 something million in cash flow for Murphy. Our dividend here is under closer review than it has been before. It will be under meeting in August. And really, you're going to do that quarter-by-quarter. We've paid 2 of the dividends at the full price here. And it is important of a capital allocation as it is for other things. And we continue to see well costs come down, we're able to execute more wells with less costs. We're able to do this at both Montney and Eagle Ford. And I think we are still on such a recalibration mode of our cash flows with all of the ins and outs of our business, this will be something really for the fall and we're going to be focusing on this production and cash flow and where we allocate capital and we'll be kicking that can down the road to the fall time, to be honest with you, Guy.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then the capital spending for the quarter, it looked like it was pretty much in line with the annual guidance. But we had actually expected that to be trending lower through the year as you ramp down some of your rig activities. So it loo
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then the capital spending for the quarter, it looked like it was pretty much in line with the annual guidance. But we had actually expected that to be trending lower through the year as you ramp down some of your rig activities. So it looked like the CapEx was lower than what we had anticipated. Are you operating more efficiently and does the CapEx look like it could be coming in lower than what the internal plan has been? Anything you can share on that front?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would imagine today if one of our financial outlook books that we produce here at Murphy we find our capital probably $30 million less than our 5 80 today. And it will be a matter of do we want to add some wells for the savings in a place like in Eagle
componenttext: I would imagine today if one of our financial outlook books that we produce here at Murphy we find our capital probably $30 million less than our 5 80 today. And it will be a matter of do we want to add some wells for the savings in a place like in Eagle Ford. But our capital is really on schedule almost x4 equal. And then we have -- well a few minutes ago we rattled off some wells in the Eagle Ford. We'll have wells in the Montney, too. And then we have opportunities -- our jackup rig in Malaysia is farmed out to another party, and it will be coming back. And we're installing a jacket there. And when CapEx gets at that level, small things can change it. But I'm very pleased with the idea that we are not overspending or front-loading our CapEx, because our CapEx is a very real item that we are focused on here. And we are not front-loading it with the idea that we're going to increase it. We just got our CapEx set at these levels. Happy with how it's going. Happy with the efficiency, the cost reductions and continue on with that regime at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then last one for me, the cost performance this quarter, obviously, very impressive with the lowest per barrel cost in a number of years. To what extent is the performance that you delivered this quarter is that sustainable? Were there any onetime ben
componenttext: And then last one for me, the cost performance this quarter, obviously, very impressive with the lowest per barrel cost in a number of years. To what extent is the performance that you delivered this quarter is that sustainable? Were there any onetime benefits? I know you ran very well during the quarter. But is that sustainable? And then also, in an improving oil price environment, to what extent do you think these are structural cost improvements that you've captured?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say we have some downtime events this quarter, as I went through in my remarks. It doesn't lead to lower OpEx, as you would imagine. We had a very, very good OpEx in 7 50 range. And we are trending to get back to where we were last year arou
componenttext: Well, I would say we have some downtime events this quarter, as I went through in my remarks. It doesn't lead to lower OpEx, as you would imagine. We had a very, very good OpEx in 7 50 range. And we are trending to get back to where we were last year around a $9 range. But in our internal planning, we were $1 under our very aggressive budget. So my folks, the handler upstream business are doing a very good job, our procurement, the cost of services continue to improve and the focus in the proper allocation of those costs, but we didn't not have a special item this quarter that drove that. So I continue to be positively surprised on OpEx by my team. It's a big focus that we have. And while I say that we manned up over at the end of the year with declining production, which we talked about here today, at the same level, I've been greatly surprised and very pleased with how OpEx is going here. As to the service side, you would anticipate that to run out of room there, but it continues to be positive, reinforced procurement and aggressive bidding of services. And each time we have procurement, we continue to have small gains in procurement of bidding to companies that are maintaining their market share or business. So I continue to be positively surprised. I got a great team focused on it, and I think we're doing a great job there and I'm really happy about it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Kyle Rhodes from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Kyle Rhodes from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one for me. Any update you can provide on Block H FLNG program, just maybe in terms of expectations for first gas? And what your future capital outlays are for that project in 2017 and 2018?
componenttext: Just one for me. Any update you can provide on Block H FLNG program, just maybe in terms of expectations for first gas? And what your future capital outlays are for that project in 2017 and 2018?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are both going to have over $100 million there and probably some more into '18 on the subsurface side of the fields, incredibly successful for us. Many successful wells in a row. Great gas project there. Very similar in rates to our SK Gas. Petronas ha
componenttext: We are both going to have over $100 million there and probably some more into '18 on the subsurface side of the fields, incredibly successful for us. Many successful wells in a row. Great gas project there. Very similar in rates to our SK Gas. Petronas has started this vessel. They're supplying floating LNG vessels in Korea. It is partially built, and they're trying to slow that project down because these are tied to Brent prices but work -- this project works well and Brent's around $50. They have come -- we have a gas agreement with them, they've come to us about pushing the first gas to that into 2020, in which they would have the expense of changing the capital spend with the vessel in the Korean shipyard, if you will. And we are agreeable to that, and it would give us more capital for next year to use in our other high-returning assets like Eagle Ford Shale or Duvernay shale. And so we pushed out that production to 2020. And that's fine with me at this time. It'll be another long-term LNG asset with one of the great LNG partners in the world, and it is going to work out for us down the road there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So less than $100 million in '17 spend, then any idea kind of just what the full development costs are?
componenttext: Got it. So less than $100 million in '17 spend, then any idea kind of just what the full development costs are?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that right in front of me. I apologize. Kelly can get that for you. But that hasn't changed I would say the costs are lower because I anticipate deep water rigs to be lower. And the well, it may not be by 2019, but I imagine they will. And ou
componenttext: I don't have that right in front of me. I apologize. Kelly can get that for you. But that hasn't changed I would say the costs are lower because I anticipate deep water rigs to be lower. And the well, it may not be by 2019, but I imagine they will. And our services there, we're in a great situation in costs. But our large partner there would like to push it to the right. I'd like to save the $100 million right now. And I'm very pleased with the adjustment when we get organized with Petronas.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- I know you guys have been very successful in reducing CapEx. I'm just trying to understand the full year production guidance following that reduction. I know there's steep declines in 2Q, in your 2Q guidance. What operationally flattens those decl
componenttext: Just -- I know you guys have been very successful in reducing CapEx. I'm just trying to understand the full year production guidance following that reduction. I know there's steep declines in 2Q, in your 2Q guidance. What operationally flattens those declines out in the second half? Is that just a return from maintenance activity that you mentioned?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. I mean, I mean, we are looking at production in Canada in the third quarter, second quarter actually going up as we have some more Montney production there, slightly more. Had enormous pile on of downtime in the second quarter we knew a
componenttext: Yes, that's right. I mean, I mean, we are looking at production in Canada in the third quarter, second quarter actually going up as we have some more Montney production there, slightly more. Had enormous pile on of downtime in the second quarter we knew about. We also have some downtime planned in our business for Kikeh, which is very rarely shut down. And our Block K area has been, I guess, 10 years since that facility stopped. And the Eagle Ford Shale is just a less well count. Decline in the Gulf of Mexico, it's basically flat. So quarter 2 to quarter 3 would primarily be around just a lack of investment in Eagle Ford Shale. And after that, it would be very flat if it were not for that issue. So I think it's a big downtime in the second quarter. But let's keep in mind that all along our external guidance is the same, and we had a capital spend that was very low. And we came into the year with many wells on the Eagle Ford Shale being completed in December. And now we are at that same guidance. So nothing has really changed on that regard.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my second question, I guess, following up on the capital allocation question, but what's the -- is regaining your investment-grade rating a key priority in the recovery? And with that would you expect that would drive running your business free
componenttext: Great. And my second question, I guess, following up on the capital allocation question, but what's the -- is regaining your investment-grade rating a key priority in the recovery? And with that would you expect that would drive running your business free cash flow positive into an early portion of a recovery?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The investment-grade thing is a couple of months ago. We moved onto all these assets ins and outs. We've been fairly active in our company changing our portfolio. We want -- I want to get my own targets on debt and continue to defend our position there. A
componenttext: The investment-grade thing is a couple of months ago. We moved onto all these assets ins and outs. We've been fairly active in our company changing our portfolio. We want -- I want to get my own targets on debt and continue to defend our position there. And it's not we get up every day and say, let's get back to investment-grade again. I think the multiples of EBITDA and a limit on debt to cap and working inside cash flow CapEx parity, we continue to illustrate that. Then we'll move back up the investment-grade line again, we're still investment-grade with S&P. So I don't get up every morning focusing on Moody's, but we're going to try to do the right thing, work on these -- being the leader in some of these multiples, and it will work out over time for us.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So free cash flow parity is how we should think about you in terms of the future reinvestment when the commodity price recovers, I guess?
componenttext: So free cash flow parity is how we should think about you in terms of the future reinvestment when the commodity price recovers, I guess?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a couple of questions with regards to decline rates. You mentioned in your comments you've been surprised by a more modest decline coming I think out of the Eagle Ford since you stopped adding new wells. And I wondered if that is just the na
componenttext: Wanted to ask a couple of questions with regards to decline rates. You mentioned in your comments you've been surprised by a more modest decline coming I think out of the Eagle Ford since you stopped adding new wells. And I wondered if that is just the natural decline or whether you're doing anything specifically to try to mitigate that, that has been the source of the better performance?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is a lot of focus on when to put in artificial lift and stay inside our operating expense and cash projections, Brian. There's these rigs we hire to optimize when you put on artificial lift, how you set up the artificial lift. And when things get ve
componenttext: There is a lot of focus on when to put in artificial lift and stay inside our operating expense and cash projections, Brian. There's these rigs we hire to optimize when you put on artificial lift, how you set up the artificial lift. And when things get very difficult and you're cutting your budget, people move from focusing on growth to enhancing the base. And we've been very happy with how our teams have performed as to that total focus on what wells are down, why are they down, and how you improve the artificial lift timing. And that's been the source of their success there, in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could ask a very similar question in Malaysia also, without speaking to the ups and downs of maintenance in various places, can you just talk to what your natural oil decline rates are and then anything that you can do either in terms of a Brownfield
componenttext: If I could ask a very similar question in Malaysia also, without speaking to the ups and downs of maintenance in various places, can you just talk to what your natural oil decline rates are and then anything that you can do either in terms of a Brownfield-type legacy type drilling here and there? Or decline mitigations?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think of Malaysia as probably a less than 20% decline, it can be as low as 15%. A lot of these projects are supported by water injection. And we're very constant production of gas. They're on a BOE basis, Brian, you would have been in that business of
componenttext: We think of Malaysia as probably a less than 20% decline, it can be as low as 15%. A lot of these projects are supported by water injection. And we're very constant production of gas. They're on a BOE basis, Brian, you would have been in that business of gas there for a long time. When things are running appropriately, we have at least 250 million gross that we operate into a Petronas LNG plant. So that's a pretty constant production. It only is up and down with LNG. So that one is fairly constant. Also still cash flow providing field for us at 3 60 type dollar per Mcf. And the rest of the fields, this Kakap-Gumusut where we have 8%, is a very, very successful field, limited decline in its own plateau. And you roll all that together and just not an enormous decline rate coming out of there, primarily at this time related to these uptown -- these downtime events that I described.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one from me. Looking at the possibility that you would resume exploration in 2017 or subsequent to that, other than Vietnam, which you just entered a few months ago, what other geographies might you consider getting back into exploration?
componenttext: Just one from me. Looking at the possibility that you would resume exploration in 2017 or subsequent to that, other than Vietnam, which you just entered a few months ago, what other geographies might you consider getting back into exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, at this time, we have a very nice acreage position in the Vulcan basin North of Australia, and we're trying to focus until the cost structure and the deepwater rigs of the Gulf get more organized. We're not focusing there right now. Vulcan basin Aus
componenttext: Well, at this time, we have a very nice acreage position in the Vulcan basin North of Australia, and we're trying to focus until the cost structure and the deepwater rigs of the Gulf get more organized. We're not focusing there right now. Vulcan basin Australia is a very underexplored place, where we have a very large new seismic data set, and we are onto a new play there with some hundred million barrel type opportunities and very inexpensive to drill. That would be one focus area. We have a partner there, Mitsui, we're 60-40 with them. We also, as you know, in The Great Australian Bight, we have the Ceduna Basin, where we have enormous acreage position with all of our seismic acquired and reprocessed. And we're setting next to BP and Statoil and also Chevron, it will be drilling upwards 6 to 8 wells over the next couple of years. This is a prolific basin, the size of the North Sea and one of the largest left undrilled basins in the world, where we have a position to be able to watch them drill. And those are our focus areas in Vietnam, it's Cuu Long Basin, and we have to think of Vietnam as a place similar to Malaysia, where we started with shallow water blocks. We also have ultra-deepwater blocks. And that entry in that long-term relationship allowed us to enter into the Cuu Long Basin, where we are working with them to add some additional acreage, and we formed into a very successful project there and have to look at Vietnam holistically because the Cuu Long Basin is the prize there. And those are areas today. We're also interested in Mexico bid round because they will not have the higher cost issues placed on the Gulf of Mexico by this administration. I think that's positive. Also of note in the exploration world today, seismic is very inexpensive. Massive seismic availability for inside our budget here. We're not looking to increase our budget in any way, especially in that. But can get lots of data today and build up positions again if needed in this low environment.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one quick one for me. Just thinking about the revolver maturity that's coming up, I guess, in just over a year. How do you guys thinking through that process? Is the expectation that it's just going to be a simple kind of amend and extend, and it sta
componenttext: Just one quick one for me. Just thinking about the revolver maturity that's coming up, I guess, in just over a year. How do you guys thinking through that process? Is the expectation that it's just going to be a simple kind of amend and extend, and it stays unsecured? If you can kind of talk about how you're approaching that now that you have some rapid sales in hand.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let John speak to it, but it is a blend and extend type thing that we would prefer, an option we prefer. And we believe our Syncrude situation and the cash that we have on our balance sheet, just in general, from an asset perspective, is helping that
componenttext: I'll let John speak to it, but it is a blend and extend type thing that we would prefer, an option we prefer. And we believe our Syncrude situation and the cash that we have on our balance sheet, just in general, from an asset perspective, is helping that. And also our lower capital spending hitting our targets and oil price recovery, I think, things are leading to a positive in nature in that, in my view. I sensed a sentiment of improvement in that business over the last 6 weeks.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of more positive action going on in the marketplace, Sean. And we are -- our goal is to extend. We're talking to our bankers about it, probably consider having to adjust our $2 billion somewhat in terms of the maximum size. And we'd like to
componenttext: There's a lot of more positive action going on in the marketplace, Sean. And we are -- our goal is to extend. We're talking to our bankers about it, probably consider having to adjust our $2 billion somewhat in terms of the maximum size. And we'd like to keep it unsecured, obviously. And so we are working toward that as well. So we'll -- it's all in the works, all being discussed and negotiations to proceed over time. And we're confident we can get the thing extended at a reasonable size and a reasonable manner in terms of security and such.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a little bit about the decision to suspend completion activity in the Eagle Ford. Broadly, at a higher level, you guys are shifting towards more of a North American, unconventional focus. A little bit surprised given the quality of you
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a little bit about the decision to suspend completion activity in the Eagle Ford. Broadly, at a higher level, you guys are shifting towards more of a North American, unconventional focus. A little bit surprised given the quality of your Eagle Ford acreage and the core that you would suspend activity or at least the completion activity. I was wondering if you can help us think about that. And what oil price do you think you need, Roger, where you think your U.S. onshore business could deliver value to the drill bit?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it's -- all of our hopefully new to be signed Duvernay shale and our Eagle Ford can deliver 10% rates of return in the low 30s and we're ahead of that now. We, at Murphy, set out earlier in the year and the price collapsed to organize our ca
componenttext: Well, I mean, it's -- all of our hopefully new to be signed Duvernay shale and our Eagle Ford can deliver 10% rates of return in the low 30s and we're ahead of that now. We, at Murphy, set out earlier in the year and the price collapsed to organize our capital around the lowest capital we could have, and then recalibrated our company because in and around that I knew of asset sales and different things we're doing. We're not a company that goes out saying we're selling all these assets and doing that, but we had a lot going on to accomplish all these purchase and sale agreements that you read about in the press. So in and around that, we're trying to get to a minimum capital spend, recalibrate our company. Once we had the closing, and then we have our revolver to redo, a recalibration of our company, a focus out of non-core in North America into unconventionals, all of that takes time. And so we went into it with a low CapEx. So we're going to Eagle Ford and we have continuous drilling obligations and we move our rig around for that. And then from that, we are not a company to bill that drill in uncompleted wells and we have a low level CapEx to meet all these other goals of recalibration I spoke of. And that led to that schedule. And that schedule has on been around since around mid-February, and I'm not interested in probably breaking it back up and open it back up to capital parade on May 5, whatever today is. So that's how we are thinking about that. It was derived on purpose from a lowest commitment basis. And we are focusing on cost in that, and we will come out of this when we are confident of an oil price recovery. Unlike any operator, oil gets into the 50s things change a lot. And we'll have to then allocate capital among that and offshore opportunities and move forward. But today, we are looking at it, more conservative view of that at Murphy Oil Corp.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. It makes sense. And just a follow-up, any more details on the Kodiak well timing and the magnitude of when do you think that could come back [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Okay. It makes sense. And just a follow-up, any more details on the Kodiak well timing and the magnitude of when do you think that could come back [indiscernible]?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a really good well. The key thing in the business is subsurface, you have to have subsurface. The well flow, has ability to flow over 10,000 barrels a day from single well, that's the beauty of offshore, that's why offshore still works. And the wel
componenttext: That's a really good well. The key thing in the business is subsurface, you have to have subsurface. The well flow, has ability to flow over 10,000 barrels a day from single well, that's the beauty of offshore, that's why offshore still works. And the well had a choke manufacturing issue on the surface involving some products that were built into the choke that had to be changed with special order type equipment. We had to get involved with the operator and get that turned around and fixed. And nothing wrong with the well. It's going to flow at a higher oil price today, so it's fine.

componenttext: Is that going to come -- any sense on timing, is it the second half '16...

componenttext: No. We're talking about hopefully right now while we're talking. We are talking about it right now, it better be right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Most of the things have been asked, but I was wondering with the unconventionals, obviously everybody is doing better with optimizations, more sand, more fluids, more intervals, whatever. Are you working at all with density pilots in your shale plays to [indiscernible]?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We work on about everything, but I have to tell you, I'm not aware of it. I wouldn't be surprised. But I will say this about unconventionals, this continued improvement by everyone and you look at all these press releases you will see Murphy executing and
componenttext:
We work on about everything, but I have to tell you, I'm not aware of it. I wouldn't be surprised. But I will say this about unconventionals, this continued improvement by everyone and you look at all these press releases you will see Murphy executing and performing at or above everybody else. That's not uncommon. But I know that in my view, with our big service providers looking to merge, and now they're not going to merge, with focus on less capital spending, I believe the technological issues in unconventionals have gone on the sideline for this year. And I believe that we're missing -- we could miss some efficiency as you go to less pad drilling and some efficiency on experimentation of capital that I think was driving a lot of the unconventional improvement, which will lead to lower U.S. oil production and an oil price recovery. But if you have just a few wells and everyone is reducing their CapEx, not just Murphy, there will be less experimentation of capital if you will, in my view.
That's all we have today. That would be the end of our call. I appreciate everyone calling in. And we'll talk to you next time we have a quarterly release. And I appreciate it. Thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. P
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, Jake. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the inform
componenttext:
Good afternoon, Jake. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the information on slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. John will begin by providing a review of the second quarter financial results, highlighting our balance sheet and strong liquidity position, followed by Roger with an operational update and outlook, after which, questions will be taken. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2015 annual report on the Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the second quarter of 2016 were a profit of $2.9 million, $0.02 per diluted share. The comparative result from the second quarter of 2015 was a net loss of $73.8 million, whi
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the second quarter of 2016 were a profit of $2.9 million, $0.02 per diluted share. The comparative result from the second quarter of 2015 was a net loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share. The improvement in 2016 net results included income tax and other benefits on dispositions of 2 former assets, including the company's 5% interest in Syncrude and the midstream gas processing plants that service the Tupper and Tupper West areas in eastern British Columbia. Excluding discontinued operations, continuing operations had a profit in the second quarter of 2016 of $2.9 million as well and $0.02 a share, and that compares to a loss in the second quarter of 2015 from continuing operations of $89 million or $0.51 per diluted share. 
Second quarter results from continuing operations in '16 included net income tax benefits of $88.9 million from sale of Syncrude and Montney midstream assets. These were mostly noncash tax benefits related to reductions and liabilities for future taxes owed on both of these disposed assets. I'll come back to these taxes and discuss them further in a moment. 
Adjusted earnings, which meant our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of results between periods was a loss of $62.4 million in the second quarter '16 compared to an adjusted net loss of $83.1 million a year ago. The improvement in adjusted results in the 2016 quarter was primarily attributable to lower cost per production, exploration and administrative activities, but these were partially offset by significantly lower oil and natural gas sales prices compared to 1 year ago. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release, and amounts on this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis, with a separate table as to the pretax and income tax impacts by area of operation. 
I now want to discuss further the Canadian transactions in the second quarter. The sale of Montney midstream assets was structured so that no cash taxes will be payable on this transaction. The company had previously recorded deferred tax liabilities for future taxes that were expected to be paid associated with these assets, and due to the structure of the transaction, the previously estimated future taxes will now not be paid so, therefore, in the second quarter, the company reversed these recorded tax liabilities and accordingly recognized the deferred tax benefit of approximately $21 million. 
The Syncrude sale was a taxable transaction, however. It did qualify for capital gain treatment, rather than ordinary tax treatment. Therefore, the tax rate was 1/2 of the standard statutory rate and equated to 13.75% rate, rather than a normal full rate of 27.5%. The overall net tax benefit of $68 million on the Syncrude disposition was mostly attributable to the reduced capital gain rate applicable to the transaction. Cash taxes apply to capital gains rate to the transaction in the amount of approximately $6 million, while deferred tax benefits were approximately $128 million to reduce future taxes payable, which had previously been accrued at the full tax rate. 
The company completed its entry into the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids-rich Montney areas during the second quarter. The initial spend upon closing the joint venture was $206.7 million, plus the company committed approximately another $171 million of future period for the seller over the next 4 to 5 years of operations. 
The company's cash flow from operations during the second quarter was $70 million. The quarter was impacted by paydown of accounts payable owed to vendors and a semiannual interest owed on outstanding debt borrowings. Since the second quarter was skewed by the timing of these cash payments, I think it is best to look at the 6 months year-to-date for understanding. 
Our first half 2016 cash flow totaled $113 million, and this included payments for canceled Deepwater drilling rig contracts of almost $262 million. In the past years, these costs would have been included as investing activity spend under the category of capital expenditures. However, since the decision was made to cancel these contracts without drilling, these costs have been recorded as cash outflows from operating activities in 2016. 
Looking at the first 6 months without these one-off rig payoffs, operating cash flow would total $375 million and annualizing this amount for a full year for pro forma purposes for 2016, operating cash flow would amount to approximately $750 million over the full 12 months, again, excluding the rig payments. 
The company's second quarter 2016 lease operating expense was lower by approximately $2.50 per barrel of oil equivalent compared to 1 year ago. Beginning in the second quarter of 2016, our average LOE costs include the new tariff associated with Montney area gas plants that were sold. Although these assets were sold above book value, for accounting purposes, the gain has been deferred. Starting in the second quarter 2016, the recorded gas processing cost is reduced to recognize a portion of the deferred gain on the asset sale, and the remainder of this gain will be recognized over the 20-year throughput commitment term. 
The company's second quarter 2016 average realized sales prices for its crude oil production was $44.42 per barrel sold, lower by $12 per barrel or 21% compared to the same period in the prior year. 
Natural gas prices also were weaker in quarter 2 compared to the prior year's quarter, with average North American gas price realizations of $1.35 per thousand cubic feet, a drop of $1.07 per Mcf or a decline of 44%. 
Realized oil index natural gas process offshore Sarawak fell 14% to an average of $3.29 per Mcf due to the decline in global crude oil prices. With crude oil prices improving during the second quarter of this year compared to the first quarter, the fair value of the company's open crude oil derivative contracts fell. Therefore, overall company revenue in the quarter was reduced by $59 million related to a lower mark-to-market fair value for open crude oil contracts. Although this revenue reduction is recorded in the second quarter, the impacts of the change in the fair value of these open contracts was not reflected -- is not reflected in the average realized sales prices recorded for the quarter, as here, only the actual cash received on contracts that matured that during the period are included in the average realized sales prices. 
Our EBITDA -- EBITDAX balances in the second quarter were hurt by well over $3 per barrel for the mark to market decline in crude contract value. 
For the remaining 6 months of 2016, the company has WTI based oil prices hedges for 25,000 barrels per day at a WTI average price of $50.67 per barrel. Additionally, the company has forward sales contracts for Canadian natural gas in the amount of 99 million cubic feet a day at an average AECO price at CAD 3 per thousand cubic feet over the remainder of '16. And we also have future Canadian gas hedges covering 59 million a day at CAD 2.81 per thousand cubic feet for the period of 2017 through 2020. 
At the end of the quarter, June 30, 2016, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to $2.44 billion, which equates to 32% of total capital employed, and net debt amounted to 28.5% of the capital employed. Both gross and net debt ratios were significant improvements from one quarter earlier. As of quarter-end, we had total cash and invested cash of almost $400 million and no outstanding borrowed balance on our $2 billion revolver that matures in June of 2017. We paid our revolving debt balance off in the second quarter using the combined net cash proceeds of approximately $1.15 billion from the Syncrude and Montney midstream dispositions. The company is working closely with our banking syndicate and expects to reach an agreement in the near term on the new revolving credit facility. 
That concludes my comment, and I'll now pass it over to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Looking back, the second quarter 2016 is a pivotal quarter for Murphy's to continued repositioning of the company. We're able to close our 2 previously announced key d
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Looking back, the second quarter 2016 is a pivotal quarter for Murphy's to continued repositioning of the company. We're able to close our 2 previously announced key divestitures, our interest in Syncrude, as well as our natural gas processing plants and pipelines servicing our Tupper Montney assets. Proceeds amounted to $1.15 billion as John mentioned. This allowed us to repay all the borrowings in our revolver and retained almost $400 million of cash in the balance sheet. 
As we closed on our new -- we also closed our new North American interventional pay or a the Kaybob Duvernay and Placid Montney at a low-cost upfront entry of USD 207 million. The new asset competes well with any recent North American transaction as we're able to acquire a low-cost entry point on any measure of 2P dollar resource or acreage. We believe that our current diversified asset mix is all weighted services as the base, which will be able to recalibrate production and respond to positive lower for longer commodity prices. 
During the quarter, we had an exceptionally low capital spend of $108 million, that's primarily due to timing. This does not include the previously mentioned Joint Venture purchase. This low rate is not indicative of a poorly run rate, as we do plan to spend $620 million over the course of 2016, as originally planned and announced in February. Also maintain our annual production guidance when adjusted for asset sales and purchases. 
We're also continuing to lower cost structure. LOE was down 23% from quarter 2 '15 and G&A down approximately 15% from quarter 2 '15 as well. 
Second quarter production, 168,600 BOE per day, was slightly lower than our guidance range when adjusted per sales and purchases. As you'll recall that we stated that there was a planned maintenance across many of our assets, which is common in quarter 2 for our company as well as natural production declines in Eagle Ford Shale as there were no wells planned, nor were any broad woman in the second quarter. 
Further impacting our second quarter production is the venture of the Syncrude, wildfires in Western Canada, another third-party infrastructure and facility curtailments. We expect our third quarter production to be flat as compared to second quarter with third quarter guidance in the range of 167,500 to 169,500. The guidance takes into account the long planned 10-day turnaround at the Tupper Montney area at over 2,400 barrel oil equivalent per day. 
The capital program for '16, as I mentioned, is maintain the $620 million plus an additional $207 million attributable to our purchase in the Kaybob and Montney areas. Spending for the first half of the year was roughly 40% of our planned annual CapEx. 
Both annual and third quarter production incorporates the production associated with newly acquired joint venture of Kaybob and Placid and divesture of interest in Syncrude, as previously announced. But these include annual guidance range has not been changed. 
Lease operating expense for second quarter '16 was $8.36 per BOE, shown a reduction of over 23% from the second quarter of 2015 reduction of over 9% for the full year of 2015. Our second quarter 2016 LOE was slightly higher than quarter 1 due to production volumes being lower, as I just mentioned. 
Always operating expenses noted here exclude Syncrude. 
We also made good progress in reducing our G&A cost over the past 12 months through strategic restructuring, workforce reductions approximately 35%. Second quarter G&A is approximately 15% from second quarter '15 and, more importantly, we've been able to decrease G&A cost by 23% from first quarter 2015 when we began implementing deliberate cost reduction measures. 
We continue to reposition our portfolio. Our current assets are more streamlined and concentrated than we became an independent E&P company almost 3 years ago. However, remaining true to our history, we're still a global diversified oil-weighted E&P company that generates stable cash flow from long-lived conventional reserves, primarily in Malaysia, that oil-weighted price to Brent along with SK Gas price with oil. We're positioned from ground grassroots efforts, in 3 premier North American unconventional plays that provide us short cycle growth opportunities following our low-cost entry point. We continue to review our portfolio, and we'll act when opportunities present themselves. 
In offshore Malaysia business, we produced 56,000 BOE per day during the quarter, with natural gas production from Sarawak registering 96 million a day. During the third quarter, we are planning a topside installation at South Acis satellite platform. The wells were drilled earlier this year and expected to start producing in the fourth quarter. This topside installation will allow us to maintain our current SK production throughout the year at maximum capacity. 
As part of the improved oil recovery project in Kikeh we installed the surface jet pump systems during the quarter now to successful installation of this system, resulting enhanced production, we'll be installing electrical submersible pump later this year. Further we are planning a long-term gas project for this field as well. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, production in the second quarter was approximately 16,600-barrel equivalents per day at 83% liquids. The Kodiak well is in production mid-quarter and is currently producing over 12,500 barrel equivalents per day gross. 
Options are currently being evaluated to co-mingle into an upper zone that's expected to further enhance rates as well as an offset well opportunity. This project has been very successful for us. 
Murphy holds a large acreage position in Southern Australia basin, where we have seismic commitments only. Previously, we have acquired and evaluated seismic across our acreage and are pleased with the prospects we have seen. We feel this area could be greatly derisked by drilling that take place in the adjacent blocks with BP and Statoil plans to spud the first of 2 wells this fall. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, second quarter production was 47,500 equivalents per day. As planned, there were no new wells brought online this quarter. However, we did complete 8 wells that are online in the current quarter. These wells were completed ahead of plan to synchronize completion schedules with offset operators and require the offset wells to be shut in. In addition to these 8 wells, which are now flowing, there are 22 wells currently scheduled to be brought during the second half of the year, including 2 Austin Chalk wells, 1 in Karnes and the other testing and most Western acreage in Catarina. 
We continue making strides in decreasing driven completion cost, as we averaged $4 million per well across the play, which is 25% below the $5 million per well in the second quarter of '15. We still have significant running room ahead for us here, over 2,000 potential locations in the Eagle Ford Shale. Reserves are all weighted at roughly 90%. The asset is very meaningful for Murphy's feature reserves production cash flow. 
Over the past several months, we followed progress on 2 prior completed Karnes well, employing high concentrations sand fracs, allowing us to use a more aggressive choke technique. We employed this technique on former wells recently and plan and on plan for more in the third quarter. Initial results are impressive, with a 15% higher EUR and 30% higher IP than offset wells. As stated prior, we should in wells during the completion of the operations. After we brought these offset wells back online we experienced an uplift in production from those wells. We look forward to bringing you updates as we move this technique across more of Karnes and into our Tilden area and also Catarina area later this year. 
We're further testing our stack zone potential exists across our acreage position, we're testing a new Austin Chalk well along with 3 upper Eagle Ford wells in Karnes and our latest high concentrations and completion program. We are also completing a new Austin Chalk well in the Catarina area. 
In Canada, our Tupper Montney asset produced over 197 million a day for the quarter. There were 10 wells brought online during this quarter, including 2 wells that tested extended laterals and increased per lateral foot in the completion phase. These wells are currently cleaning up, with encouraging initial results. We look forward to bringing you updates in the third quarter call. 
I stated earlier, we closed the sale of our Montney natural gas processing plants earlier in the quarter. After including the new tariff associated for these sales, we expect well breakeven cost for a 10% return to be USD 1.65 AECO and LOE for the second quarter was $0.63 per Mcf, which includes the new tariff associated with monetizing Montney processing plants and pipeline. The greatly reduced drilling and completion costs and higher EURs and easy to manage the new tariff and take advantage of the monetization of following the proceeds and higher returning assets. Returns have further enhance for the long-term hedging program out to 2020 as part of our ongoing strategy. 
We closed our previously announced joint venture in the Kaybob Duvernay and Placid Montney area in mid-quarter. We're just getting started on our operatorship with the Kaybob asset and move forward with development plans for the rest of the year and planning 2017. This time, we are completing 4 well pad in the condensate area of the play and anticipate flowing these wells very late this quarter or early next. 
We are also picking up rig between, we plan to drill a 4 well pad in [indiscernible] area in quarter 4 and hope to have 2 wells drilled by year-end. Our plan in the Kaybob area is to increase lateral lengths over time to 9,000 feet and pump fracs 2,000 panels per foot of sand, which we feel will lead to higher rates in the area of the play and offer upside for Murphy and our partner. 
In Placid Montney, we are a nonoperating partner with 30% working interest. The current plan's to drill 12 wells this year, drilling has already begun. The first pad of wells anticipated to flow late this year. 
As we close our call today, some takeaways. Murphy continues with our plan to reposition the company, stabilize production, and ultimately, grow production as oil prices recover. We significantly reduced our 2016 capital program to $620 million as previously announced, and recalibrated our annual production to 173,000 to 177,000 range after accounting for asset mix changes. Our key plays continued performing well in Malaysia and especially in North America and conventional onshore assets, where we have significant upside. We remain focused on our cost structure. We're proud of our plan to not issue equity in the price collapse earlier this year and also during this time, with new able to's further strengthen our balance sheet by lowering debt levels. 
I'd now like to open it up for your questions, and thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can have a follow-up here to kind of the Duvernay question that was asked. As you guys kind of get here in the back half, just trying to get a sense of maybe the pace of progress or the pace of change in how you guys complete wells. I believe that's
componenttext: If I can have a follow-up here to kind of the Duvernay question that was asked. As you guys kind of get here in the back half, just trying to get a sense of maybe the pace of progress or the pace of change in how you guys complete wells. I believe that's on the slide deck, where you're kind of going to start out at 2,000 pounds of lateral foot. I think people have gotten as high as 3,500 pounds per lateral foot. Just curious how you guys are thinking about that or for the back half of '16, you just kind of stay at a pretty standard completion technique.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going 2,000 on our operated area and working with our partner on their operated area. And our first step is to get to longer laterals to do that. It's my view then, the information I have that 1,000 pounds per foot is quite common there now. There's
componenttext: We're going 2,000 on our operated area and working with our partner on their operated area. And our first step is to get to longer laterals to do that. It's my view then, the information I have that 1,000 pounds per foot is quite common there now. There's been very few people step into the 2,000. I've not personally heard of 3,500 pound per foot lateral. But it's like all things we're taking over the operatorship, hiring those personnel into our company, get our proxies in the field, drilling our first pad starting in October, November. Then we have to work on how long it takes the time wells go to the field of development plan, near infrastructure versus these timing versus the best wells in G&G and the best for capital allocation middle of doing that right now. I'm very pleased with this ground forward buildup result, be reviewing that in more detail quickly. And so I think that we're going to start at the 2,000-pound per foot and go from there. And then, I think there will be a lot of information from that. And the flow technique and there's other things in critical to place. But our experience of hundreds of wells in the Montney and the Eagle Ford and all that experimentation around like water and sand, volumes load as well to move in here and really get off the learning curve very quickly, run by 1 single leader in all of our Onshore business.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I appreciate that. One more here. Maybe jumping over to the Eagle Ford. You guys have done a great job of lowering costs. Even this year, you guys have put downward pressure on cost. And, I believe, just kind of going around and drilling kind of s
componenttext: Got it. I appreciate that. One more here. Maybe jumping over to the Eagle Ford. You guys have done a great job of lowering costs. Even this year, you guys have put downward pressure on cost. And, I believe, just kind of going around and drilling kind of single one-off well, is there more room there on the cost side of things especially as you guys kind of get back to pad development with where squeeze all you can out of that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I keep thinking that it's flattened on the drilling side, but we continue to improve. And you're right, we've had a lease maintenance CapEx and that leads to some of this timing issue on capital in the second quarter, and that's why that capital was
componenttext: Well, I keep thinking that it's flattened on the drilling side, but we continue to improve. And you're right, we've had a lease maintenance CapEx and that leads to some of this timing issue on capital in the second quarter, and that's why that capital was paced in that way, and that's what the outcome is. We just drilled a record well last week, we drilled a well in Catarina, over 12,000 feet in 4 days. And I can tell you, that's incredible performance. And so we haven't even gotten the fullback pad drilling mode again, I just see big upside. There's discussions about service cost and lower service players, and that's going up et cetera over time. But in the oil operation days, it's a day's business. You have to be on wells these days the matter the cost and really doing well there right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our Tupper, the Tupper Montney that we have, we're looking at cost below CAD 5 million right now total. And EURs there, we've said previously we want to get to 10 12 Bcf wells there, we just did our first big high pumping of sand well, and we're pleased w
componenttext: Our Tupper, the Tupper Montney that we have, we're looking at cost below CAD 5 million right now total. And EURs there, we've said previously we want to get to 10 12 Bcf wells there, we just did our first big high pumping of sand well, and we're pleased with the results there, and think we're going to get there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The current wells that we're doing, we inherited the wells from our partner, they are completing them, and they're currently using, keep in mind we just started working there over the last month. So they're using a C 9.5 million, which is 7.2 USD kind of
componenttext: The current wells that we're doing, we inherited the wells from our partner, they are completing them, and they're currently using, keep in mind we just started working there over the last month. So they're using a C 9.5 million, which is 7.2 USD kind of a charge there. And we know that these facts weren't very well and under the current completion cost of CAD 5 million, which adds up to that number. And we're looking to drill and complete our own well in the Kaybob light oil area in the northern condensate area of what we own for around 7.9 C going in as our goal, which is USD 6 million and we've been really fairly lowering cost in our Montney, which is 60 miles away from here, learned a lot about that, pad drilling, fracking, et cetera. And we believe we can drive these costs down to that level. We're going to set a goal to do that and I believe we'll execute that.

componenttext: I think most of this has been hit, but I guess, maybe one thing to explore here, you've done the asset sales, originally we thought maybe a little more aggressive on the asset side and a lower 48 recognized valuations may have gotten away a little bit there, but is there anything else that looks particularly interesting at this point or other than the obvious or somewhere in Texas that you might want to grow?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably not out of there. I mean, we do have very active business development team at Murphy involved and always repositioning. I don't believe we're in the mode of doing a lot of shriking right now. We want to keep what we have and were not against sell
componenttext: Probably not out of there. I mean, we do have very active business development team at Murphy involved and always repositioning. I don't believe we're in the mode of doing a lot of shriking right now. We want to keep what we have and were not against selling and buying and things of that nature. We have a very active team that looks both at all the plays in and around where we're working, and we are seeing some more data rooms and different choices there. And we look at them and study them, and we have a pretty high threshold to have strip price return at Murphy here, and we're proud of our entry cost that we have in our 3 plays that we have.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then thinking about the offshore. I know you don't want to do a whole lot of exploration right now, but we've seen a number of companies sell offshore or attempt to sell offshore and in some cases, walk away from what a onetime call [ph] discovery. So
componenttext: And then thinking about the offshore. I know you don't want to do a whole lot of exploration right now, but we've seen a number of companies sell offshore or attempt to sell offshore and in some cases, walk away from what a onetime call [ph] discovery. So I'm wondering are you seeing any value or is it just far too early in the process or oil prices need to be higher to make something happen in the offshore if you decide to go that direction?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're very excited about these opportunities. We do have a very strong execution team in the offshore to operate any kind of facility or drilling kind of well anywhere in the world any time. And we look at these opportunities. I believe that with the
componenttext: No, we're very excited about these opportunities. We do have a very strong execution team in the offshore to operate any kind of facility or drilling kind of well anywhere in the world any time. And we look at these opportunities. I believe that with the deepwater rigs and the mergers of things like Technique and FMC and Cameron and Schlumberger, et cetera, will lead to opportunity for lower cost there and the new starting point of a development,   if you will. And we are poised to look at that where some others who may not have that ability or have no team or ability to look in Deepwater kind of leave that behind. So many of those, and we would be looking at those on occasion, but we're pretty selective on it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did have some items, Paul, that hit in the second quarter that were accrued in prior periods. And that include significant amount of interest costs, some of our restructuring costs were paid, even though they were accrued for last quarter. So ther
componenttext: Yes, we did have some items, Paul, that hit in the second quarter that were accrued in prior periods. And that include significant amount of interest costs, some of our restructuring costs were paid, even though they were accrued for last quarter. So there's a number of things that lag, if you will. Some of the cost reductions on our LOE are now or in fact we're see continue going down over time, but we've still paid for some of those in second quarter. So it's a timing matter as to when these deals catch up with the payments. So I don't see anything in particular worrisome with it. And it should balance itself out over time.

componenttext: Well, I mentioned earlier, Paul, that we're on a pro forma basis the 7 50 when you annualize the 6 months doesn't seem crazy. And in fact, we might be a little bit North, we'll be a little bit north of that in our internal projections. Again, subject to whatever passes do to us and maybe they won't hold up very well, but we'll see. But interest and it for example, interest in the second quarter was $40 million that we paid on our notes. So that comes in lump -- in a lumpy fashion because we pay at semiannually instead of monthly or quarterly. So the things of that nature, $10.9 million [ph] plus $1 million worth of restructuring costs, things of that nature that were paid this quarter.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a pretty cautious EUR here. We think this is going to improve over time. In certain portions of our light area, we'll probably be close to 700 equivalent type EURs at around 80% liquids. In other parts of the more eastern area, light oil, approach
componenttext: We have a pretty cautious EUR here. We think this is going to improve over time. In certain portions of our light area, we'll probably be close to 700 equivalent type EURs at around 80% liquids. In other parts of the more eastern area, light oil, approaching 500,000 equivalents with around 80% liquids there. In the condensate, approaching 800 equivalents at 55% liquids. And then down in the Placid Montney like 7 50 with 31% liquids but we actually see around 42% this time. So you take those EURs and get into our ultimate cost of drill the wells for 6.5 to 6 USD, I think you'll lead to some pretty high graded returns here. And we also have the infrastructure in place. We have adequate infrastructure built to handle a couple of years of growth here. And like I said earlier in the call, building our ground for going with a plan point rule to review it in September. And we like it when we bought it, and we love it when we own it now.

componenttext: I just wanted to make sure I understand some of the earlier comments. So just a follow-up here. Is the general framework we should be thinking about is that you can grow in the single-digit percentage rate of your 2016 exit production base, which will be in the mid 160,000-barrel a-day range assuming oil is near $60 a barrel? Is that kind of on the point at which you are considered growing? Do I have that correct?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that I'm not sure have been 16 [ph] and 17 [ph] right now, so if it's in the 50s, it will be more stabilizing next year, and that's our goal. And then look to grow, say a year from now, when oil we hope approaches $60 again. It's all about cas
componenttext: I would say that I'm not sure have been 16 [ph] and 17 [ph] right now, so if it's in the 50s, it will be more stabilizing next year, and that's our goal. And then look to grow, say a year from now, when oil we hope approaches $60 again. It's all about cash flow and the CapEx and oil price guys. But we have modeled a $60 flat price forever in our business that shows post a year from now, we can start having 4% to 5% production growth with these type prices and we believe in it confidently.

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to see how you're thinking about blockade expansion, costs have come down globally. Does that impact how you think about timing? I mean incremental capital, can you just give us an update there and how -- if that's kind of above and beyond your gro
componenttext: I want to see how you're thinking about blockade expansion, costs have come down globally. Does that impact how you think about timing? I mean incremental capital, can you just give us an update there and how -- if that's kind of above and beyond your growth and free cash flow metrics that you just laid out.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is not going to be a very large CapEx for us, I do not have that off the top of my head as that been moved out. Our partner, Petronas, is building a floating LNG ship in Korea. Due to capital cutbacks earlier in the year across all industry, across e
componenttext: That is not going to be a very large CapEx for us, I do not have that off the top of my head as that been moved out. Our partner, Petronas, is building a floating LNG ship in Korea. Due to capital cutbacks earlier in the year across all industry, across every NOCs, they have delayed that ship. It's partially built today. It sits in Korea. It will be coming to us around 2020, 2021 I believe is the latest. And we have to drill 4, 5 wells there and do the tie back of pipelines. Naturally, if Deepwater costs persist at this level, it will be much lower than we originally envisioned. This is a game, Brian, it's a $50 Brent game to give you the type of gas price to have nice returns here. This will be in our long-range plan program, but would be out in the -- we have agreed with them to delay it and it's in our assessment. And it's a long way to 2020 from now in my life. So that's the game plan there, and it would count in the numbers I was just talking about with the guy on phone.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow-up is on decline rates. Can you give us an update on where you see your corporate decline rate? And how do you see that evolving, particularly in some of the shale areas that have received less capital over the last year and then
componenttext: Great. And then my follow-up is on decline rates. Can you give us an update on where you see your corporate decline rate? And how do you see that evolving, particularly in some of the shale areas that have received less capital over the last year and then probably seeing some moderation there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're about a 15% company, Brian. Today, I think, as we become more shale focus of a company, if you look at something like the Montney, I will believe that a year 1 well's around 20%. A year 2 of that well, 17. Year 3, around 14. So not a large decline t
componenttext: We're about a 15% company, Brian. Today, I think, as we become more shale focus of a company, if you look at something like the Montney, I will believe that a year 1 well's around 20%. A year 2 of that well, 17. Year 3, around 14. So not a large decline there. And of course, Eagle Ford, we probably look at our current spending and growth plans around 20% in first year, 17 in the second, then 14 in the third that's based off as you know, more than anyone, the timing of first-year second-year third year shale wells over declining -- decline rates,   if you will. And we organize around that and feel good about the decline rates I just described.

componenttext: Duvernay is going to go to around $50 million for the rest of the year, and a big growth in CapEx there, around 40 this coming quarter. componenttext: We are seeing some very high differentials now in the $0.95 range, some of that effect. But in the forward curves that are out every day, though steps are coming down. We do see -- were looking to do some more hedging volumes now at CAD 3 through 2020. And we're seeing the differentials tighten in the '17, '18, '19 to back to like a more traditional 70% to 75% number 75% [ph] number. There's also an ability to hedge some of those differentials, which we are exploring, and we see that getting tighter. We see like good news and starts today impacting that. And pleased with how that's going, but mostly pleased in our lower LOE, lower drilling costs and the ability to handle this tariff and a plant it and with the company do really well. So that's the main thing. Got to have those assets.
