componenttext: Oh, yes, that is still confirmed. And I think that we're building enough ground for a field development plan from grassroots up there, Paul, with lateral length sand. All the -- and we're about to review that and move forward with that. And as I look at the probably some additional capital there for '17 than we originally planned. And I believe, we are well on to that number that you mentioned, yes. But that's Duvernay only specific. Yes, so we want to replace the Syncrude production with the Duvernay as fast as we can living inside cash flow CapEx parity, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now, we'll move to a question from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And now, we'll move to a question from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe I could start out with a little bit of a -- if we start with maintenance CapEx, I think Roger, in the past, you've talked -- and maybe the follow-up to last question, you've talked about some of your ability to hold production flat to 2016's exit
componenttext: So maybe I could start out with a little bit of a -- if we start with maintenance CapEx, I think Roger, in the past, you've talked -- and maybe the follow-up to last question, you've talked about some of your ability to hold production flat to 2016's exit and to 2017 potentially around $800 million -- $900 million a year [ph] spend. Given your -- is that correct given your ability to do more with less this year, is that still the right number? Or did that number come down?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it'd be on the lower end to what you just said, Ryan.
componenttext: I think it'd be on the lower end to what you just said, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess as we think about cash allocation, I mean, I think there has been some concern that despite a relatively intriguing Duvernay asset, you may be limited in your ability to allocate material CapEx in that direction in the near term. Ca
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess as we think about cash allocation, I mean, I think there has been some concern that despite a relatively intriguing Duvernay asset, you may be limited in your ability to allocate material CapEx in that direction in the near term. Can you talk about priority to capital allocation in the 2017, and where the Duvernay kind of fits in the pecking order there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we really have a lot of things to choose from an onshore if you look at individual well economics today, our top 2 places will be our Catarina and Karnes area probably over 40% with current May 25 strip prices for Duvernay light oil in the mid-30s t
componenttext: Well, we really have a lot of things to choose from an onshore if you look at individual well economics today, our top 2 places will be our Catarina and Karnes area probably over 40% with current May 25 strip prices for Duvernay light oil in the mid-30s there. And our Placid Montney also in the low 30s. We're going to be probably moving -- we're just reviewing our capital for next year, but it's going to be significant capital and near the [ph] build this production base as I just answered the question for Paul. And we're in the middle of doing our '17 plans, but this is going to -- our unconventional is going to be a lot of our CapEx there, Ryan, as you anticipate. And we're very pleased with the places I have to allocate capital, I want to add more competition for capital allocation. I'm going to do so, and we're going to be getting this CapEx up in Duvernay shale to see what we have there pretty quick.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we will hear from Ben Wyatt with Stephens.
componenttext: And next we will hear from Ben Wyatt with Stephens.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can have a follow-up here to kind of the Duvernay question that was asked. As you guys kind of get after it here in the back half, just trying to get a sense of maybe the pace of progress or the pace of change in how you guys complete wells. I believ
componenttext: If I can have a follow-up here to kind of the Duvernay question that was asked. As you guys kind of get after it here in the back half, just trying to get a sense of maybe the pace of progress or the pace of change in how you guys complete wells. I believe I saw on the slide deck, where you're going to kind of start out at 2,000 pounds a lateral foot. I think people have gotten this high as about 3,500 pounds per lateral foot. Just curious how you guys are thinking about that. Or for the back half of '16, do you just kind of stay at a pretty standard completion technique?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are going 2,000 on our operated area and working with our partner on their operated area. And our first step is to get to longer laterals and do that. It's my view, Ben, from the information I have that 1,000 pounds per foot is quite common there now.
componenttext: We are going 2,000 on our operated area and working with our partner on their operated area. And our first step is to get to longer laterals and do that. It's my view, Ben, from the information I have that 1,000 pounds per foot is quite common there now. There's been very few people step into the 2,000. I've not personally heard of a 3,500 pound per foot lateral. But it's like all things, we're taking over the operatorship, hiring those personnel into our company, get our proxies [ph] in the field, drilling our first pad starting in October, November. Then we have to work on how long it takes to time wells and go through the field development plan of near infrastructure versus lease timing versus the best wells in the G&G and the best for capital allocation. We're in the middle of doing all that right now. I'm very pleased with this ground floor buildup result, we will be reviewing that in more detail quickly. And so I think that we're going to start at the 2,000-pound per foot and go from there. And then, I think there will be a lot of information from that, and the flow back techniques and various other things that are critical to plays. But our experience of hundreds of wells in the Montney and the Eagle Ford and all types of experimentation around slick water and sand, volumes will bode us well to move in here and really get off the learning curve very quickly, run by 1 single leader in all of our onshore business.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then one more here. Maybe jumping over to the Eagle Ford. You guys have done a great job of lowering costs. Even this year, you guys have put downward pressure on cost. And, I believe, just kind of going around and drilling kind of single one-
componenttext: Got it. And then one more here. Maybe jumping over to the Eagle Ford. You guys have done a great job of lowering costs. Even this year, you guys have put downward pressure on cost. And, I believe, just kind of going around and drilling kind of single one-off well, is there more room there on the cost side of things especially as you guys kind of get back to pad development, or have you kind of squeezed all you can out of that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I keep thinking that it's flattened on the drilling side, but we continue to improve. And you're right, we've had a lease maintenance CapEx and that leads to some of this timing issue on capital in the second quarter, and that's why that that capita
componenttext: Well, I keep thinking that it's flattened on the drilling side, but we continue to improve. And you're right, we've had a lease maintenance CapEx and that leads to some of this timing issue on capital in the second quarter, and that's why that that capital was phased in that way, and that's what the outcome is. But we just drilled a record well last week, we drilled the well in Catarina, over 12,000 feet in 4 days. And I can tell you, that's incredible performance. And so we haven't even gotten to full back pad drilling mode again, and I just see big upside. There is discussions about service cost and the large service players, and that going up et cetera over time. But in the old [ph] operation days, it's a days business. You have to be on wells less days, no matter the cost, and really doing well there right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll take our next question, that will come from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And now we'll take our next question, that will come from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to -- Roger, just wanted to get into a little bit of the well cost. I know you are in some of the new areas. I mean, obviously the Canadian dollar's coming down as well. Industry is doing better. So maybe just on the top of Montney, just any
componenttext: I just wanted to -- Roger, just wanted to get into a little bit of the well cost. I know you are in some of the new areas. I mean, obviously the Canadian dollar's coming down as well. Industry is doing better. So maybe just on the top of Montney, just any updates on well costs and well performance in terms of EUR there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our Tupper, the Tupper Montney that we have, we're looking at costs below CAD 5 million right now total. And EURs there, we've said previously we want to get to 10 to 12 Bcf wells there, and we just did our first big high pumping of sand well, and we're p
componenttext: Our Tupper, the Tupper Montney that we have, we're looking at costs below CAD 5 million right now total. And EURs there, we've said previously we want to get to 10 to 12 Bcf wells there, and we just did our first big high pumping of sand well, and we're pleased with the results there, and think we're going to get there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then in the Duvernay, I mean these sort of 2,000 pound plus longer laterals, I mean, in Canadian, where do you reckon those are going to come in?
componenttext: Right. And then in the Duvernay, I mean these sort of 2,000 pound plus longer laterals, I mean, in Canadian, where do you reckon those are going to come in?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The current wells that we're doing, we inherited wells from a partner, and they are completing them, and they're currently using a -- you got to keep in mind, we just started working there over the last month. So they're using a CAD 9.5 million, which is
componenttext: The current wells that we're doing, we inherited wells from a partner, and they are completing them, and they're currently using a -- you got to keep in mind, we just started working there over the last month. So they're using a CAD 9.5 million, which is USD 7.2 million kind of a charge there. And we know that these fracs went very well, and are under the current completion cost of CAD 5 million, which adds up to that number. And we are looking to drill and complete our own wells in the Kaybob, light oil area and the northern condensate area of what we own for around CAD 7.9 million going in as our goal, which is USD 6 million, and we've been really lowering cost in our Montney, which is 60 miles away from here, learned a lot about that, pad drilling, fracking et cetera. And we believe we can drive these costs down to that level. We're going to set a goal to do that and I believe we'll execute that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I just wanted to just, I mean, I was listening but just to confirm that you feel that the underlying cash flow based on the first half oil prices and ex Syncrude, I guess for the core portfolio in the first half of the year was sort of closer to
componenttext: And then I just wanted to just, I mean, I was listening but just to confirm that you feel that the underlying cash flow based on the first half oil prices and ex Syncrude, I guess for the core portfolio in the first half of the year was sort of closer to $375 million, if I understood that correctly adding back the lease accounts as the rig lease expenditure, have you done that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. And when you take out -- factor out the one-off cost of paying off the rigs that we accrued those cost in the fourth quarter of '15, but paid them in '16, so you exclude that during the $375 million type number for the first 6 months fo
componenttext: Yes, that's right. And when you take out -- factor out the one-off cost of paying off the rigs that we accrued those cost in the fourth quarter of '15, but paid them in '16, so you exclude that during the $375 million type number for the first 6 months for operating cash flow.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now moving to our next question Roger Read with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Now moving to our next question Roger Read with Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I think most of it's been hit, but I guess, maybe one thing to explore here, you've done the asset sales, originally we thought maybe a little more aggressive on the asset side in the lower 48. Recognize valuations may have gotten away a little
componenttext: All right. I think most of it's been hit, but I guess, maybe one thing to explore here, you've done the asset sales, originally we thought maybe a little more aggressive on the asset side in the lower 48. Recognize valuations may have gotten away a little bit there, but is there anything else that looks particularly interesting at this point, other than the obvious of somewhere in Texas that you might want to grow?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably not out of there. I mean, we do have very active business development team at Murphy involved and always repositioning. I don't believe we're in the mode of doing a lot of shrinking right now. We want to keep what we have, but we're not against s
componenttext: Probably not out of there. I mean, we do have very active business development team at Murphy involved and always repositioning. I don't believe we're in the mode of doing a lot of shrinking right now. We want to keep what we have, but we're not against selling and buying and things of that nature. We have a very active team that looks both at all the plays in and around where we're working, and we are seeing some more data rooms and different choices there. And we look at them and study them, and well, we have a pretty high threshold to have strip price return at Murphy here, and we're real proud of our entry cost that we have in our 3 plays that we have.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then thinking about the offshore. I know you don't want to do a whole lot of exploration right now, but we've seen a number of companies sell offshore or attempt to sell offshore. And in some cases, walk away from what were at one time called discover
componenttext: And then thinking about the offshore. I know you don't want to do a whole lot of exploration right now, but we've seen a number of companies sell offshore or attempt to sell offshore. And in some cases, walk away from what were at one time called discovery. So I was wondering are you seeing any value or is this just far too early in the process or oil prices need to be higher to make something happen in the offshore if you decided to go that direction?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're very excited about these opportunities. We do have a very strong execution team in the offshore to operate any kind of facility or drill any kind of well anywhere in the world at any time. And we look at these opportunities. I believe that with
componenttext: No, we're very excited about these opportunities. We do have a very strong execution team in the offshore to operate any kind of facility or drill any kind of well anywhere in the world at any time. And we look at these opportunities. I believe that with the deepwater rigs and the mergers of things like Technip and FMC and Cameron and Schlumberger, et cetera, will lead to opportunity for lower costs there, a new starting point of a development, if you will. And we are poised to look at that where some others who may not have that ability or have no team or ability to look in deepwater kind of leave that behind. So many of those, and we would be looking at those on occasion, but we're pretty selective on it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And now we'll move to a question from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

componenttext: Most of the cash flows in Q2 were really low. Is there a particular -- were there any kind of one-off issues with that? I guess what I'm thinking is that if we're in Q3 with a lower price, I mean, is there a reason to think that cash flows would be stronger?

componenttext: I'll let John answer that, but we have just a real payment of our Accounts Payable during the quarter, Paul. We don't -- we feel confident in our total yearly projection. I'll let John speak to that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did have some items, Paul, that hit in the second quarter that were accrued in prior periods. And that includes significant amount of interest costs, some of our restructuring costs were paid, even though they were accrued for last quarter. So the
componenttext: Yes, we did have some items, Paul, that hit in the second quarter that were accrued in prior periods. And that includes significant amount of interest costs, some of our restructuring costs were paid, even though they were accrued for last quarter. So there is a number of things that lag, if you will. Some of the cost reductions on our LOE are now -- we're, in fact we're see continue going down over time, but we've still paid for some of those in second quarter. So it's a timing matter as to when these bills catch up with the payments. So I don't see anything in particular worrisome with it. And it should balance itself out over time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Understood. Could you give us a sense of the scale of that? Or are you pointing us towards the full year? Is there guidance for cash flow...

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mentioned earlier, Paul, that we on a pro forma basis was $750 million [ph] when you annualize the 6 months doesn't seem crazy. And in fact, we might be a little bit north, we'd be a little bit north of that on our internal projections. Again, sub
componenttext: Well, I mentioned earlier, Paul, that we on a pro forma basis was $750 million [ph] when you annualize the 6 months doesn't seem crazy. And in fact, we might be a little bit north, we'd be a little bit north of that on our internal projections. Again, subject to whatever prices do to us and maybe they won't hold up very well, but we'll see. But interest -- for example, interest in the second quarter was $40 million that we paid on our notes. So it's -- that comes in lump -- in a lumpy fashion because we pay at semiannually instead of monthly or quarterly. So the things of that nature, $10 million -- $9 million plus worth of restructuring costs and things of that nature that were paid this quarter.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. What was the price assumption, do you use the strip for the $750 million [ph]? $50 around 50?
componenttext: Understood. What was the price assumption, do you use the strip for the $750 million [ph]? $50 around 50?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. So it was definitely a one-off kind of thing this quarter, I get it. Roger, the second follow-up question, which is actually on the Duvernay. If you have -- if you feel you could add some more, you're talking about low 30s I think breakeven, i
componenttext: Understood. So it was definitely a one-off kind of thing this quarter, I get it. Roger, the second follow-up question, which is actually on the Duvernay. If you have -- if you feel you could add some more, you're talking about low 30s I think breakeven, is that correct? Could you talk about what sort of parameters you're using there to get to those numbers in terms of all the usual stuff that we need to get there if you're prepared to reveal those, that will be great.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a pretty cautious EUR here. We think this is going to improve over time, but in certain portions of our light area, we're probably close to 700 equivalent type EURs at around 80% liquids. In other parts of the more eastern area of light oil, appro
componenttext: We have a pretty cautious EUR here. We think this is going to improve over time, but in certain portions of our light area, we're probably close to 700 equivalent type EURs at around 80% liquids. In other parts of the more eastern area of light oil, approaching 500,000 equivalents with around 80% liquids there. In the condensate, approaching 800 equivalents at 55% liquids. And then down in the Placid Montney like 750 with 31% of liquids, so we actually see around 42% at this time. So if you take those EURs and get into our ultimate cost of wanting to drill the wells for USD 6.5 to USD 6, I think you'll lead to some pretty high graded returns here. And we also have the infrastructure in place. We have adequate infrastructure built to handle a couple of years of growth here. And like I said earlier in the call, building our ground floor field development plan, we're going to review it in September. And we like it when we bought it, and we love it when we own it now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: What pricing did you get with -- given the infrastructure position?

componenttext: No, this is -- we're going to build our facilities in a way to neatly pull out the NGL and the condensate and the light oil, and we actually get a premium to WTI here. In the first quarter, it's a little bit below the premium due to the shut-in of the -- all of the mining, which you're very familiar with, and but this is a nice situation to WTI. It's definitely not a discount.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: We'll now hear from Guy Baber with Simmons.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to make sure, I understand some of the earlier comments. So just a follow-up here. But is the general framework we should be thinking about is that you can grow in the single-digit percentage rate off your 2016 exit production base, which wi
componenttext: I just wanted to make sure, I understand some of the earlier comments. So just a follow-up here. But is the general framework we should be thinking about is that you can grow in the single-digit percentage rate off your 2016 exit production base, which will be in the mid 160,000-barrel a-day range assuming oil is near $60 a barrel? Is that kind of on the point at which you would consider growing? Do I have that correct?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that, I'm not sure if oil will be in the $60s in '17 right now, so if it's in the $50s, it'd be more stabilizing next year, and that's our goal. And then look to grow, let's say a year from now, when oil -- we hope approaches $60 again. It's a
componenttext: I would say that, I'm not sure if oil will be in the $60s in '17 right now, so if it's in the $50s, it'd be more stabilizing next year, and that's our goal. And then look to grow, let's say a year from now, when oil -- we hope approaches $60 again. It's all about cash flow and the CapEx and oil price, Guy, as you know. But we have modeled a $60 flat price forever in our business that shows post a year from now, we can start having 4% to 5% production growth with these type prices, and we believe in it confidently.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is the framework or is your primary objective still to spend within your cash flow and dividend? So not outspending?
componenttext: And is the framework or is your primary objective still to spend within your cash flow and dividend? So not outspending?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to see how you're thinking about the Block H expansion, as costs have come down globally. Does that impact how you think about timing and incremental capital, can you just give us an update there and how -- if that is kind of above and beyond you
componenttext: I wanted to see how you're thinking about the Block H expansion, as costs have come down globally. Does that impact how you think about timing and incremental capital, can you just give us an update there and how -- if that is kind of above and beyond your growth and free cash flow metrics that you just laid out.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is not going to be a very large CapEx for us, I do not have that off the top of my head as it's been moved out. Our partner, Petronas, is building a floating LNG ship in Korea. Due to capital cutbacks earlier in the year across all industry, across e
componenttext: That is not going to be a very large CapEx for us, I do not have that off the top of my head as it's been moved out. Our partner, Petronas, is building a floating LNG ship in Korea. Due to capital cutbacks earlier in the year across all industry, across every NOCs, they have delayed that ship. It's partially built today. It sits in Korea. It will be coming to us around 2020 to 2021, I believe is the latest. And we have to drill 4, 5 wells there and do the tie back of pipelines. Naturally, if Deepwater costs persist at this level, it will be much lower than we originally envisioned. This is a game, Brian, it's a $50 Brent game to give you the type of gas price to have nice returns here. This would be in our long-range plan program, but would be out in the -- we have agreed with them to delay it, and it's in our assessment. And it's a long way to 2020 from now in my life. So that's the game plan there, and it would count in the numbers I was just talking about with the Guy on phone.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow-up is on decline rates. Can you give us an update on where you see your corporate decline rate? And how do you see that evolving, particularly in some of the shale areas that have received less capital over the last year and then
componenttext: Great. And then my follow-up is on decline rates. Can you give us an update on where you see your corporate decline rate? And how do you see that evolving, particularly in some of the shale areas that have received less capital over the last year and then probably seeing some moderation there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're about a 15% company, Brian, today. I think, as we become more shale focused in the company, if you look at something like the Montney, we believe that a year 1 well's around 20%. A year 2 of that well is 17%, and year 3 around 14%. So not a large de
componenttext: We're about a 15% company, Brian, today. I think, as we become more shale focused in the company, if you look at something like the Montney, we believe that a year 1 well's around 20%. A year 2 of that well is 17%, and year 3 around 14%. So not a large decline there. And of course, Eagle Ford, we probably look at our current spending and growth plans around the 20% in first year, 17% and the second, 14% in the third. That's based off, as you know more than anyone, the timing of first-year second-year third-year shale wells at the declining -- decline rates, if you will. And we organize around that and feel good about the decline rates I just described.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll hear from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.
componenttext: And now we'll hear from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: This is Luana Siegfried in for Pavel. It's a very quick one for me. I know it can be a little bit too early, but if you could share your expectation for the production ramp up in Kaybob and Montney? And also any ballpark figure for the incremental CapEx going forward, that will be great.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Duvernay is going to go to around 50 million for the rest of the year, and a big growth in CapEx there, around 40 this coming quarter. And it's a little bit too early to get into our '17, but if we're able to get our capital in near 200 range, we can get that to 14,000 barrels next year.

componenttext: We are seeing some very high differentials now in $0.95 range, some of that effect. But in the forward curves that are out every day, though diffs are coming down. We do see -- we're looking to do some more hedging volumes now at CAD 3 through 2020. And we're seeing the differentials tighten in the '17, '18, '19 to back to like a more traditional 70% to 75% number -- $0.75 number. There's also an ability to hedge some of those differentials, which we are exploring, and we see that getting tighter. We see like good news and storage today impacting that. And pleased with how that's going, but mostly pleased in our lower LOE, our lower drilling costs and the ability to handle this tariff and blend it in with the company to do really well. So that's the main thing. Got to have those assets.

Good day, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, Jake. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the inform
componenttext:
Good afternoon, Jake. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the information on slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. John will begin by providing a review of the second quarter financial results, highlighting our balance sheet and strong liquidity position, followed by Roger with an operational update and outlook, after which questions will be taken. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussions of risk factors, see Murphy's 2015 annual report on the Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the second quarter of 2016 were a profit of $2.9 million, $0.02 per diluted share. The comparative result from the second quarter of 2015 was a net loss of $73.8 million, whi
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy's consolidated results in the second quarter of 2016 were a profit of $2.9 million, $0.02 per diluted share. The comparative result from the second quarter of 2015 was a net loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share. The improvement in 2016 net results included income tax and other benefits on dispositions of 2 former assets, including the company's 5% interest in Syncrude and the midstream gas processing plants that service the Tupper and Tupper West areas in eastern British Columbia. Excluding discontinued operations, continuing operations had a profit in the second quarter of 2016 of $2.9 million as well and $0.02 a share, and that compares to a loss in the second quarter of 2015 from continuing operations of $89 million or $0.51 per diluted share. 
Second quarter results from continuing operations in '16 included net income tax benefits of $88.9 million from sale of Syncrude and Montney midstream assets. These were mostly noncash tax benefits related to reductions and liabilities for future taxes owed on both of these disposed assets. I'll come back to these taxes and discuss them further in a moment. 
Adjusted earnings, which amend our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of results between periods was a loss of $62.4 million in the second quarter '16 compared to an adjusted net loss of $83.1 million a year ago. The improvement in adjusted results in the 2016 quarter was primarily attributable to lower cost for production, exploration and administrative activities, but these were partially offset by significantly lower oil and natural gas sales prices compared to 1 year ago. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release and amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis with a separate table as to the pretax and income tax impacts by area of operation. 
I now want to discuss further the Canadian transactions in the second quarter. The sale of Montney midstream assets was structured so that no cash taxes will be payable on this transaction. The company had previously recorded deferred tax liabilities for future taxes that were expected to be paid associated with these assets, and due to the structure of the transaction, the previously estimated future taxes will now not be paid so, therefore, in the second quarter, the company reversed these recorded tax liabilities and accordingly recognized the deferred tax benefit of approximately $21 million. 
The Syncrude sale was a taxable transaction, however, it did qualify for capital gain treatment rather than ordinary tax treatment. Therefore, the tax rate was 1/2 of the standard statutory rate and equated to 13.75% rate rather than a normal full rate of 27.5%. The overall net tax benefit of $68 million on the Syncrude disposition was mostly attributable to the reduced capital gain rate applicable to the transaction. Cash taxes applied at capital gains rate to the transaction in the amount of approximately $6 million, while deferred tax benefits were approximately $128 million to reduce future taxes payable, which had previously been accrued at the full tax rate. 
The company completed its entry into the Kaybob Duvernay and liquids-rich Montney areas during the second quarter. The initial spend upon closing the joint venture was $206.7 million plus the company committed approximately another $171 million of future carry for the seller over the next 4 to 5 years of operations. 
The company's cash flow from operations during the second quarter was $70 million. The quarter was impacted by paydown of accounts payable owed to vendors and a semiannual interest owed on outstanding debt borrowings. Since the second quarter was skewed by the timing of these cash payments, I think it is best to look at the 6 months year-to-date for understanding. 
Our first half 2016 cash flow totaled $113 million, and this included payments for canceled Deepwater drilling rig contracts of almost $262 million. In the past years, these costs would have been included as investing activity spend under the category of capital expenditures. However, since the decision was made to cancel these contracts without drilling, these costs have been recorded as cash outflows from operating activities in 2016. 
Looking at the first 6 months without these one-off rig payoffs, operating cash flow would total $375 million and annualizing this amount for a full year for pro forma purposes for 2016, operating cash flow would amount to approximately $750 million over the full 12 months, again, excluding the rig payments. 
The company's second quarter 2016 lease operating expense was lower by approximately $2.50 per barrel of oil equivalent compared to 1 year ago. Beginning in the second quarter of 2016, our average LOE costs include the new tariff associated with Montney area gas plants that were sold. Although these assets were sold above book value, for accounting purposes, the gain has been deferred. Starting in the second quarter 2016, the recorded gas processing cost is reduced to recognize a portion of the deferred gain on the asset sale, and the remainder of this gain will be recognized over the 20-year throughput commitment term. 
The company's second quarter 2016 average realized sales prices for its crude oil production was $44.42 per barrel sold lower by $12 per barrel or 21% compared to the same period in the prior year. 
Natural gas prices also were weaker in quarter 2 compared to the prior year's quarter with average North American gas price realizations of $1.35 per 1,000 cubic feet, a drop of $1.07 per Mcf or a decline of 44%. 
Realized oil index natural gas process offshore Sarawak fell 14% to an average of $3.29 per Mcf due to the decline in global crude oil prices. With crude oil prices improving during the second quarter of this year compared to the first quarter, the fair value of the company's open crude oil derivative contracts fell. Therefore, overall company revenue in the quarter was reduced by $59 million related to a lower mark-to-market fair value for open crude oil contracts. Although this revenue reduction is recorded in the second quarter, the impacts of the change in the fair value of these open contracts is not reflected in the average realized sales prices reported for the quarter, as here, only the actual cash received on contracts that matured during the period are included in the average realized sales prices. 
Our EBITDA and EBITDAX balances in the second quarter were hurt by well over $3 per barrel for the mark to market decline in crude contract value. 
For the remaining 6 months of 2016, the company has WTI based oil price hedges for 25,000 barrels per day at a WTI average price of $50.67 per barrel. Additionally, the company has forward sales contracts for Canadian natural gas in the amount of 99 million cubic feet a day at an average AECO price of CAD 3 per 1,000 cubic feet over the remainder of '16, and we also have future Canadian gas hedges covering 59 million a day at CAD 2.81 per 1,000 cubic feet for the period of 2017 through 2020. 
At the end of the quarter, June 30, 2016, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to $2.44 billion, which equates to 32% of total capital employed, and net debt amounted to 28.5% of the capital employed. Both gross and net debt ratios were significant improvements from the one quarter earlier. As of quarter-end, we had total cash and invested cash of almost $400 million and no outstanding borrowed balance on our $2 billion revolver that matures in June of 2017. We paid our revolving debt balance off in the second quarter using the combined net cash proceeds of approximately $1.15 billion from the Syncrude and Montney midstream dispositions. The company is working closely with our banking syndicate and expects to reach an agreement in the near term on a new revolving credit facility. 
Concludes my comments. And I'll now pass it over to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Looking back at the second quarter 2016 is a pivotal quarter for Murphy's. It marked to the continued repositioning of the company. We're able to close our 2 previousl
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. Looking back at the second quarter 2016 is a pivotal quarter for Murphy's. It marked to the continued repositioning of the company. We're able to close our 2 previously announced key divestitures, our interest in Syncrude, as well as our natural gas processing plants and pipelines servicing our Tupper Montney assets. Proceeds amounted to $1.15 billion, as John mentioned. This allowed us to repay all the borrowings under our revolver and retained almost $400 million of cash in the balance sheet. 
As we closed on our new -- we also closed our new North American unconventional play during the Kaybob Duvernay and Placid Montney at a low-cost upfront entry of USD 207 million. The new asset competes well with any recent North American transaction as we're able to acquire a low-cost entry point on any measure of 2P dollar resource or acreage. We believe that our current diversified asset mix is oil weighted [ph] serves as the base in which we'd be able to recalibrate production and respond to possible lower for longer commodity prices. 
During the quarter, we had an exceptionally low capital spend of $108 million, that's primarily due to timing. This does not include the previously mentioned joint venture purchase. This low rate is not indicative of a quarterly run rate, as we do plan to spend $620 million over the course of 2016, as originally planned and announced in February. Also maintain our annual production guidance when adjusted for asset sales and purchases. 
We're also continuing to lowering cost structure. LOE was down 23% from quarter 2 '15, and G&A down approximately 15% from quarter 2 '15 as well. 
Second quarter production, 168,600 BOE per day was slightly lower than our guidance range when adjusted for sales and purchases. As you recall we stated that, there was a planned maintenance across many of our assets, which is common in quarter 2 for our company as well as natural production declines in Eagle Ford Shale as there were no wells planned, nor were any brought-on in the second quarter. 
Further impacting our second quarter production was Divestitures of Syncrude, Wildfires in Western Canada, and other third-party infrastructure and facility curtailments. We expect that our third quarter production to be flat as compared to second quarter with third quarter guidance in the range of 167,500 to 169,500. The guidance takes into account a long planned 10-day turnaround at the Tupper Montney area at over 2,400 barrel oil equivalent per day. 
The capital program for '16, as I mentioned, is maintained at $620 million plus an additional $207 million attributable to our purchase in the Kaybob and Montney areas. Spending for the first half of the year was roughly 40% of our planned annual CapEx. 
Both annual and third quarter production incorporates the production associated with newly acquired joint venture of Kaybob and Placid and divesture of our interest in Syncrude, as previously announced. With these inclusions, our annual guidance range has not been changed. 
Lease operating expense for second quarter '16 was $8.36 per BOE showing a reduction of over 23% from the second quarter of 2015, a reduction of over 9% for the full year of 2015. Our second quarter 2016 LOE was slightly higher than quarter 1 due to production volumes being lower, as I just mentioned. 
All these operating expenses noted here exclude Syncrude. 
We also made good progress in reducing our G&A costs over the past 12 months through strategic restructuring, workforce reductions approximately 35%. Second quarter G&A is approximately 15% from second quarter '15, and more importantly, we've been able to decrease G&A costs by 23% from first quarter 2015 when we began implementing deliberate cost reduction measures. 
We continue to reposition our portfolio. Our current assets are more streamlined and concentrated than when we became an independent E&P company almost 3 years ago. However, remaining true to our history, we're still a global diversified oil-weighted E&P company. We generate stable cash flow from long-lived conventional reserves, primarily in Malaysia that oil-weighted and priced to Brent along with SK Gas price being priced with oil. We have good positions from ground -- grassroots efforts, pardon me, in 3 premier North American unconventional plays that provide us short cycle growth opportunities following our low-cost entry point. We continue to review our portfolio, and we'll act when opportunities present themselves. 
In our offshore Malaysia business, we're producing our 56,000 BOE per day during the quarter, with natural gas production from Sarawak registering 96 million a day. During the third quarter, we are planning a topside installation at South Acis satellite platform. The wells were drilled earlier this year and expected to start producing in the fourth quarter. This topside installation will allow us to maintain our current SK oil production throughout the year at maximum capacity. 
As part of the improved oil recovery project in Kikeh, we installed the surface jet pump system during the quarter. And now with the successful installation of this system resulting enhanced production, we'll be installing our electrical submersible pump later this year. Further, we are planning a long-term Gas Lift project for this field as well. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, production in the second quarter was approximately 16,600 barrel equivalents per day at 83% liquids. The Kodiak well was in production mid-quarter and is currently producing over 12,500 barrel equivalents per day gross. 
Options are currently being evaluated to co-mingle into an upper zone that are expected to further enhance rates as well as an offset well opportunity. This project has been very successful for us. 
Murphy holds a large acreage position in Southern Australia-Ceduna basin, where we have seismic commitments only. Previously, we have acquired and evaluated seismic across to our acreage, and are pleased with the prospects we have seen. We feel this area could be greatly derisked by drilling that will take place in adjacent blocks where BP and Statoil plans to spud the first of 2 wells this fall. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, second quarter production was 47,500 equivalents per day. As planned, there were no new wells brought online this quarter. However, we did complete 8 wells that are online in the current quarter. These wells are completed ahead of plan to synchronize completion schedules with offset operators and acquire the offset wells to be shut in. In addition to these 8 wells, which are now flowing, there are 22 wells currently scheduled to be brought on during the second half of the year, including 2 Austin Chalk wells, 1 in Karnes and the other testing and our most western acreage in Catarina. 
We continue making strides in decreasing drilling and completion costs, as we average $4 million per well across the play, which is 25% below the $5.0 million per well in the second quarter of '15. We still have significant running room ahead for us here, with over 2,000 potential locations in the Eagle Ford Shale. Reserves are oil weighted at roughly 90%. The asset is very meaningful for Murphy's future reserves production cash flow. 
Over the past several months, we followed progress on 2 prior completed Karnes wells employing high concentrations sand fracs, allowing us to use a more aggressive choke technique. We've employed this technique on 4 more wells recently and plan -- and on plan for more in the third quarter. Initial results are impressive, with a 15% higher EUR and 30% higher IP than offset wells. As stated prior, we shut in offset wells during the completion operations. After we brought these offset wells back online, we experienced an uplift in production from those wells. We look forward to bringing you updates as we move this technique across more of Karnes and into our Tilden area and also Catarina areas later this year. 
We're further testing our stacked zone potential to exists across our acreage position. We're testing a new Austin Chalk well along with 3 upper Eagle Ford wells in Karnes, and our latest high concentrations sand completion program. We're also completing a new Austin Chalk well in the Catarina area. 
In Canada, our Tupper Montney asset produced over 197 million a day for the quarter. There were 10 wells brought online during this quarter, including 2 wells that tested extended laterals and increased proppant per lateral foot in the completion phase. These wells are currently cleaning up with encouraging initial results. We look forward to bringing you updates in the third quarter call. 
As stated earlier, we closed the sale of our Montney natural gas processing plants earlier in the quarter. After including the new tariff associated with the sale, we expect well breakeven cost for a 10% return to be USD 1.65 AECO and LOE for the second quarter was $0.63 per Mcf, which includes the new tariff associated with monetizing Montney processing plants and pipeline.
The greatly reduced drilling and completion costs and higher EURs enable us to easily manage the new tariff and take advantage of the monetization by deploying the proceeds into higher returning assets. Returns are further enhanced for the long-term hedging program out to 2020 as part of our ongoing strategy. 
We closed our previously announced joint venture in the Kaybob Duvernay and Placid Montney area in mid-quarter. We're just getting started on our operatorship with the Kaybob asset and moving forward with development plans for the rest of the year and planning 2017. This time, we are completing a 4-well pad in the condensate area of the play and anticipate flowing these wells very late this quarter or early next. 
We are also picking up the rig and planning to drill a 4-well pad in the lateral area in quarter 4 and hope to have 2 wells drilled by year-end. Our plan in the Kaybob area is to increase lateral lengths over time to 9,000 feet and pump fracs 2,000 pounds per foot of sand, which we feel will lead to higher rates in the area of the play and offer upside for Murphy and our partner. 
In the Placid Montney, we're a nonoperating partner with 30% working interest. The current plan is to drill 12 wells this year. Our drilling has already begun. The first padded wells anticipated to flow late this year. 
As we close our call today, some takeaways. Murphy continues with our plan to reposition the company, stabilize production, and ultimately grow production as oil prices recover. We significantly reduced our 2016 capital program to $620 million as previously announced, and have recalibrated our annual production to 173,000 to 177,000 range after accounting for asset mix changes. 
Our key plays continued performing well in Malaysia and especially in North America and conventional onshore assets, where we have significant upside. We remain focused on our cost structure. We're proud of our plan to not issue equity in the price collapse earlier this year and also during this time, we've been able to further strengthen our balance sheet by lowering debt levels. 
I'd now like to open it up for your questions, and thank you.

componenttext: Our dividends have been historically a long part of our commitment to long-term shareholders here at Murphy. Our dividends are reviewed by the board each quarter, it's a common practice. Its always been our practice also to review our annual dividend policy at our August board meeting, which is scheduled for next week. We'll review our current financial outlook under various price levels and different options of capital allocation, and we're going to present this to the board and discuss it with them next week and announce it at that time.

[Technical Difficulty]

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, if I could, 2 final questions. One, I think in the past, you are talking about petrol production runway for Eagle Ford, and since then that you have raised total EUR for the area that significantly. And now we also have heard that some number falli
componenttext: Roger, if I could, 2 final questions. One, I think in the past, you are talking about petrol production runway for Eagle Ford, and since then that you have raised total EUR for the area that significantly. And now we also have heard that some number falling around talking about operate the gross 100% production say 20,000 barrel per day by 2020 to '21. So I just want to see whether you can confirm are those still the good number, or whether that those have changed. And last question is that under what criteria or that what is the criteria you will look at before you will consider raising your CapEx?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on production, Paul, we have some of the new wells. We've got 4 of the 8 wells we just brought on completed with these new techniques. They're doing very well. And our guidance for the quarter would have that and I would say we would be a little li
componenttext: First, on production, Paul, we have some of the new wells. We've got 4 of the 8 wells we just brought on completed with these new techniques. They're doing very well. And our guidance for the quarter would have that and I would say we would be a little light on our fourth quarter guidance as 2 more of those wells coming on. We have a big third quarter of well adds in Eagle Ford Shale. So hold back on increasing the fourth quarter at this time, we'll do this thing one quarter at a time. I'm not sure about your question about the 20,000 barrels over certain period of time. Murphy is quite confident that when oil recovers into near $60 level that we can achieve single-digit production growth in our company and be free cash flow. We're very confident in that because of the 3 unconventionals we have and our very strong offshore base that we have. And I'm not sure if that calculates into the number that you have, but that's...

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, the 20,000 barrel per day, you was talking about the Duvernay asset?
componenttext: Sorry, the 20,000 barrel per day, you was talking about the Duvernay asset?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes, that is still confirmed. And I think that we're building enough ground for a field development plan from grassroots up there, Paul, with lateral length sand. All the -- and we're about to review that and move forward with that. And as I look at t
componenttext: Oh, yes, that is still confirmed. And I think that we're building enough ground for a field development plan from grassroots up there, Paul, with lateral length sand. All the -- and we're about to review that and move forward with that. And as I look at the probably some additional capital there for '17 than we originally planned. And I believe, we are well on to that number that you mentioned, yes. But that's Duvernay only specific. Yes, so we want to replace the Syncrude production with the Duvernay as fast as we can living inside cash flow CapEx parity, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now, we'll move to a question from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And now, we'll move to a question from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: So maybe I could start out with a little bit of a -- if we start with maintenance CapEx, I think Roger, in the past, you've talked -- and maybe the follow-up to last question, you've talked about some of your ability to hold production flat to 2016's exit and to 2017 potentially around $800 million -- $900 million a year [ph] spend. Given your -- is that correct given your ability to do more with less this year, is that still the right number? Or did that number come down?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it'd be on the lower end to what you just said, Ryan.
componenttext: I think it'd be on the lower end to what you just said, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess as we think about cash allocation, I mean, I think there has been some concern that despite a relatively intriguing Duvernay asset, you may be limited in your ability to allocate material CapEx in that direction in the near term. Ca
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess as we think about cash allocation, I mean, I think there has been some concern that despite a relatively intriguing Duvernay asset, you may be limited in your ability to allocate material CapEx in that direction in the near term. Can you talk about priority to capital allocation in the 2017, and where the Duvernay kind of fits in the pecking order there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we really have a lot of things to choose from an onshore if you look at individual well economics today, our top 2 places will be our Catarina and Karnes area probably over 40% with current May 25 strip prices for Duvernay light oil in the mid-30s t
componenttext: Well, we really have a lot of things to choose from an onshore if you look at individual well economics today, our top 2 places will be our Catarina and Karnes area probably over 40% with current May 25 strip prices for Duvernay light oil in the mid-30s there. And our Placid Montney also in the low 30s. We're going to be probably moving -- we're just reviewing our capital for next year, but it's going to be significant capital and near the [ph] build this production base as I just answered the question for Paul. And we're in the middle of doing our '17 plans, but this is going to -- our unconventional is going to be a lot of our CapEx there, Ryan, as you anticipate. And we're very pleased with the places I have to allocate capital, I want to add more competition for capital allocation. I'm going to do so, and we're going to be getting this CapEx up in Duvernay shale to see what we have there pretty quick.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we will hear from Ben Wyatt with Stephens.
componenttext: And next we will hear from Ben Wyatt with Stephens.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can have a follow-up here to kind of the Duvernay question that was asked. As you guys kind of get after it here in the back half, just trying to get a sense of maybe the pace of progress or the pace of change in how you guys complete wells. I believ
componenttext: If I can have a follow-up here to kind of the Duvernay question that was asked. As you guys kind of get after it here in the back half, just trying to get a sense of maybe the pace of progress or the pace of change in how you guys complete wells. I believe I saw on the slide deck, where you're going to kind of start out at 2,000 pounds a lateral foot. I think people have gotten this high as about 3,500 pounds per lateral foot. Just curious how you guys are thinking about that. Or for the back half of '16, do you just kind of stay at a pretty standard completion technique?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are going 2,000 on our operated area and working with our partner on their operated area. And our first step is to get to longer laterals and do that. It's my view, Ben, from the information I have that 1,000 pounds per foot is quite common there now.
componenttext: We are going 2,000 on our operated area and working with our partner on their operated area. And our first step is to get to longer laterals and do that. It's my view, Ben, from the information I have that 1,000 pounds per foot is quite common there now. There's been very few people step into the 2,000. I've not personally heard of a 3,500 pound per foot lateral. But it's like all things, we're taking over the operatorship, hiring those personnel into our company, get our proxies [ph] in the field, drilling our first pad starting in October, November. Then we have to work on how long it takes to time wells and go through the field development plan of near infrastructure versus lease timing versus the best wells in the G&G and the best for capital allocation. We're in the middle of doing all that right now. I'm very pleased with this ground floor buildup result, we will be reviewing that in more detail quickly. And so I think that we're going to start at the 2,000-pound per foot and go from there. And then, I think there will be a lot of information from that, and the flow back techniques and various other things that are critical to plays. But our experience of hundreds of wells in the Montney and the Eagle Ford and all types of experimentation around slick water and sand, volumes will bode us well to move in here and really get off the learning curve very quickly, run by 1 single leader in all of our onshore business.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then one more here. Maybe jumping over to the Eagle Ford. You guys have done a great job of lowering costs. Even this year, you guys have put downward pressure on cost. And, I believe, just kind of going around and drilling kind of single one-
componenttext: Got it. And then one more here. Maybe jumping over to the Eagle Ford. You guys have done a great job of lowering costs. Even this year, you guys have put downward pressure on cost. And, I believe, just kind of going around and drilling kind of single one-off well, is there more room there on the cost side of things especially as you guys kind of get back to pad development, or have you kind of squeezed all you can out of that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I keep thinking that it's flattened on the drilling side, but we continue to improve. And you're right, we've had a lease maintenance CapEx and that leads to some of this timing issue on capital in the second quarter, and that's why that that capita
componenttext: Well, I keep thinking that it's flattened on the drilling side, but we continue to improve. And you're right, we've had a lease maintenance CapEx and that leads to some of this timing issue on capital in the second quarter, and that's why that that capital was phased in that way, and that's what the outcome is. But we just drilled a record well last week, we drilled the well in Catarina, over 12,000 feet in 4 days. And I can tell you, that's incredible performance. And so we haven't even gotten to full back pad drilling mode again, and I just see big upside. There is discussions about service cost and the large service players, and that going up et cetera over time. But in the old [ph] operation days, it's a days business. You have to be on wells less days, no matter the cost, and really doing well there right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll take our next question, that will come from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And now we'll take our next question, that will come from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to -- Roger, just wanted to get into a little bit of the well cost. I know you are in some of the new areas. I mean, obviously the Canadian dollar's coming down as well. Industry is doing better. So maybe just on the top of Montney, just any
componenttext: I just wanted to -- Roger, just wanted to get into a little bit of the well cost. I know you are in some of the new areas. I mean, obviously the Canadian dollar's coming down as well. Industry is doing better. So maybe just on the top of Montney, just any updates on well costs and well performance in terms of EUR there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our Tupper, the Tupper Montney that we have, we're looking at costs below CAD 5 million right now total. And EURs there, we've said previously we want to get to 10 to 12 Bcf wells there, and we just did our first big high pumping of sand well, and we're p
componenttext: Our Tupper, the Tupper Montney that we have, we're looking at costs below CAD 5 million right now total. And EURs there, we've said previously we want to get to 10 to 12 Bcf wells there, and we just did our first big high pumping of sand well, and we're pleased with the results there, and think we're going to get there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then in the Duvernay, I mean these sort of 2,000 pound plus longer laterals, I mean, in Canadian, where do you reckon those are going to come in?
componenttext: Right. And then in the Duvernay, I mean these sort of 2,000 pound plus longer laterals, I mean, in Canadian, where do you reckon those are going to come in?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The current wells that we're doing, we inherited wells from a partner, and they are completing them, and they're currently using a -- you got to keep in mind, we just started working there over the last month. So they're using a CAD 9.5 million, which is
componenttext: The current wells that we're doing, we inherited wells from a partner, and they are completing them, and they're currently using a -- you got to keep in mind, we just started working there over the last month. So they're using a CAD 9.5 million, which is USD 7.2 million kind of a charge there. And we know that these fracs went very well, and are under the current completion cost of CAD 5 million, which adds up to that number. And we are looking to drill and complete our own wells in the Kaybob, light oil area and the northern condensate area of what we own for around CAD 7.9 million going in as our goal, which is USD 6 million, and we've been really lowering cost in our Montney, which is 60 miles away from here, learned a lot about that, pad drilling, fracking et cetera. And we believe we can drive these costs down to that level. We're going to set a goal to do that and I believe we'll execute that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I just wanted to just, I mean, I was listening but just to confirm that you feel that the underlying cash flow based on the first half oil prices and ex Syncrude, I guess for the core portfolio in the first half of the year was sort of closer to
componenttext: And then I just wanted to just, I mean, I was listening but just to confirm that you feel that the underlying cash flow based on the first half oil prices and ex Syncrude, I guess for the core portfolio in the first half of the year was sort of closer to $375 million, if I understood that correctly adding back the lease accounts as the rig lease expenditure, have you done that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. And when you take out -- factor out the one-off cost of paying off the rigs that we accrued those cost in the fourth quarter of '15, but paid them in '16, so you exclude that during the $375 million type number for the first 6 months fo
componenttext: Yes, that's right. And when you take out -- factor out the one-off cost of paying off the rigs that we accrued those cost in the fourth quarter of '15, but paid them in '16, so you exclude that during the $375 million type number for the first 6 months for operating cash flow.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now moving to our next question Roger Read with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Now moving to our next question Roger Read with Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I think most of it's been hit, but I guess, maybe one thing to explore here, you've done the asset sales, originally we thought maybe a little more aggressive on the asset side in the lower 48. Recognize valuations may have gotten away a little
componenttext: All right. I think most of it's been hit, but I guess, maybe one thing to explore here, you've done the asset sales, originally we thought maybe a little more aggressive on the asset side in the lower 48. Recognize valuations may have gotten away a little bit there, but is there anything else that looks particularly interesting at this point, other than the obvious of somewhere in Texas that you might want to grow?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably not out of there. I mean, we do have very active business development team at Murphy involved and always repositioning. I don't believe we're in the mode of doing a lot of shrinking right now. We want to keep what we have, but we're not against s
componenttext: Probably not out of there. I mean, we do have very active business development team at Murphy involved and always repositioning. I don't believe we're in the mode of doing a lot of shrinking right now. We want to keep what we have, but we're not against selling and buying and things of that nature. We have a very active team that looks both at all the plays in and around where we're working, and we are seeing some more data rooms and different choices there. And we look at them and study them, and well, we have a pretty high threshold to have strip price return at Murphy here, and we're real proud of our entry cost that we have in our 3 plays that we have.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then thinking about the offshore. I know you don't want to do a whole lot of exploration right now, but we've seen a number of companies sell offshore or attempt to sell offshore. And in some cases, walk away from what were at one time called discover
componenttext: And then thinking about the offshore. I know you don't want to do a whole lot of exploration right now, but we've seen a number of companies sell offshore or attempt to sell offshore. And in some cases, walk away from what were at one time called discovery. So I was wondering are you seeing any value or is this just far too early in the process or oil prices need to be higher to make something happen in the offshore if you decided to go that direction?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're very excited about these opportunities. We do have a very strong execution team in the offshore to operate any kind of facility or drill any kind of well anywhere in the world at any time. And we look at these opportunities. I believe that with
componenttext: No, we're very excited about these opportunities. We do have a very strong execution team in the offshore to operate any kind of facility or drill any kind of well anywhere in the world at any time. And we look at these opportunities. I believe that with the deepwater rigs and the mergers of things like Technip and FMC and Cameron and Schlumberger, et cetera, will lead to opportunity for lower costs there, a new starting point of a development, if you will. And we are poised to look at that where some others who may not have that ability or have no team or ability to look in deepwater kind of leave that behind. So many of those, and we would be looking at those on occasion, but we're pretty selective on it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And now we'll move to a question from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

componenttext: Most of the cash flows in Q2 were really low. Is there a particular -- were there any kind of one-off issues with that? I guess what I'm thinking is that if we're in Q3 with a lower price, I mean, is there a reason to think that cash flows would be stronger?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I'll let John answer that, but we have just a real payment of our Accounts Payable during the quarter, Paul. We don't -- we feel confident in our total yearly projection. I'll let John speak to that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did have some items, Paul, that hit in the second quarter that were accrued in prior periods. And that includes significant amount of interest costs, some of our restructuring costs were paid, even though they were accrued for last quarter. So the
componenttext: Yes, we did have some items, Paul, that hit in the second quarter that were accrued in prior periods. And that includes significant amount of interest costs, some of our restructuring costs were paid, even though they were accrued for last quarter. So there is a number of things that lag, if you will. Some of the cost reductions on our LOE are now -- we're, in fact we're see continue going down over time, but we've still paid for some of those in second quarter. So it's a timing matter as to when these bills catch up with the payments. So I don't see anything in particular worrisome with it. And it should balance itself out over time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Understood. Could you give us a sense of the scale of that? Or are you pointing us towards the full year? Is there guidance for cash flow...

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mentioned earlier, Paul, that we on a pro forma basis was $750 million [ph] when you annualize the 6 months doesn't seem crazy. And in fact, we might be a little bit north, we'd be a little bit north of that on our internal projections. Again, sub
componenttext: Well, I mentioned earlier, Paul, that we on a pro forma basis was $750 million [ph] when you annualize the 6 months doesn't seem crazy. And in fact, we might be a little bit north, we'd be a little bit north of that on our internal projections. Again, subject to whatever prices do to us and maybe they won't hold up very well, but we'll see. But interest -- for example, interest in the second quarter was $40 million that we paid on our notes. So it's -- that comes in lump -- in a lumpy fashion because we pay at semiannually instead of monthly or quarterly. So the things of that nature, $10 million -- $9 million plus worth of restructuring costs and things of that nature that were paid this quarter.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Understood. What was the price assumption, do you use the strip for the $750 million [ph]? $50 around 50?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. So it was definitely a one-off kind of thing this quarter, I get it. Roger, the second follow-up question, which is actually on the Duvernay. If you have -- if you feel you could add some more, you're talking about low 30s I think breakeven, i
componenttext: Understood. So it was definitely a one-off kind of thing this quarter, I get it. Roger, the second follow-up question, which is actually on the Duvernay. If you have -- if you feel you could add some more, you're talking about low 30s I think breakeven, is that correct? Could you talk about what sort of parameters you're using there to get to those numbers in terms of all the usual stuff that we need to get there if you're prepared to reveal those, that will be great.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a pretty cautious EUR here. We think this is going to improve over time, but in certain portions of our light area, we're probably close to 700 equivalent type EURs at around 80% liquids. In other parts of the more eastern area of light oil, appro
componenttext: We have a pretty cautious EUR here. We think this is going to improve over time, but in certain portions of our light area, we're probably close to 700 equivalent type EURs at around 80% liquids. In other parts of the more eastern area of light oil, approaching 500,000 equivalents with around 80% liquids there. In the condensate, approaching 800 equivalents at 55% liquids. And then down in the Placid Montney like 750 with 31% of liquids, so we actually see around 42% at this time. So if you take those EURs and get into our ultimate cost of wanting to drill the wells for USD 6.5 to USD 6, I think you'll lead to some pretty high graded returns here. And we also have the infrastructure in place. We have adequate infrastructure built to handle a couple of years of growth here. And like I said earlier in the call, building our ground floor field development plan, we're going to review it in September. And we like it when we bought it, and we love it when we own it now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: What pricing did you get with -- given the infrastructure position?
