headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a follow-up on some previous comments from earlier this year. I mean I think you've spoken in the past about I think maybe in the $50 oil, about 2017 volume is holding flat with 4Q '16 levels if I've got that roughly right. Maybe this is quibbling o
componenttext: Maybe a follow-up on some previous comments from earlier this year. I mean I think you've spoken in the past about I think maybe in the $50 oil, about 2017 volume is holding flat with 4Q '16 levels if I've got that roughly right. Maybe this is quibbling over details, but can you -- well, when I think about where volumes go from here, is that like inclusive of the shut-in volumes in Malaysia? Because they're a little bit lower than we would've expected, I guess, in Q4. Is that kind of based on what a normalized run rate would be assuming Kikeh is back up and running? And is it still realistic to think, is that still an accurate way to think about your volumes, they've kind of stabilizing at these levels and then looking to grow from there?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have all the optionality around doing what we want to do on that with our capital, and like I spoke to earlier in the call, we have to consider big unconventional assets, that's new, that we're happy about, that we need to work on as well, that will ne
componenttext: We have all the optionality around doing what we want to do on that with our capital, and like I spoke to earlier in the call, we have to consider big unconventional assets, that's new, that we're happy about, that we need to work on as well, that will need a ramp-up. And I think that third to fourth quarter in there is a good description of the goal there, and then capital allocation options around that versus other things will be the focus of our budgeting, which we're working on now. So you're right, the fourth quarter is pulled back by a one-off shut-in here that's been planned for well over a year. It's done very well with the recovery of that. So that will be the way I'd describe it at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are we likely to see any exploration -- any offshore exploration in 2017?
componenttext: Okay. And are we likely to see any exploration -- any offshore exploration in 2017?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it gets back to that same old question about the production and the capital. And of course, we have opportunities there in many of them. I do not see it as a big capital allocation. And it is, again, one of the options I have on the table at this ti
componenttext: Well, it gets back to that same old question about the production and the capital. And of course, we have opportunities there in many of them. I do not see it as a big capital allocation. And it is, again, one of the options I have on the table at this time that we're really working on as to capital allocation between Duvernay, our Eagle Ford Shale, offshore projects that have very, very high rates of return on existing facilities and concepts of that in our business as well. That's what makes it -- that's why it takes till January, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on Eagle Ford. The first is can you talk about the trajectory as you begin to ramp or get more wells online in the Eagle Ford, what the impact would be, and how we should look at the oil mix in the Eagle Ford? And I've got another fo
componenttext: A couple of questions on Eagle Ford. The first is can you talk about the trajectory as you begin to ramp or get more wells online in the Eagle Ford, what the impact would be, and how we should look at the oil mix in the Eagle Ford? And I've got another follow-up there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking now that being slightly higher than it was this year, flat. We want to have a flat production business there long term that delivers free cash. And we have a model to do so and real happy to do so. As to the oil amount, I mean, you really as
componenttext: We're looking now that being slightly higher than it was this year, flat. We want to have a flat production business there long term that delivers free cash. And we have a model to do so and real happy to do so. As to the oil amount, I mean, you really ask a lot of questions on that issue. We're an oil-weighted company in there and very, very high oil-weighted. And in our comparisons from quarter-to-quarter, you have many, many issues going on there. You have some old historic wells, in which they would have some level of GOR creep [ph] I guess to them. But primarily what this is about is drilling our core acreage. And when we only drill 50 wells and we used to drill 150, we're drilling them near our facilities and capturing more gas than we used to capture. And we used to drill more on the peripheral parts of the field with multiple rigs running, and we work firing some of that gas, and we're not gathering all that gas. We're gathering more gas, and we've cut back on a lot of new wells that we used to drill. And 1% or 2% change off that is not a long-term factor, and we're very comfortable with the 89 type percent liquids in that business in which we also enjoy very little NGLs on that business. And our long-range plan and all of our PVT and all the work from 800 wells are not leading to a collapse on our liquid volumes in the Eagle Ford Shale at all.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the follow-up is just on the capital cost side. Specifically, as you're talking at some of the services companies, it's about getting more aggressive from a completions perspective. At a minimum, can you talk about the feedback that you're
componenttext: Great. And then the follow-up is just on the capital cost side. Specifically, as you're talking at some of the services companies, it's about getting more aggressive from a completions perspective. At a minimum, can you talk about the feedback that you're hearing and your expectations for cost trends as you go into '17?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're real happy about where that's going. Keep in mind that in a business like Eagle Ford Shale, before you get involved with the service companies, is that we have -- now we're looking at 7.9 days to drill a Karnes well now. It used to be 13 in 2015. Th
componenttext: We're real happy about where that's going. Keep in mind that in a business like Eagle Ford Shale, before you get involved with the service companies, is that we have -- now we're looking at 7.9 days to drill a Karnes well now. It used to be 13 in 2015. The Catarina well used to be 9.3 and now it's 7.3. So we've lowered drilling per field, in East Tilden 60%; Catarina, 75%; Tilden, 47%; Karnes, 85%. This is from the last 5 years. So -- and then the last 2, incredible continuation of efficiency here on the wells. From a service perspective, we have a frac crew lined up for the entire year and are outbidding for spud crews as we need. They are about 50% less than they were in 2014 to accomplish these services. We feel firm about the contract that we have to deliver our fracturing services in Eagle Ford. We have a rig there that doesn't expire for some time until late next year. And we're seeing spot rigs in there for 15,000 a day to add additional rig, and we're probably got a couple of rigs in that play. And I'm happy with the procurement and the bidding structure that we have to go through '17 and are able to maintain our cost, and that's not one of our main concerns in our budgeting at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question will come from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question will come from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a specific and a general. The specific, you seem to be a little bit coy about the Duvernay. Can you just talk a little bit more about -- I mean, I know you said it's kind of in line with your expectations. But we see this as a differentiated area f
componenttext: I have a specific and a general. The specific, you seem to be a little bit coy about the Duvernay. Can you just talk a little bit more about -- I mean, I know you said it's kind of in line with your expectations. But we see this as a differentiated area for you. Could you just remind us why you're differentiated there and what the outlook is for activity? I know that you've partly addressed some of these questions earlier in the coal, but if you could just be again more specific on Duvernay, that would be great.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I'm not coy about it at all. I'm real happy with the EUR curves we're seeing, well like, many, many wells in the Eagle Ford Shale or across plays in North America that deliver around 450,000 or 500,000 barrels, and we're looking very positive toward d
componenttext: Oh, I'm not coy about it at all. I'm real happy with the EUR curves we're seeing, well like, many, many wells in the Eagle Ford Shale or across plays in North America that deliver around 450,000 or 500,000 barrels, and we're looking very positive toward doing that and tying up a very 1 barrel per feet of horizontal length there. So it's going well, and those are the type of EURs we anticipated coming out of the well. We flowed the well for 40 days, still have a well on a very low choke. So I'm happy about how much it cost to frac it. I'm happy about where we're headed to drill the next 2 wells and how that will incredibly add value to us. And the CGR is a big deal, 100 units in that game is big, and we have drawn some lines as to what we felt CGR would be and it's better. And just have limited data and only flowed for 40 days, but from what I'm seeing, I'm real happy about how we evaluated and I'm very happy about how the well's performing. I just have 4 wells, and in the Eagle Ford, I have 798 or something like that. So from a differentiated perspective, I mean, we purchased the asset for $9 per foot. It's quite low. Massive [Audio Gap] volatile. What's that?

componenttext: No. So I feel we're very differentiated there because we're in a very low entry point across incredible amount of acreage we can delineate black oil, volatile oil and we can always go into the gas condensate area, which has been derisked by peers and doing very well there. And I see this as a very unique opportunity for us, but just like everything else, we have to get in there, get capital in there. And if the EURs are the same, we have some very prolific EURs coming on the next well, for example, higher than we have in the Eagle Ford. And so the EUR from a daily perspective, I'm very happy about. And we just got to get the drilling costs lower, and I'm really excited about being able to do it, because I've done it everywhere else we've been. And the same people, supervising it, same team, and we're going to do it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

I wondered where do you consider now the oil price breakeven for you guys to be I guess x growth? And what are your aspirations for what would be an appropriate or attractive level of growth for you to achieve beyond that? And at what price do you think you can achieve that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure on the breakeven question as that would change my budget as to what I do. I don't think of it that way. I think of our company as a $50 type -- or let's just say the strip for '17 and a $60 company going forward, $60 flat that would be escala
componenttext: I'm not sure on the breakeven question as that would change my budget as to what I do. I don't think of it that way. I think of our company as a $50 type -- or let's just say the strip for '17 and a $60 company going forward, $60 flat that would be escalated like many peers use that type of number. And we desire to be a single-digit growth -- production growth. Feel we can do that with the assets we have certainly and deliver free cash. And that's the long range plan that I have in front of me, and that's what we're working to obtain and feel good about that like everyone else. I would need oil to go up from where it is today. And when it does, Murphy will be very well positioned with the assets that we have.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Right. Apart from the plants, using these for now, I just want to ask you a specific question about where your maintenance capital would be? Do you think -- would it be around flat for '17 and '18? Or is that never moving?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we've said 8.50, 9.50 in the past. And the issue will be the new unconventional game we're in with no ducks there, which is a Ground Zero, which is not easy to do inside that. But we have an ability to move capital around for different production area
componenttext: No, we've said 8.50, 9.50 in the past. And the issue will be the new unconventional game we're in with no ducks there, which is a Ground Zero, which is not easy to do inside that. But we have an ability to move capital around for different production areas back to Ryan's question a few minutes ago. And that would be about the same as in the past. And it gets back into working on our budget and what we wanted to about the new unconventional asset and high rate of returns, specific projects in the offshore, which are not enormous capital, but every capital amount is precious now more than ever before. So that 8.50, 9.50 that I said in the past is maintained in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a very one-off strange occurrence, I will say because it's been an enormous capital spend by that party, and they still have a very large commitments there. So I'm not sure what's going to happen with that for now. We're a totally different sit
componenttext: Well, it's a very one-off strange occurrence, I will say because it's been an enormous capital spend by that party, and they still have a very large commitments there. So I'm not sure what's going to happen with that for now. We're a totally different situation. We do not have a well commitment there. To our east there is a very large acreage position that Chevron holds also with drilling commitments. They're quite large and rigs to be moved there, et cetera. Also in blocks next door to us, which BP has left, and Statoil remains their partner, which they formed in with BP at the time, so it's a very unique circumstance, I just know that we have some very large prospects and many of them on our block. It would be preferable for Murphy someone to drill next door. But I feel in things like this that there will be a well drilled down there by some of these folks at some period of time. And we will be there to take advantage of that at that time. And all I know is the blocks we have and the data we have and the prospectivity that we have is very good. And in the short term, it's hurtful for them to pull out, but overall it's just a long-term game and we're in this thing for very low amount of capital.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations and Com
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the information on slides we
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please refer to the information on slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. John will begin by providing a review of third quarter financial results, highlighting our balance sheet and strong liquidity position; followed by Roger with an operational update and outlook, after which, questions will be taken.
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2015 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
I now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone on the call. Murphy's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2016 were a net loss of $16.2 million or $0.09 per diluted share. The comparative result from the same quarter in 2015 was a net loss of $1
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone on the call. Murphy's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2016 were a net loss of $16.2 million or $0.09 per diluted share. The comparative result from the same quarter in 2015 was a net loss of $1.6 billion or $9.26 per diluted share. Prior year quarter included a pretax impairment charge of $2.3 billion associated with oil prices that were weakening a year ago. Excluding the impairment in the prior year, operating results in the 2016 third quarter were improved compared to 2015 due to lower operating expenses and lower administrative expenses that more than offset lower oil and gas sales prices.
Excluding discontinued operations, continuing operations had a net loss of $14.6 million in the third quarter or $0.08 per diluted share.
Adjusted earnings, which normalize our quarterly results for various items that affect comparability between periods, was a net loss of $31.7 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to an adjusted net loss of $124.5 million a year ago. This improvement in adjusted results in the 2016 quarter was primarily attributable to lower cost per production, exploration and administrative activities, but these were partially offset by somewhat lower oil and natural gas sales prices compared to last year.
Our third quarter 2016 lease operating expense, excluding Syncrude, which has been sold, was lower by approximately $0.44 per barrel of oil equivalent compared to a year ago. We have continued to bring down our operating cost due to efficiency improvements, aggressive rebidding of services and onetime benefits from operated and nonoperated fields.
Our third quarter 2016 average realized sales price for crude oil production was $44.64 per barrel sold, and that's 3% lower than the same period in the prior year. Natural gas prices also were weaker in quarter 3 compared to the prior year's quarter with average North American gas price realizations of $1.96 per thousand cubic feet, a drop of $0.46 per Mcf or a decline of 19%.
Realized oil index natural gas prices offshore Sarawak fell 20% to an average of $3.01 per Mcf due to decline in global crude oil prices between periods.
For the remaining 3 months of 2016, we have WTI-based oil sales contracts that hedged 25,000 barrels per day at a WTI average fixed price of $50.67 per barrel. Additionally, we have forward sales contracts for Canadian natural gas in the amount of 99 million cubic feet per day at an average AECO fixed price of CAD 3 per thousand feet over the remainder of 2016.
For subsequent years, we also have WTI contracts for 18,000 barrels per day in 2017 at an average price of $50.66 per barrel. Plus we have Canadian gas forward sales contracts covering 99 million cubic feet a day at CAD 2.89 per thousand cubic feet for 2017 plus 59 million cubic feet a day at CAD 2.81 for 2018 through 2020.
As previously announced, in the third quarter, we reduced our quarterly dividend from $0.35 per share to $0.25 per share, thereby reducing our annualized distribution by approximately $69 million per year.
At September 30, 2016, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to $2.97 billion, representing 36.9% of total capital employed.
Excluding capital leases, total debt was $2.8 billion. Net debt at the quarter end amounted to 29.5%.
Also as of quarter end, we had total cash and invested cash of $871 million and no outstanding borrowed balance on our revolving credit facilities, providing us ample liquidity for the future.
We currently anticipate that fourth quarter oil sales volumes will be approximately 13,000 barrels per day below our average daily production. This is due to the periodic timing of offshore oil listings primarily for our operations in Malaysia. The lifting schedule calls for 4 liftings from offshore storage facilities during the first week of January, 3 of these occur in the first 2 days of the new year, and these account for the noted reduction in sales volumes in the fourth quarter compared to production.
In August, we successfully completed a new $1.2 billion 3-year unsecured credit facility and also issued $550 million of 8-year notes at a coupon rate of 6.875%, with these notes maturing in 2024. Further details regarding these financial transactions may be found in our 8-K reports filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on August 12 and August 17.
And that concludes my comments. I'd like now to turn it back over to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good afternoon everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. We had a solid quarter operationally across our business. Our legacy offshore fields achieved just over $30 per BOE cash margin, and our onshore business achieved c
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good afternoon everybody, and thanks for listening to our call today. We had a solid quarter operationally across our business. Our legacy offshore fields achieved just over $30 per BOE cash margin, and our onshore business achieved continued success in pulling high sand concentration fracs in the Eagle Ford Shale and Tupper Montney. Furthermore, we brought on our first 4 well pad in our new Kaybob Duvernay asset and are encouraged by the early results.
On the expense side, we continued lowering our cost structure. During the quarter, our capital expenditures were $172 million and year-to-date are $429 million, in line with our 2016 previously announced capital expenditure program of $620 million.
As John mentioned, we were also successful in  obtaining our new unsecured revolver and issued a new bond, which allows for continued flexibility, ample liquidity and continued preservation of our balance sheet. We also adjusted our dividend while remaining top quartile dividend yield. We believe there are current diversified oil-weighted asset mix such as the foundation which will be able to recalibrate production, forming a new base in which to grow in the future.
Third quarter production is just over 169,800 barrel equivalents per day, which exceeded the high end of our production guidance. The higher third quarter production is largely attributable to better-than-planned performance and facility uptime in Sabah, Malaysia as well as offshore Canada and the Gulf of Mexico. We expect our fourth quarter production will be in the range of 162,000 to 164,000-barrel equivalents a day. Our fourth quarter guidance takes into account the following: a planned 10-day shut-in at Kikeh and Siakap North Petai fields in Malaysia; and also in Malaysia, a planned 2-day shut-in at our Sarawak oil and gas field, where we changed out our field-based FSO. These 2 major shut-ins account for nearly 5,000 barrel equivalents of production this quarter from downtime and risked well recovery. Both of these major shut-ins have now been completed on time, and we're very pleased with the recovery, especially in the Kikeh wells and the facility following the first major shut-in in the field's 9-year history. As expected, we will have some fuel decline, frac impact and small field shut-in across our business as well as positive production impacts in our Canadian business from quarter-to-quarter.
The capital program for 2016 is maintained at $620 million as I've just said. However, there's a change in allocation as more capital is being allocated toward our Eagle Ford Shale business at the end of the year, where we place additional wells online.
The fourth quarter production guidance is 162 to 164 due to impacts of our shut-ins as I previously discussed, and our annual production range has been tightened to [Audio Gap} 174,000 to 175,000 equivalents per day within guidance, post divestitures and purchases announced earlier this year. Our lease operating expense for the first 9 months of '16 is $7.83 per BOE, showing an 18% reduction from the same period a year ago. Our quarter 3 LOE was $7.65 as compared to $8.09 per BOE in quarter 3 '15. All LOE expenses noted exclude Syncrude. We also made good progress, and the team reduced our G&A cost over the year. Third quarter G&A is down approximately 24% from the first quarter of '16. More importantly, we've been able to decrease G&A about 36% from the first quarter of 2015 when we began implementing deliberate cost reduction measures.
Our current assets are more streamlined and concentrated when we became an independent E&P company 3 years ago. However, remaining true to our strategy, we'll still maintain a global diversified oil-weighted E&P company. We build positions from grassroots efforts in [Audio Gap Ends] 3 premier North American unconventional plays that provide short cycle growth opportunities following our low cost entry points. We continue to review our portfolio, and we'll act when opportunities present themselves.
We generate free cash flow from our long-lived offshore conventional fields that are oil-weighted and priced to Brent.
In our offshore Malaysia business, we produced over 39,000 barrels of liquids per day during the quarter, with natural gas production from Sarawak at 116 million a day. We successfully installed a second platform in our South Acis field as part of the original field development plan. The resource size of the field is doubled since it came online in December of '13. As part of the improved oil recovery project at Kikeh, we installed a surface jet pump system, which is in the first -- which is our first of 3 planned improved oil recovery projects for the field. Over the course of the next couple of years, we're going to install an electrical submersible pump followed by a gas lift project on our Kikeh spar. 
In the Gulf of Mexico and East Coast Canada, production for the third quarter was 25,000-barrel equivalents per day at 89% liquids. Subsequent to quarter-end, the Kodiak field received gain -- Kodiak field recently gained approval to co mingle production between reservoirs and expecting additional zone to be online by year-end.
We've maintained our offshore capabilities and continued its focused evaluation in the Gulf of Mexico, Vulcan and Ceduna basins of Australia, Malaysia and Vietnam. We believe that our offshore execution abilities serve as a competitive advantage and allow for assessment and entry into discovered resource opportunities that we could access through expanding alliances with other operators.
The Eagle Ford Shale third quarter production result was just over 46,000-barrel equivalents to date comprised of 87% liquids. The 23 new wells brought online in the quarter included 2 in Austin Chalk and 4 Upper Eagle Ford wells. In the fourth quarter, the company expects to bring online 17 wells, including 2 Austin Chalk wells and 2 Upper Eagle Ford wells.
The fourth quarter online wells is an increase of 10 from previous guidance, with the majority planned for very late in the quarter. Due to timing, they will have minimal impact on 2016 production.
We continue making strides in decreasing drilling and completion costs as we average $4.3 million per well across the entire play, which is 18% below the $5.3 million per well in the third quarter of '15. We drilled pacesetter wells in both our Karnes and Catarina areas. The spud-to-TD for Karnes is 7.9 days versus 13 in 2015, a 39% reduction. In Catarina, it was 7.3 versus 9.3 in 2015, a 21% reduction. We still have significant running room ahead for us there with over 2,000 potential Eagle Ford Shale locations. Our reserves are oil-weighted at roughly 9%. This asset is very meaningful to Murphy's future reserves production and cash flow.
We've continued to employ high sand concentration fracs over this last quarter, which have continued to yield higher IP rates and enhanced type curves. In our Karnes area, recent IP rates have been up to 50% higher. We've seen 1 year cumulative oil rates over 35% higher in our older vintage wells.
In our Catarina area, recent IP30 rates have exceeded the type curve by up to 17%. We're now forecasting increased EURs of high sand concentration fracs and are in the evaluation phase as to the EUR increases.
In the quarter, we completed our second Austin Chalk well in the Karnes area and tested boundaries, the Austin Chalk resource. And the first Austin Chalk well is completed in what I'd describe as a wildcat test in our Catarina areas. Both wells are flowing and still in the clean up phase, and we'll bring more information on our fourth quarter call.
In Canada, our Tupper Montney asset produced about 119 million a day for the third quarter. We are pleased with the performance of our recent extended lateral high sand concentration wells that were brought online in the second quarter. Results are compelling and are trending toward our 10 to 14 Bcf type curve.
These results, coupled with our continued lower drilling and completion cost, continued to support our ongoing field development plan. We've reduced our drilling days and cost in the Montney by approximately 30% since 2014. As John spoke earlier, we have taken on additional hedges for 2017 through 2020 as part of our strategy to lock in the terms given our low breakeven NPV at natural gas prices of CAD 2.10.
In the Kaybob Duvernay and Placid Montney, production's over 3,100 equivalents for the quarter at 44% liquids. In Kaybob Duvernay, our 4 well pad was brought online in the gas condensate area during the quarter and was previously drilled by our partner. 2 of these wells have an average effective lateral length of 4,150 feet, and the other 2 have an effective lateral length of 2,665 feet. While these lateral lengths are well below our future development plan, the pad is flowing in excess of 2,100 barrel equivalents per day with nearly 70% liquids after flowing for only 40 days utilizing our conservative choke management approach. Initial result was encouraging as the wells are trending along the tight curve and accounting through effective lateral length.
With the 2 varying exposed stimulator horizontal sections, we can tie lateral length to flow performance. We've been very impressed with the condensate to gas ratio as the wells are maintained at stabilized CGR of near 500, which is higher-than-average length in number. We further expect that as we move up the learning curve in this play, we will continue to refine completion techniques based on the first operated production flowbacks.
We'll be drilling our first operated new 2-well pad in the fourth quarter in the gas condensate region with production online in the first quarter of next year. Drilling and completion costs for this 2 well pad are expected to be $5.6 million per well. The average lateral length for these wells is near 4,500 feet, they were previously permitted by our partner on a limited by lease boundary shape. We'll be implementing a similar completion design we have done in Eagle Ford Shale, which includes pumping fracs of 2,000 pounds per foot.
Moving forward, we are working a plan in the Kaybob area to increase lateral lengths to over 9,000 feet, and we continue to pump fracs at 2,000 pounds per foot and tweak spacing of stages, et cetera, which will lead to higher rates in this area of the play and offer upside for Murphy. Over time, we've been very successful at lowering our drilling and completion costs in Eagle Ford and Montney and expect we'll do the same in the Duvernay play over time.
In our nonoperated Placid Montney, 4 wells were drilled and 8 more are planned for this winter. 4 of these wells will be completed late in the year and the remainder online in 2017.
As we close our call today, some takeaways. We're pleased with our overall results this year. As we move forward, we're focused on continuing well efficiencies, improving cost structure and preserving our balance sheet. Our high cash margin offshore assets provide the cash flow required to ramp up our new unconventional assets in the Duvernay as well as unlocking value in our Eagle Ford Shale and Montney businesses. As you can appreciate, oil and gas price have been very volatile over the past 2 years. However, we believe prices are stabilizing. We're in the middle of our internal budgeting process with the goal of maintaining cash flow neutrality, including our dividend. We have many great opportunities across our assets as we do every year, and we'll be releasing our 2017 guidance and CapEx in late January. We look forward to discussing those with you at that time.
This concludes our opening remarks. I'd like to open it up for your usual questions, and we'll go from there. Thank you.

componenttextpreview: We're trying to -- we obviously have a lot of options for both. They're all 3 of those concepts, Paul. We're in the middle of determining that now. I would like to have, at this time, probably a focus on the condensate region. But test black oil and furth
componenttext: We're trying to -- we obviously have a lot of options for both. They're all 3 of those concepts, Paul. We're in the middle of determining that now. I would like to have, at this time, probably a focus on the condensate region. But test black oil and further areas of gas condensate as well our volatile oil areas, like Eagle Ford Shale. And one of the reasons we went into the place is we feel we have all 3 there, high rate, high EUR gas condensate, very successful volatile oil areas and a very, very high issue for Murphy as to return in the black oil should that prove successful, which we applied no value at that acreage when we purchased this asset. So working on that. It's a tough call, but we're going to be spending capital in all 3 of those areas to both delineate and be able to production primarily for 2018 of that asset, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a hard call at this time. I think we need to -- we're just establishing our field development plan in our new asset. We just really started operating the field in August up there, and we have a permitting process in Canada that's longer than in Eag
componenttext: That's a hard call at this time. I think we need to -- we're just establishing our field development plan in our new asset. We just really started operating the field in August up there, and we have a permitting process in Canada that's longer than in Eagle Ford. And we are in the middle of doing that and setting up pads with this long lateral length and planning that. We're going to step into longer lateral lengths early there than we did in Eagle Ford, for sure. In a very short notice, you would probably go to Eagle Ford over that, but it will depend on the outcomes of this well. We're very happy about the results, very happy about what we planned and what we're seeing, very happy about the CGR, really nice wells to drill coming up this quarter that are next to some very high performing wells, some of the better performing wells from our partner. And all that will take into account some flexibility as to our field development plan, the pad layouts that we have, the areas in which we receive permits, comparing that back to Eagle Ford. But I'm glad to have the ability to move between them pretty easily, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, you just kind of touched on my first question. But can you remind us of where you are in the permitting process in terms of getting those longer lateral wells on schedule for 2017? Did you have to repermit all of kind of the baskets, kind of shorte
componenttext: Roger, you just kind of touched on my first question. But can you remind us of where you are in the permitting process in terms of getting those longer lateral wells on schedule for 2017? Did you have to repermit all of kind of the baskets, kind of shorter lateral wells? Or I guess where are we in that process?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We just started in August and September. This is a unique area in which there are no drilled uncompleted inventory of any kind in the whole entire play. We just completed the only 4 uncompleted wells we had, and they had 2 permits in which we're fixing th
componenttext: We just started in August and September. This is a unique area in which there are no drilled uncompleted inventory of any kind in the whole entire play. We just completed the only 4 uncompleted wells we had, and they had 2 permits in which we're fixing the drill. And we're starting over with the kind of wells we want, various options of shorter and longer lateral design across black oil, volatile oil and condensate, and we're not going to be held back by that. We have a plan and are out executing optionality around that as we speak.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So in terms of timing on the kind of the next spud behind the 2 wells, is that something kind of we should expect early '17?
componenttext: Got it. So in terms of timing on the kind of the next spud behind the 2 wells, is that something kind of we should expect early '17?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're going to be drilling and starting in November, and we have to drill 2 wells and complete them and flow them back, and we're very conservative on our choking of these wells. But we'll -- we may have it for our first call or be very close.
componenttext: Yes. We're going to be drilling and starting in November, and we have to drill 2 wells and complete them and flow them back, and we're very conservative on our choking of these wells. But we'll -- we may have it for our first call or be very close.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Appreciate that. And I understand that you guys don't want to get into the budget too much here, but any kind of high-level color you can give us on capital mix and how you guys are thinking about capital allocation for 2016? And then maybe which r
componenttext: Great. Appreciate that. And I understand that you guys don't want to get into the budget too much here, but any kind of high-level color you can give us on capital mix and how you guys are thinking about capital allocation for 2016? And then maybe which regions we would expect to see growth from kind of 4Q '16 to 4Q '17?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really prefer not to get into all that now. Have a lot of optionality around that. Real pleased about the capital allocation alternatives I have from a DPI perspective. And we're going to be spending a lot of money in our onshore business, and we also hav
componenttext: Really prefer not to get into all that now. Have a lot of optionality around that. Real pleased about the capital allocation alternatives I have from a DPI perspective. And we're going to be spending a lot of money in our onshore business, and we also have some very nice high return projects in our offshore business, such as the gas project in Malaysia, it's probably some of the highest rate of return we've seen in a while. And various types of spend like that. And not massive offshore spend, but we're going to have some offshore spend, and we're in the middle of getting that all allocated up right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one final housekeeping one from me. What's the expected net impact to Murphy from the comingling of that added zone at Kodiak?
componenttext: Great. And then just one final housekeeping one from me. What's the expected net impact to Murphy from the comingling of that added zone at Kodiak?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably a couple of thousand barrels a day.
componenttext: It's probably a couple of thousand barrels a day.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Peter Kissel with Scotia Howard Weil.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Peter Kissel with Scotia Howard Weil.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the Eagle Ford. You've been doing a lot there, and I'm just curious to see if you have an update on the inventory that you put up before. Roger, I think you mentioned 2,000 roughly locations, but with some of the bigger completions, does
componenttext: Quick question on the Eagle Ford. You've been doing a lot there, and I'm just curious to see if you have an update on the inventory that you put up before. Roger, I think you mentioned 2,000 roughly locations, but with some of the bigger completions, does that take down some of the traditional inventory that you've highlighted? I guess on the flip side, does the Austin Chalk or the Upper Eagle Ford maybe increase it?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have all that in that number, some 2,800 locations, and that's a lot of inventory, I feel, for our size company. And that latest location count to various spacings would account for these lateral lengths. We're expanding our lateral lengths in Catarina
componenttext: We have all that in that number, some 2,800 locations, and that's a lot of inventory, I feel, for our size company. And that latest location count to various spacings would account for these lateral lengths. We're expanding our lateral lengths in Catarina primarily, still have a lot of 5,000, 5,500 wells in Karnes because of the shape and the prior wells drilled there. So big, expansive, longer laterals are primarily located in Catarina, and that well count that we've been talking about would have all that in it. And our Upper Eagle Ford locations are very similar to what we broke out in the prior slide deck, and those will be maintained at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. And then one of the things you mentioned several times in the prepared remarks and one of the more impressive things is some of the cost reductions that you've seen. Have we reached the end of the cost reductions here? And is it more of an
componenttext: Got you. Okay. And then one of the things you mentioned several times in the prepared remarks and one of the more impressive things is some of the cost reductions that you've seen. Have we reached the end of the cost reductions here? And is it more of an efficiency gain game? Or kind of how you're thinking about that here?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been really, really proud of the efforts of my team here on this, and it's a misnomer that it's all about bidding. It's really 75% efficiency and a lot of work around chemical cost globally and exact amount of chemicals and doing a lot of rese
componenttext: Well, we've been really, really proud of the efforts of my team here on this, and it's a misnomer that it's all about bidding. It's really 75% efficiency and a lot of work around chemical cost globally and exact amount of chemicals and doing a lot of research around that. And so our savings is 75% efficiency and 25% rebidding of services. What we're trying to do in OpEx, and I think there's not a massive improvement left for us, but in our big businesses, like Eagle Ford, it was up a little bit this quarter due to some timing of some artificial lift and some workovers of rods and things of that nature. But what our goal here is to be a $7.50 player in -- through 2018 in this new business, Eagle Ford Shale that we built the last 5 years. So our goal is to get there. By the end of '18, I believe we will be. In our offshore business, so these shut-ins we'll go up next quarter as well. But overall, I'm pleased with the recovery of the Kikeh field, very pleased in fact, because that was quite risky for us to shut that big field in like that. And in general, happy there. And then really, what we want to be is a $9.00 BOE total company long term, and I think that will be a very successful company to be, with our high cash margin, the oil-weighted portfolio we have. And that's kind of where we're wanting to be. And Eagle Ford at $7.50 and the company at $9.00, and that's not off of where we are now. So I see that as a good plan and kind of where we're going to be.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. One quick last one from me. In terms of the portfolio, obviously, it's been a pretty active year in terms of acquisitions and divestitures, but how are you thinking about it going forward?
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. One quick last one from me. In terms of the portfolio, obviously, it's been a pretty active year in terms of acquisitions and divestitures, but how are you thinking about it going forward?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't really have a lot of noncore things. Our heavy oil would stick out as my goal of being an unconventional only North American player, and that would be the only thing that I consider not on that path at this time.
componenttext: We don't really have a lot of noncore things. Our heavy oil would stick out as my goal of being an unconventional only North American player, and that would be the only thing that I consider not on that path at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about acquisitions, Roger?
componenttext: What about acquisitions, Roger?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, we're very active looking at various things in both offshore and onshore. I think one of our advantages is we have the teams and ability to look at both. We very, very much know the North American onshore space and also looking globally as well in the
componenttext: Oh, we're very active looking at various things in both offshore and onshore. I think one of our advantages is we have the teams and ability to look at both. We very, very much know the North American onshore space and also looking globally as well in the offshore for certain areas where we could really believe that there'll be a lack of competition for fields that are discovered in certain countries. And we have the ability to execute and evaluate those and real pleased with what I'm seeing and hearing in that situation.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: About a year ago, you farmed into the new Vietnam block. Can you confirm that you have not had any activity there to date? And if not, any sense of what the plans might be for 2017?
componenttext: About a year ago, you farmed into the new Vietnam block. Can you confirm that you have not had any activity there to date? And if not, any sense of what the plans might be for 2017?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been working through a partnering arrangement there in a field development planning process. It's a little slower than we're used to in Malaysia, but we're very, very, very senior at working in that region and understand what we're doing there. We w
componenttext: We've been working through a partnering arrangement there in a field development planning process. It's a little slower than we're used to in Malaysia, but we're very, very, very senior at working in that region and understand what we're doing there. We would see activity in there next year in the drilling of a well, highly likely at this time. And we're very happy about that project and very happy about the running room in that block and continue to progress that. Just a little slower pace than we had desired, but it fit into our capital reductions this year that we had anyway. So looking to get back in there next year going with that. And the field development planning process, and the resource remains positive, in my view, very positive.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can also ask about the Kaybob, it's obviously not as much of a household name as the Eagle Ford for most operators. Have the results you've gotten to date over the last 6 months or so, have they met your original expectations when you did that as
componenttext: And if I can also ask about the Kaybob, it's obviously not as much of a household name as the Eagle Ford for most operators. Have the results you've gotten to date over the last 6 months or so, have they met your original expectations when you did that asset swap?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we only brought on 4 wells, and the other wells were drilled by the prior operator and quite overflowed for well over a year. There's been very little activity in the place for probably 14 months. So when we bought the play, we had EUR assumptions f
componenttext: Well, we only brought on 4 wells, and the other wells were drilled by the prior operator and quite overflowed for well over a year. There's been very little activity in the place for probably 14 months. So when we bought the play, we had EUR assumptions for volatile oil, gas condensate and black oil, black oil, which we put very little value, if any. And we've, since that time, broken this field into many EUR curves, which will be normal in shale operations, which we're very experienced at doing. And if you were to tie this up with the lateral length of the kind of wells we want to drill and what we're seeing from a linear concept between -- it's an advantage to have a short and a longer well, we can see how they flow side-by-side actually. And we're real happy about the EURs we assumed. Real happy about what we assumed when we purchased it. And this is going to be about lowering drilling costs, and we're going to lower drilling costs just like we did in all our other plays. And we add a lot of value here for the company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Edward Westlake with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Edward Westlake with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the Montney. I mean, obviously, well done on the completions. You've got a massive resource base there. What are the steps you have to take to get that gas production up and out to market?
componenttext: Just on the Montney. I mean, obviously, well done on the completions. You've got a massive resource base there. What are the steps you have to take to get that gas production up and out to market?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have TCPL agreements that can get us out of there at 200 million a day for some time. The plants are flowing now on a net basis when I say the 200. Naturally, it's a capital allocation decision, probably coming up late next year into early next y
componenttext: Well, we have TCPL agreements that can get us out of there at 200 million a day for some time. The plants are flowing now on a net basis when I say the 200. Naturally, it's a capital allocation decision, probably coming up late next year into early next year, if we want to expand in that play and work with midstream partners to build additional gas plants there. And we're now seeing very, very high EURs, very, very good economic returns. And we have that on our long-range plan list of positive capital allocation alternatives in the company. And they were also been very active at hedging, probably -- Murphy has never been a big hedging outfit. But up there, we are getting into 50% of production range to protect these returns, real happy about our operations, the uptime, the operating expenses, the EUR per well, and all those things are going well. And we lock in anything north of $2.10, we're doing very well. The DPR of these wells are very strong. And so we have set up and covered here to be able to handle these lower gas prices and are profiting from that, delivering free cash flow in that business every year, and we'll continue to do so, and we have a big decision to make if we want to expand it because we certainly have this subsurface ability to do so.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to make sure I heard you correctly, that decision will be late 2017, so CapEx, so maybe 2019?
componenttext: And just to make sure I heard you correctly, that decision will be late 2017, so CapEx, so maybe 2019?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it won't be like that, it would be a cap, it will be an issue around working with a midstream partner. Very happy with the midstream partner that we have. And it'll be about drilling wells for that person to execute that buildout, if you will. It will
componenttext: No, it won't be like that, it would be a cap, it will be an issue around working with a midstream partner. Very happy with the midstream partner that we have. And it'll be about drilling wells for that person to execute that buildout, if you will. It will be a decision. It won't be a capital constraint for those periods of time, if you catch my drift. They have to build a plant. We have to then drill the wells to meet the plant schedule, the permitting and all those various things, if we want to do that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we'll just watch the infrastructure guys there. And then on the Duvernay, I mean, obviously, it's still early days. I mean, given your experience, I mean, when do you think you'll have drilled enough wells to really get to the point where you can
componenttext: Yes, so we'll just watch the infrastructure guys there. And then on the Duvernay, I mean, obviously, it's still early days. I mean, given your experience, I mean, when do you think you'll have drilled enough wells to really get to the point where you can move to a development plan? I mean, it feels like, again, that's not next year. It's probably into 2018.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a field development plan now. It's just a matter of deciding, as to Paul's question, where we allocate the capital. We do not see any reason why we're not going to be successful at work here because we have so much acreage and so much optionality
componenttext: We have a field development plan now. It's just a matter of deciding, as to Paul's question, where we allocate the capital. We do not see any reason why we're not going to be successful at work here because we have so much acreage and so much optionality around different acreage that we own. It's just a matter of delineating and getting going. I consider some field development plan mode every day there, and there will be certain areas that would improve or go further down the list. And we'll -- through next year, a year from now, we'll be setting up for what we're going to do in '18. And the goal here is to replace the production, the higher margin that we sold in Syncrude, and I see us well on that ability and happy with the costs, operating expenses and all that. And real pleased about how that's going. And we're hitting this ground running pretty hard. With our experiences in Eagle Ford and Montney and what we learned about going to higher sand and going to longer laterals early is really helping us here, relocate a lot of staff around, building up that ability, doing things quicker and -- while still maintaining some of the Murphy conservatism we have like in flowback. These wells are flowing only on 14, 16 choke. So real happy about how all that's going right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Roger Read with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Roger Read with Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry about that earlier, but it's been one of those kind of days. Anyway, Eagle Ford Shale and CapEx. I guess, I want to understand in general, and I know you're hesitant to give us a specific CapEx number for '17, but as you think about whatever the rig
componenttext: Sorry about that earlier, but it's been one of those kind of days. Anyway, Eagle Ford Shale and CapEx. I guess, I want to understand in general, and I know you're hesitant to give us a specific CapEx number for '17, but as you think about whatever the right oil price may be, use a strip as an example today, and the cash flow you would generate, should we presume you're aiming for cash flow neutrality after CapEx and dividends? Is there a desire to build a cash balance? I mean, I know, not necessarily a necessity but maybe a preference as we try to think about it. And then as you think about an incremental dollar obviously, a lot of discussion here about Canada. But where does the Eagle Ford Shale fit in, in all that, given you've talked of fairly optimistic scenarios there in terms of well cost and the Austin Chalk as well?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do desire cash flow neutrality with our dividend as a corporation and working around that right now as an overall basis for us. In the Eagle Ford, CapEx is going to be going up. Production will not continue to decline. It will be flattened or slightly
componenttext: We do desire cash flow neutrality with our dividend as a corporation and working around that right now as an overall basis for us. In the Eagle Ford, CapEx is going to be going up. Production will not continue to decline. It will be flattened or slightly growing is the current plan. Real happy about that. It's the best these downspace wells in Catarina, some of the top in the company, and it's a matter of capital allocation around -- to put all the capital in there if we would like. But our Duvernay shale, we have to delineate this black oil, volatile oil, condensate, and we have to also prove that we can lower cost. And the only way to prove you can lower costs is to drill some pads. And you have to drill those pads aggressively with longer laterals. So it's going to be one of those kind of calls, Roger. We make production what you want it to be if you put all the capital and the best IP type wells, which lead to the better returns mostly -- usually. But we have a new unconventional shale business that has 0 ducks in it. So that's not that common, and we have that as a capital allocation decision. But we absolutely have to get in there and drill some wells. And our Eagle Ford will be there for us, and it's doing really, really well.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess along those lines, and I apologize again because I have been on and off the call, but have you given a CapEx number for Canada for the Duvernay or at least some broad guidance on what we should think about for next year?
componenttext: And I guess along those lines, and I apologize again because I have been on and off the call, but have you given a CapEx number for Canada for the Duvernay or at least some broad guidance on what we should think about for next year?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I have not.
componenttext: No, I have not.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got to wait till January, huh?
componenttext: Got to wait till January, huh?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's nothing wrong with waiting till January. It's just 90-some days away, Roger.
componenttext: There's nothing wrong with waiting till January. It's just 90-some days away, Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're asking Wall Street for patience, Roger, that's always a challenge.
componenttext: You're asking Wall Street for patience, Roger, that's always a challenge.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you know, it will be what it will be.
componenttext: Well, you know, it will be what it will be.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Roger, is just on the income statement. You had a pretty meaningful decline in G&A sequentially almost it's $12 million. Anything unusual in that number? Or is that a good run rate kind of going forward? Because you're at $74 million in
componenttext: My first question, Roger, is just on the income statement. You had a pretty meaningful decline in G&A sequentially almost it's $12 million. Anything unusual in that number? Or is that a good run rate kind of going forward? Because you're at $74 million in the first quarter, and you're $56 million this quarter so.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good run rate for us. We've had, unfortunately, some reductions in staff earlier in the year. And now those, call it, special items are rather behind us, and we're doing very, very well, on not just employees, but lowering G&A and G&A focus on our
componenttext: It's a good run rate for us. We've had, unfortunately, some reductions in staff earlier in the year. And now those, call it, special items are rather behind us, and we're doing very, very well, on not just employees, but lowering G&A and G&A focus on our company in general. And I think that's a good run rate number, what we're hoping to have next year or better. And that's where we're headed there, greatly improved in that situation.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's a permanent reduction. Okay, great. My second question is regarding the high density completions in the Eagle Ford. On the charts on Page 12, it looks like you guys have been doing this for well over a year. I just wanted to -- if you could know
componenttext: So that's a permanent reduction. Okay, great. My second question is regarding the high density completions in the Eagle Ford. On the charts on Page 12, it looks like you guys have been doing this for well over a year. I just wanted to -- if you could know this, is -- have the bulk of the completion over the past year been using these high density completions? Or are you shifting? Has it been more of a mix and then going forward you could benefit from a well productivity standpoint?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've only had probably 4 wells flow for over a year, and the others have flowed about 90 days, and we're now moving to it almost exclusively in Karnes and Catarina and Tilden as well, which is a big large acreage area for us, so of course the technology
componenttext: We've only had probably 4 wells flow for over a year, and the others have flowed about 90 days, and we're now moving to it almost exclusively in Karnes and Catarina and Tilden as well, which is a big large acreage area for us, so of course the technology works there as well. So we do not have still massive amounts of data on that, but we're very, very happy with what we're doing, and we know it's working in the industry here. And we show a long-term example, but that doesn't mean I have dozens of wells at that. But I'm real happy about how this is going. This Catarina area's very prolific for us, very low cost and doing very, very well, too.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my final question is just thinking about A&D activity. We have seen -- primarily a lot of the transactions have been in the Permian, but we have seen some things in the Gulf of Mexico as well as the Eagle Ford. How are you thinking about A&D act
componenttext: Okay. And my final question is just thinking about A&D activity. We have seen -- primarily a lot of the transactions have been in the Permian, but we have seen some things in the Gulf of Mexico as well as the Eagle Ford. How are you thinking about A&D activity? Could Brazil be an opportunity? Perhaps just give us where you're seeing some opportunities for perhaps Murphy to participate in?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in all 3 of those places for sure. We see one in Eagle Ford this week and some acreage surrounding our Catarina area, north and south there. Of course, an inch is as good as a mile in some of these plays sometime. And the offshore business, we're an
componenttext: Well, in all 3 of those places for sure. We see one in Eagle Ford this week and some acreage surrounding our Catarina area, north and south there. Of course, an inch is as good as a mile in some of these plays sometime. And the offshore business, we're an offshore company from the old days, and we look at opportunities there. And in Brazil, we're very excited about Brazil. We see them with needing companies like Murphy to develop fields that they have discovered prior, and these fields will have some level of delineation to them. There will be a market in there for super majors after the very, very large fields. We will be going after the smaller ones and things in which we operate. We do operate smaller FPSOs, TLPs, you name it. We operate everything globally and have been and can do this very well. We're very, very good at it, and we're going to be looking at those opportunities down there real hard.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Sean Sneeden with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Sean Sneeden with Oppenheimer.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, maybe for you. LOEs were down pretty nicely in the quarter. Could you just bridge us from the kind of roughly 8.36 per BOE in Q2 to the 7.65 in Q3?
componenttext: John, maybe for you. LOEs were down pretty nicely in the quarter. Could you just bridge us from the kind of roughly 8.36 per BOE in Q2 to the 7.65 in Q3?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, we had particularly in our operations in Malaysia, we had some one-off items this quarter with the cap. So our operator has been given us a number of projections at what our LOE was to be. And after a period of time, it became obvious that they were
componenttext: Sean, we had particularly in our operations in Malaysia, we had some one-off items this quarter with the cap. So our operator has been given us a number of projections at what our LOE was to be. And after a period of time, it became obvious that they were not going to run that high, so we adjusted for that. And so there's a little bit of benefit in there associated with that. So it's just a trueing up case, if you will, that benefits the third quarter.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Let me have a comment on that. I mean, our Kikeh recovery, our risk recovery to this Kikeh downtime is a big deal for us. And this is real live in our face right here, this recovery. And that's a big part of that business over there, is to get this field back going after not shutting in for a long time, 9 years, ever. We pride ourselves in less turnarounds than anyone else in the industry. It's the highest performing FPSO in the world, and we have that thing back on now and that can impact us. It's very positive for us.

componenttext: We have all the optionality around doing what we want to do on that with our capital, and like I spoke to earlier in the call, we have to consider big unconventional assets, that's new, that we're happy about, that we need to work on as well, that will need a ramp-up. componenttext: A couple of questions on Eagle Ford. The first is can you talk about the trajectory as you begin to ramp or get more wells online in the Eagle Ford, of what the impact would be, and how we should look at the oil mix in the Eagle Ford? And I've got another follow-up there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking now at that being slightly higher than it was this year, flat. We want to have a flat production business there long term that delivers free cash. And we have a model to do so and real happy to do so. As to the oil amount, I mean, you really
componenttext: We're looking now at that being slightly higher than it was this year, flat. We want to have a flat production business there long term that delivers free cash. And we have a model to do so and real happy to do so. As to the oil amount, I mean, you really ask a lot of questions on that issue. We're an oil-weighted company in there and very, very high oil-weighted. And in our comparisons from quarter-to-quarter, you have many, many issues going on there. You have some old historic wells, in which they would have some level of GOR creep I guess to them. But primarily what this is about is drilling our core acreage. And when we only drill 50 wells and we used to drill 150, we're drilling them near our facilities and capturing more gas than we used to capture. And we used to drill more on the peripheral parts of the field with multiple rigs running, and we were flaring some of that gas, and were not gathering all that gas. We're gathering more gas, and we've cut back on a lot of new wells that we used to drill. And 1% or 2% change off that is not a long-term factor, and we're very comfortable with the 89 type percent liquids in that business in which we also enjoy very little NGLs in our business. And our long-range plan and all of our PVT and all the work from 800 wells are not leading to a collapse on our liquid volumes in the Eagle Ford Shale at all.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're real happy about where that's going. Keep in mind that in a business like Eagle Ford Shale, before you get involved with the service companies, is that we have -- now we're looking at 7.9 days to drill a Karnes well now. It used to be 13 in 2015. Th
componenttext: We're real happy about where that's going. Keep in mind that in a business like Eagle Ford Shale, before you get involved with the service companies, is that we have -- now we're looking at 7.9 days to drill a Karnes well now. It used to be 13 in 2015. The Catarina well used to be 9.3 and now it's 7.3. So we've lowered drilling per field, in East Tilden 60%; Catarina, 75%; Tilden, 47%; Karnes, 85%. This is from the last 5 years. So -- and then in the last 2, incredible continuation of efficiency here on the wells. From a service perspective, we have a frac crew lined up for the entire year and are outbidding for spot crews as we need. They are about 50% less than they were in 2014 to accomplish these services. We feel firm about the contract that we have to deliver our fracturing services in Eagle Ford. We have a rig there that doesn't expire for some time into late next year. And we're seeing spot rigs in there for 15,000 a day to add additional rig, and we're probably at to a couple of rigs in that play. And I'm happy with the procurement and the bidding structure that we have to go through '17 and are able to maintain our cost, and that's not one of our main concerns in our budgeting at this time.

componenttext: Oh, I'm not coy about it at all. componenttext: No. So I feel we're very differentiated there because we're in a very low entry point across incredible amount of acreage we can delineate black oil, volatile oil and we can always go into the gas condensate area, which has been derisked by peers and doing very well there. headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure on the breakeven question as that would change my budget as to what I do. I don't think of it that way. I think of our company as a $50 type -- or let's just say the strip for '17 and a $60 company going forward, $60 flat that would be escala
componenttext: I'm not sure on the breakeven question as that would change my budget as to what I do. I don't think of it that way. I think of our company as a $50 type -- or let's just say the strip for '17 and a $60 company going forward, $60 flat that would be escalated like many peers use that type of number. And we desire to be a single-digit growth -- production growth company. Feel we can do that with the assets we have with certainty and deliver free cash. And that's the long range plan that I have in front of me, and that's what we're working to obtain and feel good about that like everyone else. I would need oil to go up from where it is today. And when it does, Murphy will be very well positioned with the assets that we have.

componenttext: No, we've said $8.50, $9.50 in the past. And the issue will be the new unconventional game we're in with no ducks there, which is a Ground Zero, which is not easy to do inside that. So that $8.50, $9.50 that I said in the past is maintained in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a very one-off strange occurrence, I will say because it's been an enormous capital spent by that party, and they still have a very large commitment there. So I'm not sure what's going to happen with that for them. We're a totally different sit
componenttext: Well, it's a very one-off strange occurrence, I will say because it's been an enormous capital spent by that party, and they still have a very large commitment there. So I'm not sure what's going to happen with that for them. We're a totally different situation. We do not have a well commitment there. To our east there is a very large acreage position that Chevron holds also with drilling commitments. They're quite large and rigs to be moved there, et cetera. Also in blocks next door to us, which BP has left, and Statoil remains their partner, which they formed in with BP at the time, so it's a very unique circumstance, I just know that we have some very large prospects and many of them on our block. It would be preferable for Murphy someone to drill next door. But I feel in things like this that there will be a well drilled down there by some of these folks at some period of time. And we will be there to take advantage of that at that time. And all I know is the blocks we have and the data we have and the prospectivity that we have is very good. And in the short term, it's hurtful for them to pull out, but overall this is a long-term game and we're in this thing for very low amount of capital.
